Annual Statement

Insurance regulators also monitor insurer solvency by reviewing industry-specific financial reports, such as the Annual Statement. An Annual Statement is a financial report that every insurer in the United States must file annually, with interim quarterly reports, with the NAIC and the insurance regulatory organization in each state in which the insurer conducts business to assist regulators with monitoring insurer solvency. In Canada, every life insurer must file the LIFE report, an accounting report that presents information about an insurer’s operations and financial performance, with the Office of the Superintendent of Financial Institutions (OSFI) and with the regulators of every province in which the insurer does business.

Industry-specific financial reports, such as the Annual Statement and the LIFE report, are designed to meet the specific requirements of insurance regulators, whose primary purpose is to safeguard insurer solvency and ensure that the company can take care of its obligations to customers, even if it stops doing business tomorrow.

 

Own Risk and Solvency Assessment

In 2008, in an effort to improve the insurance solvency regulatory framework in the United States, the NAIC launched a Solvency Modernization Initiative (SMI), which focused on certain key components, such as capital requirements, governance and risk management, group supervision, statutory accounting and financial reporting, and reinsurance.

To support the initiative, the NAIC also introduced the Own Risk and Solvency Assessment (ORSA), a solvency program that requires each insurer to regularly analyze all material risks that could affect the insurer’s ability to meet its financial obligations to its policyowners. In an ORSA, an insurer conducts an internal assessment of the risks associated with its current business plan and the adequacy of its capital resources to support those risks.

ORSA requires each insurer to

  • Conduct an ORSA annually—or whenever there are significant changes to the insurer’s risk profile—to evaluate the adequacy of its ERM framework and its current and future solvency positions

  • Provide details on the processes for assessing risk in both normal and stressed environments and document the results of the assessment of risk exposures

  • Detail how the insurer used various risk assessments to evaluate its capital adequacy and determine the amount of capital to hold for current and future business periods 3

Although the ORSA originated in Europe, the NAIC developed the Risk Management and Own Risk Solvency Assessment (ORSA) Model Act, which requires U.S. insurance companies in the U.S. to conduct an ORSA annually, unless otherwise exempt, and to submit the findings in the ORSA Summary Report. The following insight describes the three required sections that are included in the ORSA Summary Report.

INSIGHT

The ORSA Summary Report

The ORSA Summary Report consists of three sections:

  • Section 1: Description of the Insurer’s Risk Management Framework—Insurers must provide a summary of ORSA’s five risk management framework principles present in the company, as well as describe how the insurer identifies, evaluates, and mitigates its material risk exposures. We discuss risk management frameworks in further detail in Chapter 3. The insurer must also provide risk appetite statements and explain the relationship between risk tolerances and the amount and quality of capital supporting those risks.
  • Section 2: Insurer’s Assessment of Risk Exposures—Risks identified and prioritized as having the most potentially significant impact on the solvency of the insurer are assessed in this section. Insurers are required to assess qualitative and quantitative risks under both normal and stressed scenarios. The insurer must address the impact these risks have on its ability to meet capital requirements.
  • Section 3: Group Assessment of Risk Capital and Prospective Solvency Assessment—Insurers must describe how they combine qualitative and quantitative risk assessments to determine how much capital to hold for current and future business periods. This should be done at the group level, unless an insurer is not part of a group.
 

The Financial Analysis and Solvency Tracking System

A tool for evaluating the solvency of insurers operating in the United States is the Financial Analysis and Solvency Tracking (FAST) System, which is a collection of analytical solvency tools that include a ratio-based evaluation system established by the NAIC that is based on (1) ratio analysis of an insurer’s most recent financial statements and (2) analysis of a five-year history of specific aspects of an insurer’s financial statements. FAST is intended to assist regulators in prioritizing resources to those insurers in greatest need of regulatory attention. Regulators select the specific factors they will analyze on a case-by-case basis. Insurers whose financial statements produce unusual ratio results may be subject to corrective action by the state insurance department. FAST includes the Insurer Profiles System, the ratio-based NAIC Scoring System, and the Insurance Regulatory Information System.

 

The Insurance Regulatory Information System

The Insurance Regulatory Information System (IRIS), a tool within the FAST system, is a ratio-based evaluation system that monitors the financial condition of insurers with a view toward preventing insolvencies in the United States. IRIS uses 12 standardized financial ratios to identify insurance companies that are likely to experience financial difficulties. The purpose of IRIS is to aid insurance departments in identifying any insurers that deserve closer scrutiny. The information needed to calculate IRIS ratios comes from the Annual Statement each insurer must submit. Companies whose results on four or more ratios fall outside the usual range are required to undergo additional analysis.

 

Financial Condition Examination

Another tool insurance regulators use to monitor the solvency of insurers operating in the United States is a financial condition examination, which is part of an onsite formal regulatory audit that investigates two broad aspects of an insurer’s operations: (1) whether the insurer’s accounting records are accurate and the insurer is being operated on a sound and lawful basis, and (2) whether the insurer’s financial and business profiles contain any apparent hazards to the insurer’s solvency. Regulators typically conduct a financial condition examination every three to five years, usually in the insurer’s offices. A financial condition examination includes an examination report, which identifies potential problems and recommends solutions to the problems.

If a problem is uncovered during a financial condition examination, an insurer must respond in writing, typically within 30 days, to specify how the identified problem will be corrected. Based on their findings in the financial condition examination, regulators may take certain actions to protect the insurer’s policyowners. These actions range from ordering the insurer to correct identified problems to seizing control of the insurer in order to sell the insurer’s business and terminate its operations.

 

Insolvency

As discussed in Chapter 1, insolvency is a condition in which a business is unable to meet its obligations on time. When an insurer becomes financially unsound, insurance regulators generally are authorized to intervene in the insurer’s operations to protect policyowner interests. As we noted earlier, the RBC ratio measures capital levels and indicates the degree of regulatory intervention, if necessary.

State laws prescribe the following types of corrective action when an insurer’s financial soundness is impaired:

  • Before insolvency occurs, regulators may order an insurer to take specific corrective actions designed to improve the insurer’s financial condition. The insurer operates as usual apart from the specific required actions. The Model Hazardous Condition Regulation, a model law developed by the NAIC, describes the mandatory corrective actions an insurance commissioner can order an insurer to take to improve its financial condition.

  • Before insolvency occurs, regulators may place an insurer under administrative supervision, which is a legal condition under which an insurer may be required to obtain the insurance commissioner’s permission before taking any of a variety of specified actions. The NAIC developed the Model Supervision Act, also known as the Administrative Supervision Model Act, to provide details about a state insurance department’s authority to require administrative supervision of an insurer.

  • When more drastic regulatory action is required, state regulators may place the insurer in receivership. Receivership, also known as conservatorship, is an arrangement in which an individual—known as a receiver or conservator—is appointed by a court to hold and administer an insolvent insurer’s assets and liabilities. In receivership, regulators install a team of on-site supervisors who actively monitor the insurer’s ongoing operations. Insolvency may be declared concurrently with receivership or may be delayed. Either the insurer or the regulator may seek a declaration of insolvency.

The two possible outcomes of receivership are

  • Rehabilitation, in which regulators take over operation of the insolvent company from management and attempt to restore the company to solvent. In rehabilitation, an impaired insurer continues to operate and exist, but its sales and marketing activities usually are suspended. If the insurer cannot be rehabilitated, it is placed into liquidation.

  • Liquidation, in which a receiver either transfers all of the insurer’s business—including its reserve liabilities and assets—to other insurers or sells the insurer’s assets and terminates the insurer’s business. The receiver works to close down the business after collecting all assets and settling all obligations. Typically, a solvent insurer or several solvent insurers accept a permanent transfer of the insolvent insurer’s contractual obligations through a specific kind of reinsurance arrangement. The coverage provided to the customers of a failed insurance company under this kind of reinsurance arrangement is known as continuation coverage.

In the United States, state guaranty associations provide insurers with financial support for providing this continuation of coverage. A guaranty association is an organization that operates under the supervision of the state insurance commissioner to protect policyowners, insureds, beneficiaries, annuitants, payees, and assignees against losses that might result from the impairment or insolvency of an insurer that operates in that state. Outside of the United States, many countries have a national guaranty association. However, some small countries without a guaranty association may provide a government bailout to protect the customers of insolvent insurers.

The specific remedies that regulators are permitted to apply when an insurer becomes insolvent vary from jurisdiction to jurisdiction. In the United States, remedies vary somewhat from state to state, depending on applicable state insurance laws. The following chart shows the NAIC model laws that form the basis of such state laws.

Model Law

Summary Description

The Model Hazardous Condition Regulation
  • Authorizes regulators to order an insurer to take specified actions to improve its financial condition.

The Model Supervision Act
  • Authorizes regulators to require an insurer to gain permission from regulators before taking any of a variety of specified actions.

The Model Rehabilitation Act or, in some states, the Uniform Insurers Liquidation Act
  • Authorizes regulators to take over the operation of an insurance company.

The Model Regulation for Defining Companies in Hazardous Condition
  • Sets forth standards for identifying insurers found to be in such condition as to render the continuance of their business hazardous to the public or to holders of their policies or certificates of insurance.

Life and Health Insurance Guaranty Association Model Act
  • Enables the state guaranty association to provide protection to state residents who are holders of life insurance policies and annuities from an insolvent insurer.

Insurer Receivership Model Act
  • Helps conserve the assets of an insurer in a potentially hazardous condition, thus protecting the interests of the insurers, claimants, creditors, and the public.

Administrative Supervision Model Act
  • Outlines the parameters under which administrative supervision of an insurance company takes effect.

Source

Figure 2.2 lists examples of remedial actions available to regulators in cases of financial distress according to the Model Hazardous Condition Regulation and the Model Supervision Act.

 

International Standards

Around the world, insurance regulation differs from one jurisdiction to another. Within a jurisdiction, regulatory authority can vary based on the financial activity being regulated. In Canada, for instance, the federal government does not have jurisdiction over the securities industry. Each of the thirteen provincial and territorial governments regulates securities in its own jurisdiction. In contrast, Canadian insurance regulation is primarily a federal function. Federal insurance regulation primarily focuses on general account investments and addresses solvency, capital adequacy, and asset adequacy.

Typically, solvency regulation—or prudential regulation in many countries outside the United States—is the primary focus of insurance regulations throughout the world. Several international entities and standards are important in shaping insurance prudential regulation.

 

International Association of Insurance Supervisors

The International Association of Insurance Supervisors (IAIS) works globally to (1) improve regulatory supervision of the insurance industry, (2) maintain efficient, fair, safe, and stable insurance markets, (3) protect policyowners, (4) promote well-regulated insurance markets, and (5) support global financial stability. The IAIS is comprised of insurance regulators and supervisors from over 200 jurisdictions, which constitute most of the world's insurance premiums.

At the time of this text’s publication, the IAIS was developing its Insurance Capital Standard (ICS), which will provide a more uniform approach to RBC requirements among insurance supervisors across jurisdictions. The ICS will affect Internationally Active Insurance Groups (IAIGs), which the IAIS describes as large multinational financial services companies that engage in insurance activities in at least three jurisdictions. To qualify as an IAIG, a company must also conduct a certain percentage of premium business outside of its home jurisdiction and hold a specified minimum amount of total assets.

The IAIS is developing its ICS as part of the Common Framework for the Supervision of Internationally Active Insurance Groups (ComFrame). ComFrame will provide a set of international supervisory requirements designed to effectively coordinate supervision of IAIGs across jurisdictions.

 

Basel III

The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision (BCBS) is a membership organization comprising representatives of bank supervisory authorities and central banks from countries with prominent economies, including the United States, with a mission to provide a forum for discussing bank supervision matters worldwide. The BCBS developed Basel III, which is a comprehensive set of financial supervision reform measures designed to strengthen the regulation, supervision, and risk management of the banking, insurance, and securities sectors globally. Created in response to the 2008 financial crisis, Basel III aims to promote stability in financial systems through its reforms. Specifically, Basel III’s goals are to improve the capital holdings of financial services companies, reduce the amount of risk they assume, and increase their transparency. The United States is attempting to integrate Basel III into the requirements of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act. 4

 

Solvency II

Solvency II is a European-sponsored solvency standard for insurance companies, designed to support solvency testing and supervision in the public interest. Based on Basel III, Solvency II is also known as the EU Directive on the Taking-up and Pursuit of the Business of Insurance and Reinsurance. Solvency II introduced RBC requirements, which influenced the asset allocation decisions of many insurers in the EU. One of the key elements of Solvency II is the ORSA, which other countries and jurisdictions, including the United States, have adopted and implemented. The ORSA program in Solvency II requires each insurer to determine the capital necessary to ensure its overall solvency needs are met at all times.

 

ISO

The International Organization for Standardization (ISO) is an independent, non-governmental international standards-setting organization that consists of national standards bodies of 164 countries. A national standards body (NSB) is a country’s sole standardization organization and the country’s representing member of ISO. ISO member organizations can be non-governmental or governmental organizations.

 

COSO

The Conference of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO) is a consortium of self-regulatory member organizations that provides frameworks and guidance on enterprise risk management, internal control, and fraud defense. COSO members include the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants (AICPA), the Institute of Internal Auditors (IIA), the American Accounting Association, the Institute of Management Accounts (IMA), and Financial Executives International (FEI). COSO maintains frameworks that provide principles-based guidance for designing and implementing effective internal controls. We provide a more in-depth discussion of frameworks and internal controls in the next chapter.

pages.title: Risks Insurers Manage
pages.contents:
Risks Insurers Manage

As we have mentioned, insurance company solvency is directly linked to a company’s ability to manage the risks associated with its investments, pricing, business, and operations. Each company may categorize and name risks differently, so you may know some of these risks by another name.

 

Investment Risk

Any time a company invests its funds with an expectation of earning a profit, the company is taking an investment risk. From an insurer’s perspective, an investment risk is the possibility that an investment may fail to generate some or all of an expected profit or that the insurer will lose all or part of the original investment. All investing activities involve some element of risk. The types of investment risk that have the greatest priority for life insurers are credit risk and market risk.

 

Credit Risk

Because insurers hold a large amount of debt securities in their general accounts, credit risk exposures are one of the main threats for insurer portfolios. Credit risk is the risk that (1) a borrower defaults on debt obligations by failing to make payments of principal or interest on time, or (2) a lender sustains a financial loss based on an adverse change in a borrower’s creditworthiness. These two categories of credit risk are also known as default risk and downgrade risk:

  • In the context of investing, default risk is the risk that an insurer will not receive the cash flows to which it is entitled because a party with which the insurer has a financial arrangement is late with payments or entirely fails to fulfill its debt obligations. Default risk affects all types of debt securities and also affects corporate equity securities, which lose substantial market value if the issuing company defaults on its debt obligations and becomes insolvent.

EXAMPLE

Blocksmith Insurance issues a loan to Forthright Financial. Two months later, Forthright fails to make scheduled interest payments as promised and goes bankrupt. Because Forthright will likely be unable to pay the loan back in full, Blocksmith suffers a loss, and its solvency could be affected.

  • Downgrade risk involves the risk of the deterioration in a credit rating assigned to an issuer of a debt security. A credit downgrade does not affect payments of principal or interest to investors. However, market value decreases usually accompany downgrades. Thus, if an investor must sell a downgraded security before maturity, the amount of money raised by the sale will be lower than it would have been prior to the downgrade.

EXAMPLE

Blocksmith Insurance owns a bond issued by Camion Corporation. Camion receives a reduction in its credit rating—a rating downgrade. As a result, investors perceive bonds issued by Camion to be riskier and less valuable than before the downgrade. If Blocksmith sells its Camion bond, it will receive less money than it would have if it sold the bond before Camion was downgraded. Thus, Camion’s rating downgrade reduced the value of Blocksmith’s bond investment.

The main threat of credit risk is that, when an investment goes into default or is downgraded, its market value also decreases. Typically, defaults cause larger market value drops than downgrades.

 

Market Risk

Another investment risk, market risk, is the risk of losses or reduced investment returns caused by movements in overall market conditions or in a specific sector of the market. Market risk can take many forms, including equity risk, inflation risk, interest-rate risk, reinvestment-rate risk, currency risk, foreign investment risk, and liquidity risk.

Equity risk is the risk of a loss arising from movements in the direction of the stock, or equity, markets. The market price of shares varies depending on demand and supply, among other factors.

EXAMPLE

Blocksmith Insurance, like most insurers, doesn’t invest heavily in the stock market, but it does have some stock investments. As a result, Blocksmith is exposed to equity risk when market conditions change. Because Blocksmith limits the amount of stock it owns, however, it also limits its exposure to equity risk.

Inflation risk is the risk that the price of goods and services will increase over time, causing a decline in the value of investments and returns. During periods of inflation, market interest rates and the cost of most goods and services increase. For insurers, those increases have a direct impact on the profitability of their fixed-rate products, such as fixed cash value life insurance and fixed deferred annuity products.

The value of an investment return is affected by the value of money. Over time, inflation erodes the value of money, also known as money’s purchasing power. The presence of inflation requires an investor to earn a rate of return greater than or equal to the expected inflation rate in order to avoid losing purchasing power.

EXAMPLE

Blocksmith Insurance owns a bond with a fixed interest rate of four percent. During the period that Blocksmith owns the bond, the inflation rate increases to five percent, causing the prices of goods and services to rise. In addition, the rate of price increases is higher than the rate that Blocksmith is earning in bond interest. As a result, goods and services are becoming more expensive for Blocksmith, but the amount of bond interest that Blocksmith receives is not keeping pace. In other words, because of rising inflation, the purchasing power of the bond’s interest payments is declining.

Interest-rate risk, a contingency risk we described earlier, is the risk that unpredictable movements in market interest rates will cause the value of an investment to change. An insurer’s assets can lose value or its liabilities can gain value as a result of fluctuations in market interest rates.

The market values of existing interest-bearing investments generally have an inverse relationship with market interest rates. Thus, for interest-bearing investments—such as bonds and mortgage loans—the market value of an existing investment will

  • Decrease as market interest rates increase

  • Increase as market interest rates decrease

Changes in interest rates have a significant impact on insurers because the majority of their investments are fixed income products, such as bonds. For instance, in rising interest-rate environments, existing bonds typically fall in market value because new bonds offer higher interest rates, which are more attractive to investors. In such cases, an investor can hold existing bonds to maturity, thus avoiding selling them at unfavorable market values. Life insurance companies generally purchase bonds and other debt securities with the intention of holding them to maturity. Investments in mortgages and other fixed-rate investments are also subject to interest-rate risk.

EXAMPLE

Blocksmith Insurance owns a block of commercial mortgage loans. When Blocksmith purchased the mortgages, they paid the same interest rate as the market interest rate, which was four percent. The market interest rate is now five percent. Because Blocksmith is still earning four percent interest on its mortgages, the value of its investment has decreased. If Blocksmith sells the mortgages, it will need to discount the price to make them attractive to potential buyers.

Reinvestment-rate risk is the risk that a change in interest rates will lead to lower income when owners reinvest their funds. It refers to the possibility that owners will have to reinvest funds at a lower rate of return than the investment originally earned.

Insurers’ bond investments are susceptible to reinvestment-rate risk. When bonds mature and insurers reinvest their funds, they must invest at the current rates. If those rates are lower than the original rates, the insurer will earn a lower rate on its funds. The same is true for bonds that can be repaid before their maturity date.

EXAMPLE

Five years ago, when Blocksmith Insurance purchased a series of callable bonds issued by the Noblock Corporation, the market interest rate was five percent. The bonds, which also paid an interest rate of five percent, had a 10-year maturity date. However, after six years, Noblock called, or repaid, the bonds. At the time of the bond call, the market interest rate had fallen to three percent. When Blocksmith reinvested its funds from the call into bonds also paying a three percent interest rate, it wasn’t able to earn as much in interest payments as it had previously, when its bonds paid five percent.

Currency risk, also known as foreign exchange risk, is the risk arising from changes in currency exchange rates. Insurers that operate in more than one country or that invest in securities that are denominated in a foreign currency are subject to currency risk.

When one currency falls in relation to another, the falling currency loses relative value and the rising currency gains relative value. Generally, currency risk can arise from geopolitical factors, fluctuations in the supply and demand of a country’s manufactured goods, inflation, and changes in government leadership.

EXAMPLE

Although Blocksmith Insurance currently operates only in the United States, it plans to open offices in China in the next year. Blocksmith’s overseas operations will likely expose the company to currency risk. To set up its offices, Blocksmith will need to convert U.S. dollars into Chinese yuan. If, between the planning period and the conversion date, the value of the yuan rises relative to the value of the dollar, then the amount of dollars that Blocksmith set aside will not purchase as much in China as was thought during planning. In effect, because of the weaker dollar, Blocksmith will end up paying more in dollars to rent offices and hire staff in China than it originally planned.

Foreign investment risk is the risk of loss when investing in a foreign company if the government where the company is domiciled takes actions such as nationalization or increased taxation. Nationalization occurs when the government takes control of a private company or industry with or without compensating the former owners.

EXAMPLE

Blocksmith Insurance invests in significant assets in a foreign country. If nationalization occurs in the foreign country in which Blocksmith invested, Blocksmith is at risk of having its assets seized by the government without compensation.

Liquidity risk is the risk that an asset might not be easily sold for its underlying value. This risk can arise from a lack of buyers, lack of secondary markets, or the structure of the investment. Liquidity risk is important to insurers because they must have enough cash and liquid assets on hand at all times to pay their policy benefits as they come due. If a company’s cash and liquid assets are not sufficient to cover these financial obligations, the company could be forced to sell long-term assets to meet its current needs or borrow cash on unfavorable terms, which could threaten its solvency.

EXAMPLE

Blocksmith Insurance received an unusually high number of life insurance claims and didn’t have enough cash on hand to pay the contractual benefits due. In order to meet its contractual obligations, Blocksmith had to sell existing assets below their underlying value and borrow cash from a lender at a higher interest rate than it would otherwise have considered.

 

Pricing Risk

In addition to the operational and business risks that all companies face, insurers face risks that are unique to the insurance business. One of the most important of these is pricing risk, a contingency risk we described earlier in this chapter.

For insurers, pricing is complicated because the amount and timing of many of the costs associated with insurance products are unknown. For example, when an insurer designs a life insurance product, it can only estimate how much in benefits it will have to pay in a given year. If more insureds die than the company anticipated, it will have to pay more in death benefits than it planned. If differences are great enough, the company may even lose money on the product.

In addition, insurers manage underwriting risk, which is the specific risk that insurers assume through the insurance and annuity contracts they underwrite. Underwriters must follow the insurer’s underwriting philosophy, a set of objectives that guides all of an insurer’s underwriting actions when selecting risks. If underwriters select risks outside of the parameters designated during pricing, the product may not meet profitability goals.

 

Mortality Risk

One of the most significant pricing risks for life insurers is mortality risk, which is the risk that actual mortality—the incidence of death in a specified group of people—will differ from expectations. For life insurance, mortality risk is the likelihood that a person will die sooner than statistically expected; for annuities, it is the likelihood that a person will live longer than statistically expected.

Recall from Chapter 1 that actuaries are responsible for performing experience analysis. Actuaries typically review the mortality experience data associated with a new product at the end of a specified period to compare actual mortality rates and assumed mortality rates. This evaluation is important because differences can affect company reserves and its results on the balance sheet and income statement. The evaluation may also affect future products and services.

EXAMPLE

Blocksmith Insurance released a new term life product four years ago. The product’s profits were lower than anticipated; therefore, Blocksmith’s actuaries performed experience analysis on the product to see if the actual experience corresponded with the assumptions they previously made. The actuaries found that actual mortality rates were higher than the model’s assumptions. Since the actual mortality rates were higher than the expected mortality rates of the new product, Blocksmith failed to make an adequate amount of profit on this product.

 

Expense Risk

Another significant pricing risk insurers face is expense risk, which is the risk that actual expenses will differ from the amounts assumed during product design. The company estimates its operating expenses, such as salaries, agent compensation, rent, and legal fees, in an expense budget, which is a financial plan of action that identifies the types and amounts of expenses a company expects to incur during an accounting period.

Most of the information insurers use to estimate product expenses comes from the company’s past experience data. However, due to changes in economic and business conditions, a company’s actual experience can differ from its expected experience. Like an unexpectedly high mortality rate for life insurance products, unexpectedly high expenses can lead to lower profits and could even create losses.

EXAMPLE

In designing a new annuity product, Blocksmith Insurance used assumptions for expenses that turned out to be much lower than the expenses it experienced in supporting the product. As a result, Blocksmith ended up losing money on the product.

An insurer builds its operating expenses into product design so that these expenses are passed along in the form of charges to customers. The amount charged to cover each policy’s share of the expenses of operation is called expense loading. Expense loading is a cost area that can vary from company to company based on its operations and efficiency.

An insurance company’s operating expenses affect not only product design, but also the company’s competitive position in the marketplace. Through careful expense management, an insurer can reduce its operating expenses, thereby requiring less expense loading. In this way, the insurer improves its operational efficiency and its competitive position.

 

Policyholder Behavior Risk

Policyholder behavior risk, or customer behavior risk, is the risk that policyholder actions or decisions will adversely affect product performance. This risk is especially high for actions or behaviors that affect product persistency. Although life insurance and annuity products are typically intended to stay in force for a relatively long time before benefits become payable, customers sometimes stop paying premiums, causing a lapse—termination due to nonpayment of premiums—of their policies. Other customers may decide to surrender their policies. A surrender occurs when the owner of a cash value life insurance policy or a deferred annuity chooses to receive the contract’s monetary value before the contract matures. If the number of lapses or surrenders exceeds the number planned for in product design, profitability can be negatively affected because the lapses and surrenders

  • Eliminate future income streams from premium payments

  • Can prevent the company from recovering its product costs

EXAMPLE

Due to an economic downturn, Blocksmith Insurance’s new product did not perform as well as Blocksmith had anticipated. The actual amount of policyholder lapses and surrenders for the new product was higher than was assumed when the policy was designed, which led to a loss on the product.

Insurers can often reduce the negative effects of policyholder behaviors, such as excessive lapses and surrenders, by adding margins, or extra amounts, to the expense amounts in their product designs. Margins provide a cushion in case actual expenses caused by policyholder behavior exceed assumed expenses. Insurers can also reduce the impact of excess lapses and surrenders by assessing surrender charges on lapses or surrenders that occur during the early years of certain policies, or by implementing customer retention programs to reduce overall lapse rates. We will discuss how operating expenses and policyholder behavior expenses are incorporated into product design in Chapter 9.

A type of policyholder behavior risk that insurers face is antiselection risk, also called adverse selection risk, which is the risk of loss or adverse product performance due to the tendency of individuals who believe they have a greater-than-average likelihood of loss to seek insurance protection to a greater extent than do those who believe they have an average or a less-than-average likelihood of loss. Insurers manage antiselection risk by ensuring that underwriters assess each risk carefully and by including provisions such as the incontestability provision in their policies.

 

Business Risk

A risk category common to companies in all industries is business risk, which is the risk that changes in a company’s external environment will affect its operations. Business risks include regulatory risk, competition risk, event risk, and geopolitical risk. Some companies also recognize industry risk, which focuses on changes in the external environment specifically shared by companies in the same industry.

Regulatory risk is the risk created by changes in the regulatory environment. Regulatory risk includes the risk of loss associated with non-compliance with laws, rules, or regulations. In addition to complying with current laws and regulations, insurers must keep up with constant regulatory changes, as oversight of the insurance industry continues to receive heightened scrutiny. These constant changes can negatively affect company performance. For example, insurers often devote substantial resources to prepare for new laws and regulations. These efforts can place a huge strain on a company and can even threaten its solvency.

EXAMPLE

As a result of the NAIC’s Risk Management and Own Risk Solvency Assessment Model Act, large and medium insurers in the United States are now required to regularly perform an ORSA and file a confidential ORSA Summary Report with regulators. Complying with this new law takes time and resources, including staff, technology, and in some cases, consultants, as insurers attempt to make improvements to their ERM frameworks to comply with ORSA.

Competition risk is the risk that an insurer’s relative market position will be adversely affected by the actions of its direct competitors, changes in industry structure, or changes in standards for the use of technology.

EXAMPLE

Advances in technology are changing the way most insurance companies do business. Computer software programs can significantly reduce the time needed to underwrite applications and reduce the number of errors that occur during processing. If one insurer decides to purchase a new kind of software, other companies are likely to make similar purchases; failure to do so could mean losing customers to competitors.

Event risk is the risk that a single, unforeseen occurrence will negatively impact a company’s financial position. Occasionally, companies may face events that unexpectedly affect their ability to continue business operations or to meet debt obligations. A common example is a natural disaster, such as a hurricane, tornado, or fire. Other examples include hostile takeovers and terrorist attacks.

EXAMPLE

The city in which Blocksmith Insurance has its main headquarters sustained widespread flooding. Entire areas of the city remained shut down for weeks, leaving Blocksmith to operate under its business continuity plan. Because mail service had to be suspended, Blocksmith was unable to get premium notices to its customers and consequently took in a lower premium amount than it expected. Blocksmith needed to use some of its surplus to pay claims during this time, which over time could threaten the company’s solvency.

Geopolitical risk is the risk of loss due to unexpected changes in international relationships, political alignments, socioeconomics, or cultural shifts. Global companies are likely to be affected, but regional and national companies need to manage this risk as well.

EXAMPLE

Example 1: Increased tensions between two countries drove up the price of oil. This event reduced discretionary income available to the average consumer and changed buying behaviors locally.

Example 2: A banking crisis in one region drives investors to purchase bonds and other conservative investments in another region. The resulting reduction in bond yields affects consumer and insurer investment portfolios.

 

Operational Risk

Operational risk is the risk of financial losses resulting from inadequate or failed internal processes, controls, systems, and people. These risks can arise in any operational area of the company, including marketing, product development, claim administration, information technology, underwriting, and customer service. Operational risk is challenging because one situation can pose multiple risks to multiple operational areas. The types of operational risk we will discuss are strategy risk, distribution risk, reputation risk, human resources risk, business process risk, cyber risk, and fraud risk.

Strategy risk is the risk that a particular strategy selected by an insurer to grow sales, market share, profits, or distribution will not produce the desired results and instead lead to losses.

EXAMPLE

An insurer decides to expand its product portfolio to include variable products. The insurer makes significant investments in product development, new systems, distribution channels, and staff training. However, the variable product sales are significantly less than expected and insufficient to recover the investments made to develop the new line.

Distribution risk is the risk of financial losses resulting from activities and resources involved in making products available to customers. Given the crucial role distribution channels play in the insurance business, this risk can potentially threaten a company’s financial condition.

EXAMPLE

The compensation structure at Blocksmith Insurance is set up to reward agents who sell a new insurance policy by providing them with income for each policy sold. If there are no built-in procedures to safeguard against churning, this compensation structure may encourage unscrupulous agents to induce policyholders to replace existing policies with new ones multiple times purely so that the agents can earn additional compensation.

Reputation risk is the risk of loss due to damage or a decline in an insurer’s image, which can lead to the loss of customers’ trust. While monetary losses due to reputation risk can typically be quantified, it is difficult to measure the damage done to a company’s reputation.

EXAMPLE

Blocksmith Insurance receives negative reviews by industry experts and downgrades by rating companies, both of which have an adverse effect on the insurer’s reputation. The public perception of Blocksmith declines, thereby negatively affecting its revenue.

Human resources risk is the risk that a loss will occur as a result of a company’s failure to properly train or evaluate prospective and current employees. The human resources function is responsible for recruiting and screening job applicants, selecting qualified employees, and providing proper orientation, training, and development programs.

EXAMPLE

An unexpected jump in sales at Blocksmith Insurance caused a staff shortage in the new business department. A number of temporary staff were hired to cover the shortage, but in the rush they were not given sufficient training and management was spread thin. The results were an increase in errors and rework on newly sold policies and a reduction in sales as financial professionals took their business to other companies.

Business process risk, the risk of a loss related to the processes used by the organization to create, sell, and service products, is another type of operational risk. The loss can be a result of an inefficient or ineffective business process or can be a result of a company’s failure to adhere to a business process. Both inefficient and ineffective processes result in higher costs, longer service times, and increased quality errors. Because business processes are internal factors controllable by the company, business process risk is distinct from other types of risk that may involve factors that are external to the insurer.

Most processes are part of a company’s day-to-day business operations and are in place to ensure that company goals are met and procedures followed. Sometimes deviating from current business processes can lead to innovation and process improvements. However, departing from an existing business process, whether intentional or not, often results in an ineffective and inefficient process.

EXAMPLE

Blocksmith Insurance has implemented new practices in its call center. While employees get accustomed to the changes, the call center has become less efficient, thus creating long turnaround times. The decrease in customer service even results in a loss of business.

Cyber risk is the risk of a financial loss, business disruption, theft of proprietary information, or damage to the reputation of an organization caused by failure in a process, procedure, or technology involving interconnected systems. For example, using “password” or “12345” as access passwords to a system is a cybersecurity risk based solely on a business practice. Insurers and insurance agents must protect the highly sensitive customer medical and financial information collected as part of the underwriting and claims processes.

Fraud risk involves loss resulting from one party intentionally deceiving another party and inducing that party to part with something of value, usually confidential information or money. Losses caused by fraudulent activities affect insurers’ profits and potentially their financial soundness and reputation.

Both internal and external parties to an insurance company can commit fraud. The sources of internal fraud include the insurer’s employees and sales force. Common types of internal fraud include

  • Submission or approval of fictitious policies or policies that have not been authorized by the proposed customer

  • Theft of premium or annuity payments that the customer intends to pay the insurer

  • Approval of fictitious claims and theft of policy values the insurer intends to pay to the customer

  • Improper relationships with vendors or consultants, such as relationships involving conflicts of interest

External perpetrators of insurance fraud include insureds, healthcare providers, vendors, and organized crime.

EXAMPLE

An imposter contacts Blocksmith Insurance’s customer service, posing as one of the company’s clients. The imposter pretends to have forgotten his password and asks the CSR to change it for him. If the CSR does not detect the fraud, the imposter may use his new access to the client’s account to steal funds or learn more about the client’s financial information or other sensitive data.

Now that you know the typical risks life insurers face, we will discuss the strategies and programs companies use to manage these risks. Over the years, insurers have used a number of risk management strategies. At first, these strategies were confined to various operational units of the organization, but with the passage of time, some strategies expanded beyond any single unit. In recent years, most life insurance companies have begun to manage risks as a corporate portfolio of risks and opportunities, while keeping in place the long-standing systems for managing risks at the operational level.

In this chapter, we will first explore some basic risk management strategies and the role risk management plays in life insurance companies. Then we will detail certain components of risk management programs including enterprise risk management, asset-liability management, expense risk management, and operational risk management.

pages.title: Basic Risk Management Strategies
pages.contents:
Basic Risk Management Strategies

Recall from Chapter 1 that risk management is the process of systematically identifying, assessing, and minimizing the negative impact of risk. Because the effects of an unexpected financial loss can be severe, individuals and businesses usually seek to limit their exposure to risk whenever possible, especially if the risk severity exceeds the likely expected gain. Whether explicitly or implicitly, most insurers have risk management philosophies and strategies. Insurers generally rely on five basic strategies for managing financial and other risks: (1) avoiding risk, (2) accepting risk, (3) controlling risk, (4) transferring risk, and (5) exploiting risk.

 

Avoiding Risk

The first and perhaps most obvious method of managing risk is simply to avoid it altogether. Avoiding risk involves taking actions to eliminate a person’s or company’s exposure to risk. Avoidance is a good strategy for risks that are likely to have a large impact or cause large losses. Insurance companies can avoid some product risks by rejecting applications for life insurance if the proposed insured does not meet insurability standards. Another way insurers can avoid certain risks is by including provisions in their policies that restrict payment of benefits in specified situations; depending on the conditions of the provision, this is also a form of controlling risk.

EXAMPLE

Blocksmith Insurance receives an application for a life insurance policy. When processing the application and determining the proposed insured’s level of risk, Blocksmith discovers the proposed insured has recently been diagnosed with terminal cancer. In accordance with company insurability standards, Blocksmith rejects the application for life insurance and does not issue the policy, thus, avoiding the risk.

Unfortunately, neither individuals nor insurance companies can avoid all risks. Because insurance companies are in the business of taking on risk, avoiding risk is not always a practical risk management strategy. Insurers can, however, control the negative effects of those risks by taking steps to reduce their potential losses.

 

Accepting Risk

Another strategy to manage risk is to accept, or retain, risk. To accept a risk is to recognize the existence of the risk and accept financial responsibility for that risk. The company or individual may still mitigate the potential losses from the risk by controlling or transferring the risk, but some or all of the financial responsibility remains with the party who accepted the risk.

EXAMPLE

Blocksmith’s underwriters determine that a recent application for insurance meets the company’s insurability standards. Blocksmith approves the application and issues a policy, thus, accepting the risk.

Note that simply choosing to ignore the existence of a risk is not risk acceptance. Risk acceptance requires recognition of a risk and the explicit choice not to avoid, control, transfer, or exploit it.

 

Controlling Risk

Controlling, or mitigating, risk is the most commonly used risk management strategy. This strategy involves taking steps to reduce potential losses that may result from a given risk exposure. For example, insurers can reduce their overall losses on high-risk products by redesigning products.

EXAMPLE

During the economic downturn of 2008, many insurers that issued a substantial amount of variable annuities (VAs) with secondary guarantees incurred losses on these products. As a result, insurers redesigned these products to minimize potential losses in the future. Newer-generation VAs often come with higher charges and more restrictive guarantees.

Another way that insurers control risk is through their underwriting guidelines.

EXAMPLE

Like most life insurers, Blocksmith Insurance classifies proposed insureds according to the risk they present to the company. If an applicant represents a higher-than-average risk, Blocksmith can accept the risk but minimize its effect by charging the applicant a higher premium rate than it would charge a similar applicant who represents an average or a lower-than-average risk.

Many aspects of product development are influenced by the need to control risk. See the following table for examples of low-risk and high-risk elements that can be associated with a product.

Lower-Risk Elements

Higher-Risk Elements

Smaller face amounts on life insurance policies

Larger face amounts on life insurance policies

Shorter payout periods on annuities

Longer payout periods on annuities

Annuities that begin payout at a later date

Annuities that begin payout immediately

Stricter underwriting guidelines

Looser underwriting guidelines

Policy exclusion provisions

 No exclusion provisions

Surrender charges

 No surrender charges
 

Transferring Risk

Another method of managing risk is to transfer it. Transferring risk involves shifting the financial responsibility associated with that risk to another party, usually through financial products that involve a fee for the transfer. The most common way for most individuals and businesses to transfer risk is to purchase insurance coverage.

Insurers also transfer their risk under insurance and annuity contracts by purchasing reinsurance. Recall from Chapter 1 that reinsurance is insurance that one insurance company—known as the direct writer—purchases from another insurance company—known as the reinsurer—to transfer all or part of the risk on insurance policies that the direct writer issued.

EXAMPLE

Blocksmith decides to purchase reinsurance to cover part of the death benefit payouts for a block of life insurance policies. In this case, Blocksmith is transferring part of its risk on this block to the reinsurer.

When an insurer transfers risk through reinsurance, the insurer does not necessarily avoid all exposure to risk. In such cases, the direct writer must accept the risk that the reinsurer will fail to perform its part of the agreement.

Note that when an insurer uses reinsurance to transfer part of the risk on a life insurance policy or annuity contract, the insurer is also controlling its risk exposure by sharing part of the contract’s liability. In other words, controlling risk and transferring risk are not always mutually exclusive events. Similarly, if the insurer does not transfer all of the risk on a policy or contract, the insurer is accepting any risk that remains.

EXAMPLE

Insurers that use surrender charges are both controlling and transferring risk. For example, by imposing a surrender charge for the first several years of a deferred annuity contract, an insurer attempts to control its exposure to early terminations by transferring some of the risk associated with a surrender back to the contract owner.

 

Exploiting Risk

A final way that insurers can manage risk is to exploit it—in other words, take advantage of an opportunity presented by a risk. For example, an insurer may possess a competitive advantage that allows it to develop a new product that satisfies a customer need. Exploiting risk, like accepting risk, does not mitigate the potential losses from a risk; rather, it increases the possibility of gain from the risk. In exploiting a risk, an insurer must be confident the potential losses are an acceptable hazard in light of the potential gains. Like other basic risk management strategies, exploiting risk is not an exclusive strategy—when deciding to exploit a risk, an insurer typically chooses to control the risk in addition, just as the insurer would for other risks it has accepted.

EXAMPLE

A few years ago, insurers realized that Baby Boomers who were approaching retirement were concerned about their longevity risk. Some insurers with expertise in assessing longevity risk were able to develop new products—such as annuities with long-term care insurance riders—to help these customers. Because of their unique expertise, these insurers were able to exploit a risk known as new product risk, which we’ll discuss more in a later chapter.

The following table summarizes the five basic risk management strategies covered above.

Basic Strategy

Strategy's Effect on Insurer

Avoiding Risk

Insurer eliminates the risk exposure

Accepting Risk

Insurer assumes financial responsibility for the risk exposure

Controlling Risk

Insurer mitigates the potential losses from the risk exposure

Transferring Risk

Insurer shifts part or all of the financial responsibility to another party

Exploiting Risk

pages.title: Traditional Risk Management in Life Insurance Companies
pages.contents:
Traditional Risk Management in Life Insurance Companies

Risk management plays a crucial role in helping an organization achieve its objectives and meet performance targets. This role is vital to an insurer’s overall success. Generally, effective risk management programs in life insurance companies have an established governance structure, a risk taxonomy, and a system of internal controls. When combined, these practices contribute to a risk management approach called the three lines of defense. The three lines of defense is a comprehensive, systematic approach to enhancing communication on risk management and controls by assigning clear responsibilities and roles to each of the following components:

  • First Line of Defense: Operational Management. Operational, or “frontline,” managers are responsible for identifying and assessing risk within their unit on a day-to-day basis, ensuring controls are in place, and taking corrective actions when needed. The first line of defense owns and manages the risks under its supervision.

  • Second Line of Defense: Risk Management and Compliance. The second line of defense consists of internal monitoring and oversight functions, such as a risk committee and compliance function, which ensure risks and controls are properly managed by operational managers in the first line of defense. The second line of defense oversees risks throughout the company.

  • Third Line of Defense: Internal Audit. Internal auditors provide independent assurance to the board of directors and senior management on the effectiveness of the company’s governance, its risk management practices, and its internal controls, including the level of performance achieved for the first two lines of defense. The main difference between the third line of defense and the first two lines is its high level of independence and objectivity.

Every insurer should aim to employ some variation of the three lines of defense, regardless of its size or risk approach. 1 Watch Video 3.1 to see the three lines of defense in action.

The Three Lines of Defense

Now that you’ve seen how the three lines of defense work together, let’s take a closer look at some of the elements of an insurer’s risk management program: governance, risk taxonomy, and internal controls.

 

Governance

Governance refers to the combination of people, rules, controls, and policies put in place to provide oversight and direction for the organization’s operations and actions. A governance structure provides guidance so that the company can achieve its strategic objectives.

Two common approaches exist for the governance of a risk management function:

  • Under one approach, typically used by large insurers, an insurer employs a chief risk officer [CRO], who, along with a large staff, is responsible for all of the insurer’s risk management activities. The CRO usually reports to the company’s chief executive officer (CEO) and board of directors.

  • Under a second approach, the insurer has no CRO but instead relies entirely on a risk committee, which we describe later in this chapter.

Most insurers have a risk management function integrated throughout the organization that blends elements of these two approaches.

Regardless of the approach, each insurer’s board of directors and senior management play a key role in the company’s governance structure. The board of directors and senior management set the company’s objectives, the strategies to achieve those objectives, and the governance structure needed to manage risks. When setting objectives, insurers must understand the risks and opportunities involved in the strategies employed to achieve them. For example, how will the company manage its risks? Do the levels of risk fall within defined tolerances and limits? An effective governance structure aligns an organization’s objectives and strategies with its risk management decisions.

 

Risk Taxonomy

In Chapter 2 we discussed many types of risks that insurers commonly manage. However, one challenge of risk management is that, as regulatory and economic environments change, new types of risks emerge, and existing risks may increase in complexity. For example, some life insurers are experiencing significant, high-severity losses due to unanticipated, emerging nonfinancial risks, including (but not limited to) regulatory risk, cyber risk, and fraud risk. These risks are unlike the traditional financial risks insurers are accustomed to managing, such as credit risk and market risk. With the evolving nature of risk, each life insurance company must be able to create a comprehensive list of all of its key risk exposures, including emerging nonfinancial risks. To classify risks on that list, the insurer needs a risk taxonomy. For this course’s purposes, we define a risk taxonomy as the classification and aggregation of all risks across an organization based on each risk’s core, defining characteristics.

In establishing a risk taxonomy, an insurer identifies, defines, and then expands risks into several subcategories, creating a hierarchical structure of risks. It groups risks that have similar characteristics together, which helps the company identify relationships and interconnections between risks. An agreed-upon language for its risks enhances communication across the organization.

A risk taxonomy often includes a list of risk terms along with clear definitions, which reflect the company’s specific interpretation of each risk. Risk taxonomy is also an ongoing activity that an insurer must continually monitor and update. Once an insurer compiles a list of risks that pose a threat to the achievement of its strategic objectives, it must ensure it has a system of internal controls in place to monitor them.

 

Internal Control

Another crucial element of risk management is an effective system of internal controls. Internal control is the process a company takes to encourage adherence to the company’s policies, promote operating efficiency, and safeguard the organization’s assets. Proper internal control helps ward off potential misconduct and establishes accountability for compliance throughout the company. Internal control functions add checks and balances to the insurer’s overall governance structure, providing assurance to the board of directors while fulfilling commonly required risk oversight responsibilities. An insurance company’s internal control system consists of a risk committee, a compliance function, and internal audits.

 

Risk Committee

At the heart of most insurance companies’ internal control system is a cross-functional risk committee, which reports to the board of directors. A risk committee is a senior management group whose primary role is to provide overall guidance and control of an insurer’s risk management efforts. This group is responsible for identifying, measuring, and managing all the significant risks to which an insurer is exposed, including operational risks. The members of the risk committee typically come from the various business units and work as a team to manage the insurer’s risk exposures.

Risk committees have emerged in insurance companies in response to increasing regulatory requirements, a need for independent risk oversight, and a need for specialized professionals with risk expertise. An insurance company’s board of directors typically establishes a permanent risk committee to oversee the company’s risk management efforts. The risk committee is a key part of the second line of defense.

 

Compliance Function

The compliance function establishes policies and procedures that the company must follow to satisfy the regulatory requirements of the jurisdictions in which it operates. Other duties the compliance function is typically responsible for include

  • Assessing potential occurrences of compliance issues or risks

  • Monitoring the regulatory environment on a continual basis

  • Anticipating regulatory changes and emerging issues that could impact the organization

  • Interpreting new laws and regulatory requirements

  • Making necessary changes to company policies and procedures

Although insurance companies must follow regulatory requirements, which represent external standards, they also monitor employees’ compliance with internal standards and encourage ethical behavior. We define ethical behavior as behavior that meets accepted standards of moral conduct. An insurance company can encourage ethical behavior by requiring training in ethics for its employees, establishing an ethics office or hotline, and incorporating ethical guidelines into the company’s mission statement. For an ethics program to succeed, top management must be involved, and the company must incorporate principles of ethics into everyday business decisions.

The compliance function is generally considered part of the second line of defense. A key role of the third line of defense is monitoring the compliance function to ensure effectiveness.

 

Internal Audits

Another important component of internal control is the internal audit. An internal audit is an examination of the company’s records, policies, and procedures conducted by a person who works for the organization, typically in the compliance area. Internal auditors work independently of all other departments and report directly to the audit committee of the insurer’s board of directors and to other top executives, such as the CEO. When an insurer establishes a professional internal audit, it ensures its governance and risk management processes will be addressed and examined. Internal audits are a key part of the third line of defense.

pages.title: Enterprise Risk Management
pages.contents:
Enterprise Risk Management

The topics discussed so far in this chapter are common components of risk management programs for life insurance companies. As we described in Chapter 1, enterprise risk management (ERM) is a system that identifies and quantifies risks from both potential threats and potential opportunities and manages these risks in a coordinated approach that supports the organization’s strategic objectives. ERM takes a top-down, enterprise-wide approach to viewing all of the significant risks that could affect an insurer’s strategic objectives. According to ERM, risk is any negative consequence a company faces as it conducts its operations, including the failure to meet objectives or to exploit profitable opportunities.

ERM and traditional risk management share many specific practices in common, such as employing a CRO, maintaining a risk committee, and establishing a risk taxonomy. The key differences between the two systems are the number of risks encompassed and ERM’s inclusion of risk as an opportunity for gain. Although an insurer’s actuaries and investment specialists are responsible for managing a company’s ERM activities, all employees should recognize how ERM programs differ from other traditional risk management techniques. The following table summarizes the differences between traditional risk management and ERM.

Traditional Risk Management

Enterprise Risk Management

Defines risk as the potential for loss and primarily focuses on preventing or minimizing such losses

Expands the definition of risk to include not only the potential for loss but the potential for failing to take advantage of an opportunity

Works to prevent or minimize losses

Works to improve the overall risk-return profile of an organization

Emphasizes only certain risks that an organization faces

Encompasses all significant risks that an organization faces

Adopts a “silo” approach to managing risks in which separate departments or areas do not necessarily communicate with one another

Adopts a holistic approach to managing risks in which risks are integrated across the organization into a corporate portfolio of risks

Assumes that the responsibility for risk management is confined to specific employees

Proposes that risk management is everyone’s responsibility

Recent regulations have been strong drivers in pushing financial institutions and insurers to adopt ERM. Two examples of such regulations are the NAIC’s Risk Management and Own Risk and Solvency Assessment (ORSA) Model Act and the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act of 2010 (the Dodd-Frank Act).

Most insurers practice ERM to some extent, although some insurers implement ERM practices and techniques to a greater degree than do others. An effective ERM program typically includes the following components: (1) a risk management culture, (2) strategic risk management, (3) a risk control process, (4) a risk management framework, and (5) catastrophic event management.

 

Risk Management Culture

Although ERM begins at the top level of an organization, it must reach all areas of the organization to be successful. Whether a company uses a CRO, a risk committee, or some combination of the two, the company must establish a risk management culture.

Individuals at all levels of the company are responsible for risk management—not just the risk management department or senior management. Every employee is a stakeholder and part owner of a risk. Although the company’s board of directors and senior management have the primary authority for establishing the risk management culture—what is generally known as “setting the tone at the top”—employees should communicate frequently and every employee should be aware of his role in the company’s risk management efforts. When compared with the three lines of defense strategy, a risk management culture based on ERM would consider all employees part of the first line of defense.

Recall from Chapter 1 that, when implementing a risk management culture, management must first communicate the company’s risk appetite and risk tolerance. Employees in various functional areas can contribute to the company’s goals by understanding how the company views and manages risks, as well as how each function helps achieve the company’s objectives.

Knowledgeable employees have the expertise to spot seemingly small irregularities or unusual occurrences that may be an indicator of underlying issues. For example, employees can

  • Analyze work processes and suggest improvements to increase productivity and reduce duplicated or wasted efforts

  • Detect irregularities in records related to transactions with customers or vendors and report incidents that suggest fraud or unnecessary expenditures

  • Apply a team-oriented, cooperative approach to improve work processes and procedures

Regardless of specific job duties, a company’s employees can work together across functional lines to manage risk, with the guidance of the established governance structure, risk taxonomy, and clearly defined roles within the three lines of defense.

 

Strategic Risk Management

The global financial crisis of 2007-2008 illustrated the weaknesses inherent to a largely reactive risk management approach. A company with an effective ERM system proactively aligns its strategic goals with risks, seeking to optimize its risk-adjusted returns. Characteristics of strategic risk management include

  • Incorporating risk into all decision making

  • Taking a long-term view of the company’s risk profile

  • Adopting a risk-adjusted financial measurement system, particularly in the area of incentive compensation

  • Exploiting risks that have the potential to create competitive advantages

Strategic risk management requires a broad perspective that considers more than the most immediate potential risks. For example, a company that follows regulations and economic patterns in other countries is better positioned to anticipate and exploit risks that may arise due to the interconnected nature of the global economy.

 

Risk Control Process

The risk control process is especially important to ERM because it includes the steps necessary to limit a company’s risk exposures. A risk control process gathers information and then evaluates, monitors, and limits risk. Although the exact process varies by company, the typical steps in the process include:

  • Identifying risks. Develop a comprehensive list of risk exposures throughout the organization that could affect its ability to meet objectives, including key risks and emerging risks.

  • Evaluating risks. Determine the cause, likelihood, and potential severity of each of the identified risks and prioritize according to significance.

  • Treating risks. Decide which risks qualify for treatment and implement an action plan for each top-priority risk. Action plans can include avoiding, controlling, accepting, transferring, or exploiting risks that exceed defined limits.

  • Monitoring and reviewing risks. Determine the effectiveness of the risk management process and the strategies implemented through internal controls, such as assessments and internal audits.

 

Risk Management Frameworks

Various authorities have developed risk management frameworks to be used as guides for implementing risk management. For our purposes, a risk management framework is a set of components and principles that supports risk management throughout an organization.

Although developed by recognized authorities, risk management frameworks are voluntary, unless mandated by a governmental agency. When a governmental agency mandates a framework, it becomes a regulation. Companies that voluntarily comply with a framework adhere to best practices and are better prepared to respond to more stringent risk management requirements in the future. Three of the most well-known risk management frameworks are the ORSA ERM framework, the COSO ERM framework, and the ISO 31000 standard.

 

ORSA ERM Framework

Recall that each U.S. insurer is required to maintain and continually assess its risk management framework and solvency position in an ORSA Annual Summary Report, which must be signed by the CRO or an equivalent person. Some companies have one or more actuaries dedicated to ORSA; in other companies actuaries work on ORSA in addition to their usual responsibilities.

According to Section 1 of the NAIC ORSA Guidance Manual, an effective risk management framework should incorporate, at a minimum, the following five key principles:

  • Risk culture and governance

  • Risk identification and prioritization

  • Risk appetite, tolerances, and limits

  • Risk management and controls

  • Risk reporting and communication 2

 

COSO ERM Framework

The premise of the COSO ERM framework is that internal controls should help organizations achieve their objectives in the areas of operations, reporting, and compliance. Recently updated in 2017, the COSO ERM framework is now organized into five interrelated components:

  • Governance and culture

  • Strategy and objective setting

  • Performance

  • Review and revision

  • Information, communication, and reporting

These five components are supported by a set of twenty principles, which describe in further detail the practices that can be used to enhance performance and meet strategic objectives. 3

 

ISO 31000 Standard

ISO 31000 was published in 2009 as an international standard for the implementation of risk management principles. Recently updated in 2018, it lists eight principles of risk management believed to be crucial for a company to successfully manage its risk exposures. The risk management framework should be

  • Customized to the organization’s strategic objectives

  • Structured and comprehensive

  • Responsive to changes

  • Based on the best available information

  • Considerate of human and cultural factors

  • Integrated across the entire organization’s activities

  • Continuously improving

  • Inclusive of stakeholders’ involvement

Most of the widely recognized frameworks, including the ISO 31000 standard and the COSO ERM framework, contain similar approaches to managing risk, although there are some key differences. For example, ORSA requires each insurer to evaluate its risk management framework on an annual basis, whereas neither the COSO ERM framework nor the ISO 31000 standard contains such a requirement (each is voluntary). Each insurer selects a risk management framework that best fits its strategic objectives and individual risk exposures. 4

 

Catastrophic Event Management

Whereas risk control focuses on everyday risk-taking, catastrophic event management addresses extreme risks that materialize only rarely—but can result in solvency issues for companies. Examples of catastrophic events include acts of terrorism, such as the events of September 11, 2001; economic downturns, such as the financial crisis of 2008; natural disasters, such as the Japanese tsunami of 2011; and pandemics, such as the COVID-19 outbreak of 2020.

One of the greatest challenges with catastrophic event management is that low-frequency, high-severity events are often unpredictable and more difficult to understand, leaving companies unable to prepare for them. Instead, the company must attempt to envision various extreme scenarios and the response it would take to each. Financial models can stress test the extreme scenarios and determine the potential impact an event could have on the company.

Insurers develop contingency plans with detailed actions the company would take should one of the catastrophic events occur, thereby reducing its overall impact on the company. For example, employee feedback may help a company prioritize which systems would be most critical to restore first should a natural disaster shut down or destroy the company’s computers. Typically, insurers seek reinsurance to reduce the impact of extreme events.

Other contingency plans insurers may use to prepare for catastrophic events are

  • Having remote work capabilities, such as allowing employees to log in to the company network to work from home

  • Preparing for communication of possible events, such as using text messages, emails, or phone calls to announce an imminent event

  • Maintaining an office status or disaster hotline that can be accessed 24 hours a day and 7 days a week

  • Having offices in different locations and providing each employee with an alternate location to work

  • Having computer system data backed up and stored at an offsite facility

  • Conducting simulated events and exercises designed to model catastrophic events as practice
