pages.title: Asset-Liability Management
pages.contents:
Asset-Liability Management

In addition to the basic strategies for managing risk, life insurers practice asset-liability management (ALM) to address specific financial risks. Recall that ALM consists of a portfolio approach to managing the risks associated with a company’s assets and liabilities. A portfolio is a collection of assets with differing degrees and kinds of risk, usually assembled for meeting a defined set of goals. The process in which portfolios are evaluated for their risk-return potential is known as portfolio management.

Insurers group their risk exposures into two types of portfolios:

  • An asset portfolio, which holds the insurer’s securities and other invested assets.

  • A liability portfolio, or, within the context of ALM, product portfolio, which represents the insurer’s obligations to customers.

ALM addresses financial risks including, but not limited to, interest-rate risk, currency risk, equity risk, and policyholder behavior risk. The ALM process is designed to help insurers (1) manage risks at an acceptable level and (2) take advantage of opportunities to earn a return.

 

Risks and Returns

Recall that insurers need to balance risks incurred with potential returns. For some purposes, risks can be divided into two categories:

  • Diversifiable risk—also known as nonsystematic risk or specific risk—is risk that is specific to an individual asset or issuer. Credit risk is an example of diversifiable risk. Most financial risks are diversifiable risks.

  • Nondiversifiable risk—also known as systematic risk—is risk that affects all assets in an economic system and is therefore not specific to an individual asset or issuer. The risk of an economic recession is an example of nondiversifiable risk.

An insurance company’s asset and liability portfolios generate cash flows. In general, over the long run, asset portfolios generate net cash inflows, whereas liability portfolios generate net cash outflows.

When assets are assembled in a portfolio, their combined risks can have desirable or undesirable interactions:

  • A risk augmentation effect is present if the combination of specific risks is greater than the sum of those risks.

  • A risk offset effect is present if the combination of specific risks is less than the sum of those risks.

Portfolio risk management approaches support the safety in a portfolio of risks by avoiding a condition of high positive correlation among the portfolio’s risks. Correlation among the returns of portfolio assets means that the returns tend to move together. When returns move in the same direction, correlation is positive; when returns move in opposite directions, correlation is negative. High positive correlation occurs when the amount and direction of the movement in returns are nearly the same for all assets in the portfolio.

ALM involves four primary portfolio risk management approaches:

  • Diversification is a risk management strategy for spreading risk by investing in different assets having different risk profiles. To diversify their investments, insurers carefully spread their investment selections among the securities of different issuers in different business categories. Diversification is effective in controlling diversifiable risk, especially asset concentration risk. Asset concentration risk is the risk of an excessive concentration of assets in any single category, such as a portfolio that consists only of corporate bonds.

  • Hedging is a risk management strategy that involves holding an asset with characteristics that counterbalance one or more of the risks in the investor’s risk array. Insurers often hedge, or counterbalance, risks in some assets by holding other assets with offsetting risk characteristics.

  • Cash-flow matching is a risk management strategy that involves identifying the patterns of cash outflows for insurance products and matching those cash outflows with a selection of assets that will produce a similar pattern of cash inflows. In other words, portfolio assets are selected for their ability to generate cash inflows that offset the estimated cash outflows related to an insurer’s liabilities. In general, cash-flow matching works well for life insurance companies because their liabilities are fairly predictable and occur over relatively long time periods. Life insurers typically buy fixed-income investments to ensure predictable cash inflows.

  • Duration matching is a risk management strategy that involves matching the duration statistics for fixed-income assets such as bonds with the duration statistics for the insurance company liabilities that the assets support. In an actuarial context, we define duration as a statistic that measures the price sensitivity of an asset or liability to changes in interest rates. Duration is the time-weighted value of expected cash inflows, expressed in years. However, the actual duration statistics used by insurers vary widely from one company to another.

EXAMPLE

Example 1: Leed Insurance’s portfolio of bonds has duration of 15, which means that for a 0.1 percent increase in interest rates, the value of the bond portfolio declines by 1.5 percent. If there is a 0.1 percent decrease in interest rates, the value of the bond portfolio increases by 1.5 percent.

Example 2. Leed Insurance uses duration matching for liabilities that have highly predictable cash flows and whose value is very sensitive to interest rates. Leed structures its fixed-income asset portfolio so that the values of the asset and liability portfolios move in sync in response to interest-rate changes. In other words, the duration-matched portfolios have the same sensitivity to interest-rate changes.

These portfolio risk management strategies are not exclusive to one another; for instance, an insurer uses duration matching in addition to other strategies to achieve proper ALM. The success of these strategies depends on the insurer’s ability to balance assets and liabilities so that

  • Total assets match or exceed total liabilities

  • Total cash inflows over any time period exceed, match, or are reasonably close to total cash outflows over the same period

  • The interactions between the asset and liability portfolios are likely to reduce or eliminate some risks through risk offsets or hedges

  • The interactions between the asset and liability portfolios produce residual risks—the lesser risks that remain after balancing—that insurers can actively manage

To properly execute these strategies, insurers use specialized modeling techniques such as cash-flow testing and asset adequacy analysis. We discuss these and other modeling techniques in the next chapter. Figure 3.1 illustrates the four portfolio risk management approaches described above.

 

ALM Reporting Systems

ALM processes establish lines of communication that cross the formal boundaries of the traditional organizational hierarchy. In day-to-day operations, investment professionals typically handle the risks inherent in the assets portfolio, and product professionals typically handle the risks inherent in the liabilities portfolio.

However, for effective ALM, a company must coordinate its financial expertise in the areas of

  • Investment policy and operations

  • Product design and pricing

  • Insurance risk management, including underwriting, diversification, claims management, fraud, and reinsurance programs

  • Operating expenses, including information systems costs, legal costs, and employee compensation costs

Because ALM processes require that technical information be communicated to a variety of financial professionals and top-level decision makers, most financial institutions maintain a formal reporting system for ALM information. This system communicates the results of technical ALM analysis to an internal ALM steering committee and to regulators. The system also provides documentation and communication support to help technical experts and nonexperts work together to implement ALM strategies. ALM reporting systems produce internal ALM reports and external ALM reports.

 

Internal ALM Reports

Insurance companies use a variety of internal reports for ALM. Some reports provide details concerning the company’s liabilities, while other reports provide details about investments in the asset portfolio. Internal ALM reports support sound ALM within a company. Because of the company-specific nature of these reports, they vary from one company to another. Some of the most common internal ALM reports are the investment activity report, investment portfolio performance review, and duration gap report.

An investment activity report specifies the details of all investment portfolio transactions, including all asset acquisitions and all dispositions of assets from the investment portfolio through sales, prepayments (redemptions), or repayment at maturity. Although narrow in scope, this report is typically the most detailed and the most frequently produced of any report in a formal ALM reporting system.

EXAMPLE

For each newly acquired debt security, the investment activity report typically gives the asset’s face amount, coupon rate, yield, term to maturity, duration, and quality rating.

An investment portfolio performance review is a quarterly ALM report that summarizes the company’s investment performance for the board of directors and the ALM committee. This report is usually the broadest in scope of any ALM report, but is not the most detailed, because it covers much of the information in summary form.

The investment portfolio performance review presents quarterly and year-to-date information about the following aspects of investment performance:

  • Overall growth in the portfolio’s monetary value, specified in terms of price appreciation and income growth; an analysis of capital gains and losses; and an analysis of changes in market values

  • Acquisitions and dispositions by asset type, and an analysis of the effect on yields of all purchases and sales

  • A narrative discussion of the portfolio composition, known as the asset mix, and the suitability of the asset mix

  • Narrative explanations of key events in the external environment and the company’s strategic responses to those events

  • Summary reports on special topics such as problem assets, real estate investments, and international investments

A duration gap report provides a snapshot of the insurer’s asset-liability match at the time of the report. This report describes the results of a duration analysis of the company’s asset and liability portfolios and discusses the insurer’s current exposure to portfolio cash flow mismatches caused by changes in market interest rates. Information in a duration gap report is time-sensitive because even small changes in market interest rates and other economic factors can produce dramatic changes in the asset-liability gap.

 

External ALM Reports

Insurers commonly use two formal ALM reports for external reporting: (1) an Actuarial Opinion and Memorandum (AOM), with supporting documentation, and (2) a crediting-rate resolution. Recall that an AOM consists of two separate documents—the actuarial opinion and the actuarial memorandum—that insurers are required to submit annually to regulators.

A crediting-rate resolution is a formal declaration by the board of directors of the rate of interest the insurer will credit on customers’ money held in interest-bearing products.

Crediting rates vary widely by product and by company. An annual crediting-rate resolution typically presents details about the company’s interest-crediting strategies. Interest-crediting strategies are the formulas and criteria a company uses to set the interest rates it will credit for interest-sensitive products.

EXAMPLE

An interest-crediting strategy for a given fixed deferred annuity product would be a rule to generally credit that product with interest at a rate equal to the asset portfolio earnings rate minus 1.5 percent.

pages.title: Measuring and Managing Expense Risk
pages.contents:
Measuring and Managing Expense Risk

In addition to ERM and ALM, insurers take specific steps to manage risks associated with their expenses. Three approaches that insurers use to manage their expenses are

  • Making major expense reductions, which involve eliminating or drastically reducing expenses in certain areas. Eliminating staff positions, selling certain lines of business, or closing selected field offices are examples of major expense reductions. Although major expense reductions can be effective, insurers often use them selectively rather than across the board. Some expenses, such as promotions for newly introduced products, may need to increase rather than decrease, at least over the short term. For example, an insurer may need to increase its IT budget in order to implement a new automated system that will reduce expenses in the long run.

  • Making minor expense reductions, which involve finding more efficient ways to perform certain functions. For example, an insurer can often reduce contract maintenance costs by processing routine transactions on the company’s website rather than routing them to customer service representatives. Outsourcing and benchmarking, which we discuss later in this section, are practices commonly used to reduce operating expenses.

  • Reallocating corporate expenses, which involve separating expenses that are related to the total company from expenses related to particular products or lines of business. By allocating to a product line only those expenses that are directly related to the product line, an insurer can more easily identify where resources should be directed.

 

Eliminating Expenses

One way to eliminate expenses is through rightsizing. Rightsizing, also known as downsizing, is the elimination of nonessential jobs within an organization. To be successful, rightsizing must be accompanied by careful redesign of work processes to determine the number and types of employee positions that are essential for effective business operations. Some rightsizing can be achieved through attrition, which occurs when a company purposefully elects to not replace employees who leave their jobs because of retirement, resignation, death, or disability. Additional methods that companies can use to eliminate employee positions include early retirement programs, closing regional offices, and layoffs.

 

Reducing Expenses

Companies must pay for information systems, accounting services, salaries for home office employees, and various other expenses. Insurers can attempt to reduce these and other administrative expenses by outsourcing certain functions and using benchmarking.

 

Outsourcing Certain Functions

Outsourcing is the practice of hiring an external vendor to perform specified operations or functions. An outsourcing arrangement may cover all or only part of the functions for an area. For example, an insurance company might outsource its entire claim administration operation, or it might outsource only claim investigation and perform all other claim administration processes in-house. Functions that life insurance companies commonly outsource include

  • Information management functions

  • Investment management functions

  • Life insurance claim administration functions, such as claim investigation and claim processing

  • Customer service functions, such as call center operations and premium billing and collection

  • Human resources functions, such as payroll and benefits processing

Often, vendors can perform certain jobs at a lower cost to the insurer than can the insurer’s employees. Before deciding whether to outsource a particular function, an insurer evaluates the expected benefits and drawbacks associated with outsourcing that function. The insurer generally considers the following factors:

  • The insurer’s own ability to perform the function efficiently and effectively. External vendors tend to specialize in certain business functions, and their expertise often allows them to perform these functions faster, better, and less expensively than can the insurer. For example, an information management vendor might offer faster turnaround on data processing than the insurer can achieve with its own resources. Further, the vendor may have a workforce in a location where salaries are less costly than in the insurer’s location.

  • The importance of immediate implementation. An insurer that does not have an infrastructure established for a particular function may need to delay starting the function until it can hire and train personnel and establish information systems and procedures. If timing is critical, outsourcing the function to an external vendor that already has the necessary human resources, technology, and procedures in place can minimize delays and reduce costs.

  • The availability of start-up capital. The start-up costs associated with new operations are often substantial. For example, the high upfront costs of purchasing necessary technology and hiring and training personnel for a new call center can create a strain on capital. An insurer can relieve this strain by outsourcing capital-intensive functions to external vendors.

  • The importance of control over the operation. When an insurer outsources a function, it relinquishes some control over the day-to-day performance of that function. Before outsourcing it, the insurer should weigh this loss of control and potential privacy risk against the savings in time and money offered by outsourcing. If maintaining control over a function is a priority, outsourcing may not be an effective alternative even if it reduces costs.

 

Benchmarking

One of the most popular ways to manage operating expenses and improve operating efficiency is to benchmark company operations. Benchmarking consists of (1) identifying the best outcomes that other companies have achieved for a specific activity or process and the practices that produced those outcomes and (2) implementing the best practices to equal or surpass the best outcomes. In effect, benchmarking allows companies to improve operations without reinventing the wheel.

Insurers frequently use benchmarking to improve the efficiency of their

  • Employee training and development programs

  • Document management processes

  • Accounting processes

  • Compensation and incentive programs

  • Distribution systems

The following insight illustrates how an insurer can use benchmarking to manage distribution costs.

pages.title: Measuring and Managing Operational Risk
pages.contents:
Measuring and Managing Operational Risk

Many companies consider operational risk to be the most dangerous type of risk that they face. Recall that operational risk is the risk of financial losses resulting from inadequate or failed internal processes, controls, systems, and people. The challenge of measuring and managing operational risk can be overwhelming. Ideally, companies take a comprehensive approach to operational risk measurement and management that includes a variety of tools. These tools range from key risk indicators, risk maps, loss-incident databases, and control self-assessments to the methods of scenario testing and simulation modeling, which we discuss in the next chapter.

 

Key Risk Indicators

A key risk indicator (KRI) is a quantitative metric that indicates the level of operational risk exposures at a given point of time in order to help companies forecast future occurrences. KRIs can play an important role in managing risk by identifying potential high risk exposures and enabling the company to take timely action.

KRIs can be considered leading—identifying risk trends and issues that may need to be addressed in the future—or lagging—identifying events that have occurred in the past and that may occur again. Effective KRIs should be relevant, measurable, predictive, auditable, easy to monitor, comparable, and timely.

KRIs help to support effective governance, risk taxonomies, and internal controls by providing a consistent and repeatable way for tracking both risk exposures and management activity. By monitoring KRIs and checking them against agreed limits and thresholds, a company is able to see if its operational risk exposures are within its stated risk tolerance. Limits and thresholds may be set to help show whether an indicator is red, amber, or green. The amber zone is given more priority than green, and red is given even greater priority. Video 3.2 shows the typical significance of the KRI zones and the managerial responses for KRI values in each zone. 5

Risk Maps

A risk map, also called a risk heat map, categorizes each risk identified for a particular operational or business process along two dimensions—(1) impact or significance and (2) likelihood. Risk maps typically classify individual risks as minor (green), moderate (yellow), major (orange), or severe (red), based on the impact or significance of the risk and the likelihood that the risk will occur. Severe or high risks usually require immediate attention to address the risk at its source. Major and moderate risks usually require regular monitoring, but may not demand immediate attention. Minor or low risks may require monitoring, but usually don’t require significant control. Figure 3.2 shows an example of a risk map presented in table form.

 

Loss-Incident Databases

As its name indicates, a loss-incident database is simply a database that records every loss that an insurer has experienced. It allows insurers to review operational activities from a single system and then identify incidents or activities that create or have the potential to create losses, analyze the company’s performance during those incidents, create summaries, and make recommendations for improvements.

 

Control Self-Assessments

A control self-assessment is a detailed report, typically compiled by each line manager, capturing each operational area’s key risks, controls, and management implications. The assessment can help identify potential areas of vulnerability based on the ratings received. For example, an insurance company might use a control self-assessment to (1) collect data—from underwriting, claims, and sales divisions—related to risks, inefficient or failed control processes, and performance gaps, and (2) propose actions to improve performance.

To implement an effective risk management strategy or to develop a profitable product, an insurer needs an accurate estimation of its future financial situation. While it’s impossible to know exactly what the future holds, the process of financial modeling allows an insurer to make estimates that can serve as the foundation for its business strategies. pages.title: Introduction to Financial Modeling
pages.contents:
Introduction to Financial Modeling

Financial models forecast a company’s or product’s future financial performance using historical data and assumptions about the future. Insurance companies commonly use financial models that interact with company accounting and financial reporting systems to generate financial reports and produce estimates of future financial conditions. These estimates are an important part of insurance company efforts in ERM, ALM, portfolio management, and technical product design. Practical uses of financial models include

  • Estimating future cash inflows, future cash outflows, net cash flows, and the timing around such activities

  • Estimating future values for assets, reserves, capital, and expenses

  • Determining the value of an insurance company, a new product, or product line

  • Evaluating how future economic and regulatory environments might affect financial health

  • Analyzing risks that threaten an insurer’s solvency

Poor assumptions and ineffective models can lead to problems in risk management and product development—in particular, the technical product design phase, where most financial modeling occurs. An insurer’s long-term financial success relies on the ability to estimate the future behavior of key risk factors, such as mortality or investment performance, over the lifetime of insurance and annuity products.

While actuaries do the majority of financial modeling work, other employees at an insurance company are also vital to the process. For example, any historical data used in a model must be accurate and precise. So, employees in other departments, such as underwriting, claims, accounting, and marketing, all play a critical role by providing accurate data, and therefore building a foundation for the company’s financial projections.

 

Components of Financial Models

Financial models consist of four primary components: inputs, approaches, outputs, and analysis.

 

Model Inputs

The inputs in financial models take the form of variables, which are items of data whose numerical value varies. The input variables used in models are independent variables that represent the measurement of real-world financial values. An independent variable is a variable that influences the behavior of another variable—called the dependent variable—and determines the outcome of a financial model. By definition, independent variables are not influenced by other variables. By convention, independent variables are labeled x. Multiple independent variables are labeled x 1, x 2, and so on.

Insurers typically derive model inputs for financial models from four sources: actuarial assumptions, internal and industry experience data, regulatory requirements, and estimates of possible future conditions. Recall from Chapter 1 that insurers use assumptions in risk management or technical product design to represent the estimated value of components, such as investment earnings, the cost of benefits, company expenses, and unexpected financial results. The accuracy of the assumptions and inputs used in financial models directly affect the success or failure of new and existing products. Even a small change in an assumption’s value can result in significant changes in the model’s results.

Flambeau Life Insurance is modeling the effect of investment earnings on the interest-crediting rate for a proposed fixed-rate deferred annuity product. The assumption in this model is the investment earnings. One example of an input for this model would be investment earnings of 4%.

 

Modeling Approaches

The goal of financial modeling is to test a scenario by extrapolating multiple outcomes as variables change, determining the most probable outcomes so that the insurer can plan for them accordingly. Realistically, there are far too many variables that can potentially influence a scenario over a number of years for any one financial model to incorporate. An insurer must therefore choose the right model for the task at hand.

Modeling approaches include deterministic modeling, stochastic modeling, and optimization modeling. We discuss these approaches in a later section.

 

Model Outputs

The outputs of financial models represent the projected future values produced by processing inputs—the independent variables—through the model. In financial modeling, a dependent variable is a variable that reacts to changes in other variables. By convention, dependent variables are labeled y, and multiple dependent variables are labeled y 1, y 2, and so on. The rule, or function, that describes how a dependent variable relates to—or depends on—an independent variable is usually written as y = f(x).

Insurers use the outputs of financial models to perform financial analysis and to help them make decisions about deploying capital, budgeting and forecasting, growing the business, and prioritizing product ideas.

Flambeau Life Insurance is modeling the effect of investment earnings on the interest-crediting rate for its proposed fixed-rate deferred annuity product. The interest-crediting rate depends on the investment earnings, so the interest-crediting rate is the dependent variable, while the investment earnings act as the independent variable.

 

Model Analysis

Model analysis involves examining all the outputs of a financial model to see whether patterns or correlations exist. Model analysis can determine the direction of the change in output variables created by changes in input variables—as well as the amount and timing of those changes—and whether the outcomes represent favorable or unfavorable conditions.

Testing multiple scenarios is a key component in model analysis. In product design, testing involves using one or more sets of assumed values in the model to ensure that the product can produce sound financial results for the customer and the insurer. Throughout product testing, the company must ensure that the assumed values are realistic, actuarially sound, and validated by testing.

pages.title: Model Inputs
pages.contents:
Model Inputs

 

 

As previously stated, insurers typically derive model inputs for financial models from four sources: actuarial assumptions, experience data, regulatory requirements and estimates of possible future conditions. Each of these sources provides independent variables to be used as inputs. In some cases, the values of these independent variables are derived from real-world observations—for example, a company’s experience with lapse rates on previous products. In other cases, the values of independent variables are selected randomly from a data distribution.

 

Actuarial Assumptions

Companies use assumptions that represent unknown future values within the context of product pricing, product reserving, and other modeling applications for life insurance and annuity products. Assumptions may be classified as fixed, dynamic, or stochastic.

  • Fixed assumptions, also known as constants, are variables for which actuaries assign a specific value or proportional relationship, and the value or proportion remains unchanged throughout multiple iterations of a model. Typically, such assumptions are fixed by policy or contract terms, or are dictated by regulation.

An actuary calculates a life annuity factor using assumptions mandated by regulators. Because these particular assumptions are fixed, the calculations don’t allow for any discretion by the actuary.

  • Dynamic assumptions are variables that change over time, but in a way that is predictable and formula driven. Actuaries use dynamic assumptions to model policyholder behavior with respect to lapse and surrender rates, flexible premium payments, and utilization of optional benefits. Both interest-rate movements and policyholder behavior can have significant effects on an insurance company; we will discuss these effects in detail in Chapters 7 and 9.

A fixed-rate deferred annuity product has a current interest-crediting rate of 4%. Contract owners who are beyond the eight-year surrender period for this product can withdraw their money at any time without incurring a financial penalty. If such a contract owner can earn more than 4% in another investment, then he is more likely to exchange his annuity for another insurer’s fixed-rate deferred annuity. On the other hand, if other investments are earning less than 4%, the contract owner is more likely to keep their funds with the insurer. Based on these different scenarios, the insurer can use a dynamic formula that models a higher withdrawal rate when market interest rates are high and a lower withdrawal rate when market interest rates are low.

  • Stochastic assumptions are variables that are selected randomly from a specified statistical distribution applied across multiple simulations or scenarios. Stochastic assumptions are used when assumptions are unknown and cannot be easily modeled using a dynamic formula. Some assumptions are unknown because a product is new or contains new features with which an insurer has no experience. Other times, assumptions are unknown because they are based on factors that are completely outside the control of the insurer, such as assumptions about market interest rates and equity market returns. Insurers can use stochastic assumptions to model unknown future quantities, as well as to measure the sensitivity of an assumption to the model’s result. The insight below discusses two tools used to generate random selections.

INSIGHT

Random Generators

If an insurer wants to randomly select an independent variable, it can use a random number generator or a random scenario generator.

  • A random number generator is a software application that automatically identifies a pattern of values that we would expect to get by sampling from a given probability distribution. Insurers limit the number of independent variable values by setting parameters for the distribution and selecting a random sample of values that meet the defined parameters. A random sample is a statistical sample in which each possible value is equally likely to be selected.

EXAMPLE

Chevalier Life Insurance wants to model lapse rates over a ten-year period for a life insurance product, and chooses a random number generator to determine the lapse rate for the scenario. Although values in the data set might range from 0% to 100%, many of these values can be eliminated because they are not realistic. So, Chevalier limits the number of independent variables by setting parameters of 5% to 20% for the distribution. The random number generator produces a random sample of values that fall within these defined parameters.

  • A random scenario generator is a software application that uses defined parameters, such as value ranges and time periods, to create sets of scenarios that meet the defined parameters. In the context of financial modeling, a scenario is a set of values that describes actuarial and economic conditions. These scenarios represent possible examples of values that could occur. The scenario generator then selects a random sample of scenarios to use as input variables.

EXAMPLE

Chevalier Life Insurance is planning a new life insurance product that falls under specific regulatory requirements due to the features it offers. One of the regulatory requirements is that Chevalier must test the new product using a prescribed economic scenario generator to ensure that the product performs adequately under certain scenarios.

Within any model, a company may use combinations of fixed, dynamic, and stochastic assumptions. Also, actuaries must decide which assumptions will be represented by variables and which assumptions will be fixed by the model’s software.

 

Experience Data

Insurance company records and systems, such as accounting, ALM, and ERM, maintain a large amount of experience data about the past behavior of factors such as mortality rates and expenses. Insurers also have access to external experience data published in experience studies. An experience study is a compilation of data representing company or industry-wide historical experience with a specified modeling variable.

Actuaries use data from experience studies to help them determine the appropriate input to use in the model and to test the model’s assumptions against past experience. Insurance industry and company experience studies address observed trends in mortality rates, lapse rates, product expenses, product persistency, and policyholder behavior. Many experience studies focus on specific subsets of customers, such as studying mortality rates among groups selected by age, sex, or smoking status.

Experience data can provide insurers with valuable information about how financial variables behaved in the past and how they can be expected to behave in the future, if conditions remain stable. One limitation of experience data is that such data cannot accurately predict how variables will behave if future conditions do not follow historical trends.

 

Estimates of Future Conditions

Because life insurance and annuity products are designed to be long-term products, a major part of their financial success depends on how accurately insurers can estimate the behavior of key risk factors over the lifetime of the products. For decision makers, these estimated values can help identify possible courses of action and alert companies to potential opportunities or threats.

The outcomes generated by analyzing estimated future values are possible outcomes, which represent the range of outcomes that can happen. Possible outcomes include probable outcomes and preferred, or desired, outcomes:

  • Probable outcomes represent what is likely to happen and are based on constant trends, such as the estimates produced by modeling experience data.

  • Preferred, or desired, outcomes represent outcomes that a company would like to happen and are based on planned strategies and actions.

  • Improbable outcomes represent what is unlikely to happen. Improbable outcomes can be desirable, such as a product succeeding well beyond expectations, or highly undesirable, such as circumstances that cause much larger losses than the company was prepared to endure.

Unlike the outcomes derived from experience data, outcomes derived from estimated future values may fall outside the range of real-world observation. Insurers can use trend analysis and futures studies to estimate future conditions.

 

Trend Analysis

For some tasks, insurers can use trend analysis to forecast future values for design elements that follow known patterns, such as the cost of benefits and operating expenses. Trend analysis is a form of technical analysis that projects the future movement of specified variables based on historical patterns. Trend analysis can identify patterns in experience data that could, if they persist, have a significant impact on the company. Mortality trends are a particularly important area of analysis for the insurance industry.

Although trend analysis can be a valuable tool for forecasting the behaviors of variables that follow regular patterns, it generally doesn’t provide accurate estimates for variables whose behavior is volatile or that can’t be described in terms of observed values. In these cases, insurers typically use modeling to produce estimates of future conditions.

 

Futures Studies

Insurers use futures studies to gain insight into the type of future conditions that are most likely to affect life insurance and annuity risk factors. Futures studies identify possible developments that could disrupt trends and then produce an array of possibilities for future values based on these developments.

Insurers use futures studies in ERM to identify potential future, low-probability, high-impact events, known as wild cards, which may constitute turning points in the evolution of a trend or system.

Futures studies employ a variety of quantitative and qualitative methods to produce images of the future.

  • Quantitative methods generally use data about past events and values to forecast future events and values.

  • Qualitative methods typically rely on expert opinion, judgment, and other subjective factors to forecast the future. Qualitative methods are best used when there is little available historical data or when there is reason to believe that the past is not a reliable predictor of the future.

Compared to traditional experience studies, futures studies require users to view information from a broader perspective, conduct more detailed analyses of results, and project outcomes along a longer time horizon. Futures studies also require a shift from scientific thinking to speculative, or even visionary, thinking.

 

Quality of Inputs

A model’s outputs are only as good as the inputs and assumptions that go into it. Insurers must be careful to use high-quality data to receive accurate results, rather than selecting data that implies the most favorable result for the insurer. In general, analysts measure data quality in terms of the data’s

  • Appropriateness. The degree to which data meet the requirements of the intended purpose.

  • Accuracy. The degree to which data correctly describe the real-world phenomena they are designed to measure.

  • Relevance. The degree to which information derived through data analysis meets the needs of users.

  • Timeliness. A measure of the delay between the reference date for the data and the date the analysis is published.

  • Interpretability. The ease with which data can be correctly interpreted.

  • Accessibility. The degree of ease with which needed data can be obtained.

  • Coherence. The degree to which data can successfully be integrated with other statistical information over time.

Ideally, the data used in financial modeling should have all the attributes of quality data. In reality, trade-offs are often necessary. For example, new products have no existing data from which to draw assumptions, and an insurer must determine which data from other existing products would meet the required quality standards. pages.title: Modeling Approaches
pages.contents:
Modeling Approaches

Many factors influence an insurer’s selection of the best modeling approach for a given purpose. Overall, a company wants the most accurate simulation of a process while still remaining cost-effective. Simulation modeling is the use of a real-world process model and extrapolation to emulate the behavior of the process over time. The real-world process model might be anything from new product sales to the number, type, and probable resolution of claims. In the context of statistics, extrapolation is the process of estimating values outside of a known range on the basis of other values derived from direct observation. These extrapolated values are expected to follow the characteristics and behaviors of the known values.

An insurer can use simulation modeling to assess the impact of different levels of economic activity, including economic growth and market interest rates, on its future financial condition.

Running a model once produces a single scenario and a single set of results. However, the objective of simulation modeling is not to produce a single forecast of future conditions based on a known or expected set of conditions. Instead, simulation modeling is designed to explore a number of “what if” situations, or scenarios. Because pricing decisions are so important, actuaries often model up to 200 interest-rate scenarios and up to 1,000 market scenarios when pricing new products.

Sometimes decision makers are interested in determining the best outcomes rather than an array of possible outcomes. Modeling based on this approach is referred to as optimization modeling, which we discuss later in this chapter.

 

Deciding on a Model

After selecting a general approach, actuaries must decide which model to use. When deciding on a model, an actuary must understand what it will be used for, as well as the results that are needed, who will be using it, and the resources available for its use.

One of the considerations when choosing a model are the needs of its intended users, which may include actuaries, rating agencies, and regulators. For example, an actuary at an insurance company may need a model for valuation of a new product design, while a regulator may need a model for assessing an insurance company as a whole.

The model chosen directly influences the data and resources required, the design of the model, and the form in which outputs are produced. The more detailed and complex the model, the more time is needed to determine assumptions, validate the results, and ensure the assumptions are revised as necessary. The model must strike a balance between the need for complexity and time and cost constraints.

If a model is too complex, it may require a prohibitive amount of time and financial resources to attain the desired results, and the complexity may make the results more difficult to interpret. Alternatively, if a model is too simple, it may not provide sufficient detail, which may lead to erroneous decisions and conclusions.

Other considerations when choosing a model include

  • Time horizon. Because life insurance and annuity products can be in force for decades, a scenario that plays out over the lifetime of a product can grow increasingly complex. The longer the time horizon, the more variables that a model must evaluate.

  • Interrelationships. The outputs from a model may be intended to be used as inputs for another model. In this situation, the actuary must choose the models correctly so that the data is usable from one model to the next with minimal additional effort.

  • General vs. tailor-made. A financial model built for a specific scenario can provide much more accurate results, but requires considerably more resources and time than using a more general model that the company already possesses.

  • Product risk profile. Products with varying risk profiles might have varying requirements for accurate modeling. For example, a single-premium deferred annuity has a relatively low mortality risk and a significant market interest risk. Therefore, when modeling a new single-premium deferred annuity product, an insurer needs a model that focuses on market interest changes more than it needs a model that provides the best possible mortality projections.

As previously mentioned, three modeling approaches are deterministic modeling, stochastic modeling, and optimization modeling.

 

Deterministic Modeling

Deterministic modeling is a form of quantitative modeling that simulates the real-world interactions of a stated set of input variables and produces a single set of output variables. In other words, each input variable has a single value, and each output variable has a single value. If the output variable can be predicted with 100 percent certainty based only on the input variables, a deterministic relationship exists. A simple example of a deterministic model is a model that calculates the return on an investment given the single values of money invested, interest rate, and so on.

The independent variables that serve as inputs are typically derived from analysis of historical experience data. For example, a deterministic model that calculates claims paid based on an assumed mortality rate would require the company to specify the mortality rate, rather than have the model select a mortality rate from a range of possible rates. A deterministic model calculates a specific result according to the chosen inputs, but it cannot verify whether those inputs are correct, or even probable.

Although deterministic modeling does not inherently account for risks or probabilities, users can acknowledge risks through defined conditions, such as the rates used to discount cash flows. In effect, the user adjusts the inputs to reflect the risk involved.

Users can also acknowledge risk by basing the number of alternative scenarios they evaluate on the sensitivity of the output to changes in input values. Sensitivity is a measure of how responsive a dependent variable is to changes in independent variables. For most variables, insurers need between 1 and 20 scenarios to achieve a reasonable estimate. For other variables, insurers may need as many as 100 scenarios. One popular approach is to develop three possible scenarios, or groups of scenarios: a pessimistic scenario, an optimistic scenario, and a best-estimate (or most likely) scenario. Another approach includes a worst-case scenario or group of scenarios as well.

Deterministic modeling is valuable to insurers for its relative ease of use, its relatively modest demand for system resources and data, and its speed in producing decision-support information. Actuaries have long been familiar with deterministic modeling, and most insurers have in-house expertise in using deterministic methods. In addition, deterministic methods support some of the applications U.S. regulators require for monitoring insurers.

However, results from deterministic modeling are highly dependent on the quality of the values assigned to input variables. To counter this potential limitation, insurers take great care in developing value estimates of the variables they model.

 

Stochastic Modeling

Life insurance companies have been using deterministic approaches to product modeling for many years. In recent years, however, insurers have been increasingly applying stochastic modeling approaches. Stochastic modeling, also known as probabilistic modeling, is a form of modeling in which an automatic process randomly assigns values to specified input data in order to create a large number of scenarios, conduct numerous process iterations as needed, and produce output data that can be described in the form of a probability distribution. We discuss probability distributions later in this chapter.

A stochastic model takes into account the uncertainty in a company’s estimated cash flows by treating one or more components of the cash flows as random variables from specified probability distributions. In contrast, a deterministic model treats all estimated cash flows as though they are certain. If the goal of a model is to produce probabilities of results, then an actuary would most likely use a stochastic model.

The result of a stochastic forecast might tell us that, in the year 2025, the cumulative value of a portfolio’s net cash flows has the following profile:

Probability Range between
60% $20 billion and $80 billion
40% $30 billion and $65 billion
20% $40 billion and $50 billion

Stochastic modeling of financial processes is most often used to simulate real-world financial conditions, such as stock market returns and market interest rates. Stochastic models are also an increasingly useful option for modeling mortality outcomes.

To support probabilistic results, a stochastic model must begin with a data set of potential future outcomes for all critical variables. For example, a stochastic model used to forecast asset values would need a data set of potential real-world investment returns and a data set of potential real-world market interest rates.

A stochastic model replicates data interactions by combining multiple data sets, one for each of the critical variables, and running thousands of iterations of the model. These thousands of iterations produce thousands of results in the form of scenarios.

The major benefits of stochastic modeling are a high volume of decision-support information, accompanied by assessments of probability and risk. One potential risk of stochastic modeling is that a poorly constructed model can produce greatly distorted outcomes and can lead to false confidence in the results. Stochastic methods use data values that evolve over a lengthy projected future period in a trend consistent with historical behavior. Even a small error in model construction can be greatly magnified over the course of thousands of model iterations, especially if large numbers of independent variables are involved. An additional risk associated with all computer-based modeling, stochastic or otherwise, is that flaws in either the model or the processing might go undetected.

The extent to which life insurers use stochastic modeling varies. Some companies use stochastic modeling only in limited situations, such as when it is thought to be superior to deterministic modeling or when it is a regulatory requirement. Other companies apply stochastic modeling routinely. As computing power advances, stochastic models are becoming more accessible.

The following insight illustrates stochastic and deterministic modeling of the same term life insurance premium.

INSIGHT

Stochastic and Deterministic Modeling for a Term Life Insurance Premium

An actuary can calculate a term life insurance premium using either a deterministic or a stochastic model. The deterministic model finds only one path to the solution, whereas the stochastic model finds many paths. If the result from the deterministic model happens to be close in value to the average of the stochastic results, then the resulting term life premium will be approximately the same whether it is calculated using a deterministic or stochastic method. Suppose, as often happens, the model produced an average stochastic premium result that was slightly greater than the deterministic term life premium, as shown:

PREMIUM MODELING RESULTS: TERM LIFE INSURANCE

Deterministic premium ………………………………………………………. $2.00

Average stochastic premium ………………......................................... $2.10

Range of stochastic premiums ………………………………………...…. $1.50-$2.65

Stochastic methods take into consideration some risk elements that deterministic methods may not fully take into account, and thus, often produce results that vary farther from the baseline of a deterministic method.

 

Optimization Modeling

Optimization modeling is a form of modeling that focuses on finding an optimum solution to several simultaneous equations. The optimum solutions generated by optimization modeling are always single values. Actuaries use an optimization model to find the maximum or minimum possible result for a chosen set of objectives. These maximum or minimum results are known as optimum results, because they represent the most favorable value for each result.

Insurers can use optimization modeling to determine either (1) the maximum possible profit for a chosen level or risk or (2) the minimum possible risk level for a chosen level of profitability. Optimization modeling techniques include linear programming, quadratic programming, dynamic programming, and multidimensional programming. Further discussion of these techniques is beyond the scope of this course.

pages.title: Model Outputs
pages.contents:
Model Outputs

Outputs represent the results of a financial process. A model’s outputs can be single values or a listing of all the possible values in a data set, depending on the particular modeling approach used. The estimates of future financial values generated by models usually take one of three forms: point estimates, range estimates, and probability distributions.

 

Point Estimates and Range Estimates

Deterministic models, which assign single values to input variables, produce results in the form of single-value estimates. Optimization models, which generate optimum results, also produce single-value estimates. An estimate that is assigned a single value is referred to as a point estimate.

Insurers sometimes use point estimates to calculate product profitability based on interest earnings. Insurers also use point estimates to identify projected lapse rates.

The Fairview Insurance Company used a deterministic model to project the first-year lapse rate of a new life insurance product. Using single-value input variables derived from Fairview’s historical lapse experience data, the model produced an estimated first-year lapse rate of 10% for the product.

As an alternative to assigning single values to estimates, decision makers can acknowledge the uncertainty of forecasted values by specifying a range of values for a model’s outcomes. An estimate that provides a range of possible outcome values is known as a range estimate. An estimated first-year lapse rate of 5 to 15 percent is a range estimate. By analyzing a range of values, decision makers can take steps to protect against potential unfavorable situations and take advantage of potential favorable situations.

With range estimates, financial models sometimes also produce a confidence limit. A confidence limit expresses the probability that a specific outcome will fall within a stated range. The more confident the forecaster is that a projected value will be correct, the higher the value of the confidence limit assigned to that projected value. Only stochastic models generate outputs with probabilities attached.

Fairview then used a stochastic model to project the product’s first-year lapse rate, with the outputs expressed as range estimates. The model also produced confidence limits to project the probability of the first-year lapse rate falling in each range estimate.

Lapse Rate Confidence Limit
Between 4% and 6% 68.0%
Between 3% and 8% 95.0%
Between 2% and 10% 99.0%

Based on these results, Fairview can see that the first-year lapse rate is highly likely to fall between 2% and 10%.

 

Probability Distributions

Stochastic modeling assigns multiple values to input variables and produces results in the form of probability distributions. A probability distribution is a data distribution that includes both data values and the probability of observing each value. So, the output of a stochastic model indicates how likely certain results are to occur, which allows an insurer to better analyze risk. Because the output variables produced by deterministic modeling do not involve randomness—output variables can be predicted with 100 percent certainty based only on the input variables—they are not associated with a probability distribution.

Sometimes the results of stochastic modeling follow a normal distribution, which is the most common form of probability distribution. A normal distribution, also known as a normal probability distribution, is one in which the number of values that are less than the mean is the same as the number of values greater than the mean, and in which the values are dispersed in a specific proportion. In other words, there are as many values greater than the average as there are values less than the average, which is what we normally expect when we find the average value on a set. When plotted on a graph, the data values in a normal distribution form a bell-shaped curve called a normal curve, also known as a normal distribution curve. A normal distribution typically results when the modeled variable is the sum of a large number of independent, identically distributed variables.

Normal distributions are symmetrical. Thus, if you were to divide a normal curve down the middle, using a vertical line, the left and right sides of the curve would match exactly. The midpoint of the curve is the mean, or arithmetic average of the values in the data set, calculated by summing all of the values in a specified group and dividing by the number of values in that group. In a normal distribution, the mean is also equal to the median—the middle value in the data set—and the mode—the most common value in the data set. The standard deviation is a measure of the dispersion of values in a data set around the mean of the data set.

Although all normal distributions are symmetrical, not all symmetrical distributions are normal distributions. The exact differences between non-normal symmetrical distributions and normal distributions are beyond the scope of this course. In general, these differences stem from the relationship between data values and the distribution’s mean. Individual data values in a normal distribution are dispersed around the mean so that approximately

  • 68.27 percent of the data fall within one standard deviation on either side of the mean

  • 95.45 percent of the data fall within two standard deviations on either side of the mean

  • 99.73 percent of the data fall within three standard deviations on either side of the mean

The two portions of the normal curve that extend beyond three standard deviations on either side are called tails. If the data being analyzed is normally distributed, the probability of a value being in one of the tails is extremely small—approximately 0.003, or 0.3%. Figure 4.2 provides an illustration of a normal distribution. In this normal curve, with a standard deviation of 4, the mean is located at “0,” and the standard deviations are located at +/- 4, +/- 8, +/- 12.

Because real-world observations are rarely distributed normally, the probability distributions produced by stochastic modeling are often non-normal distributions. A non-normal distribution is generally an asymmetric distribution in which the number of values on one side of the mean is greater than the number of values on the other side of the mean. In a non-normal distribution, the mean is not generally equal to the median and the mode. An example of a non-normal curve is shown in Figure 4.3.

Financial values, such as stock values, are often distributed non-normally because they are affected by a variety of market factors. Many variables used in the financial design of insurance products are also distributed non-normally, including

  • Investment earnings, which depend on market conditions

  • Mortality costs and other costs of benefits

  • Product shelf life

  • Lapse rates, withdrawal rates, changes in premium allocations, and benefit utilization choices, all of which depend on policyholder behavior

  • Product expenses

Analysts often use skewness and kurtosis measures in addition to the mean, median, and mode to describe probability distributions.

Skewness is a statistical parameter that describes the lack of symmetry in a probability distribution. A normal distribution has a skewness of 0. A distribution is positively skewed if the peak of the distribution is shifted to the left of the mean value. A distribution is negatively skewed if the peak of the distribution is shifted to the right of the mean value. The non-normal curve shown in Figure 4.3 is positively skewed.

Kurtosis is a statistical parameter that describes the shape of a probability distribution. Distributions with high kurtosis tend to have “fat” or heavy tails. A tail is considered “fat” if the probability of values occurring in the tail and the risk associated with tail values—known as tail risk—are higher than predicted by the normal distribution. Some distributions, like the one in Figure 4.3, may have a “fat” tail at only one end. Note also that a distribution might have low kurtosis, meaning that relatively fewer values appear in the tails. Kurtosis may appear in both symmetrical and asymmetrical probability distributions.

The low probability/high severity risks in the tail are important for insurers because they indicate the potential for catastrophic losses or windfall gains. Insurers typically measure the severity of tail risk by calculating a statistic known as the conditional tail expectation. The conditional tail expectation (CTE) is the average of all the values within a specified range of the probability distribution.

To properly focus on values within a distribution’s tails, an actuary measures CTE in terms of the scenarios it excludes, rather than the scenarios it includes. The average for all the scenarios in a distribution is referred to as CTE(0) because it excludes none of the scenarios in the distribution. The average of the worst 10 percent of scenarios, which excludes 90 percent of the scenarios in the distribution, is referred to as CTE(90).

To assess the severity of the tail risk, insurers often compare the CTE for a specified range with some measure of profitability, such as internal rate of return (IRR) or return on assets (ROA). Insurers can adjust for risks above the acceptable level by establishing a higher reserve amount for the product or by modifying the product’s design.

pages.title: Model Analysis
pages.contents:
Model Analysis

When insurers run multiple iterations of a financial model, they are testing multiple scenarios that consist of projections of actuarial and economic values. To understand the implications of a model’s results, insurers must be able to determine the amount and timing of changes in output variables created by changes in input variables. For example, model analysis of a proposed life insurance product can measure changes in the output of projected profits based on changes in input variables such as market interest rates, lapse rates, mortality, and so on. Insurers generally obtain this information through scenario testing and sensitivity analysis.

 

Scenario Testing

Scenario testing for financial modeling is a method of evaluating modeling results that involves entering different sets of data into a model and then determining how changes in the input data affect the model’s output data. Generally, the scenarios being tested include a mix of optimistic, moderate, and pessimistic scenarios with at least one worst-case scenario. For example, the annual OASDI Trustees Report on Social Security uses scenario testing to project potential shortfalls in the U.S. Social Security program as various scenarios take place.

One common practice among insurers using deterministic models is to create optimistic, pessimistic, and most likely scenarios using input data derived from historical experience. By making changes to input variables and then running separate iterations of the model for each new value, insurers can capture varying degrees of optimism or pessimism and better determine the likelihood of each of these outcomes.

One important application of scenario testing is dynamic financial analysis. Dynamic financial analysis (DFA) is the use of simulation modeling and multiple scenario testing to project an insurer’s assets, liabilities, and owners’ equity as of a given valuation date and to compare the values of those variables at various times after the valuation date. In general, DFA holistically analyzes risks and challenges for the entire organization’s operations. DFA produces decision-support information that an insurer can use in narrowly focused or broad-ranging risk analysis and risk management.

At a strategic level, DFA often takes the form of dynamic solvency testing. Dynamic solvency testing (DST) is an application of DFA that involves projecting an insurer’s capital as of a given valuation date and comparing the projected amounts of capital at various times after the valuation date. Because DST illustrates the effects of various plausible scenarios on the adequacy of an insurer’s forecasted capital, it is often called capital adequacy testing. Capital adequacy refers to the minimum amount of capital that an insurer must hold to meet a specified standard for capital.

Another specific application of scenario testing is to determine the adequacy of the assets backing an insurance company’s reserves. Asset adequacy analysis is a broad actuarial practice undertaken to ensure that the assets backing reserves meet established standards. Actuaries can use deterministic or stochastic scenarios to test asset adequacy; in recent years, stochastic scenarios have become increasingly popular with insurers. On a more specific level, insurers typically measure the adequacy of assets and liabilities for particular products through cash-flow testing. Cash flow testing (CFT) is the use of simulation modeling to project the cash flows associated with an insurance company’s assets and liabilities as of a given valuation date and to compare the timing and amounts of asset and liability cash flows at various times after the valuation date.

Cash-flow testing requires that an insurer model assets and liabilities under a variety of economic scenarios.

  • Modeling assets. Asset cash-flow models use a variation of the company’s asset valuation and reporting system to estimate future asset values. The values produced by the models for asset prepayment rates, asset default rates, and reinvestment rates vary by scenario.

  • Modeling liabilities. Liability cash-flow models use a variation of the company’s liability reporting system to estimate future liability cash flows. The values produced by the models for market interest rates and interest-crediting rates vary by scenario. Insurers commonly use liability cash-flow modeling to evaluate liabilities associated with deferred annuities.

Most insurers use modeling software that projects asset and liability cash flows simultaneously.

 

Sensitivity Analysis

Insurers use sensitivity analysis to assess the level of the change in input needed to create a change in the outputs. Sensitivity analysis is a method of measuring the responsiveness of the outputs produced by a financial model to changes in the values of the model’s input variables.

Like scenario testing, sensitivity analysis requires multiple scenarios and multiple processing runs. However, whereas scenario testing measures the amount of the change in a dependent variable created by a change in an independent variable, sensitivity analysis measures how much change in the independent variable is necessary to create a change in the dependent variable. In essence, scenario testing asks “What will the outcome of these scenarios be?”, while sensitivity testing asks “What effect does this variable have on another variable?” Sensitivity analysis can also be useful in identifying a range of values for independent variables over which the changes in dependent variables are acceptable.

EXAMPLE

Example. Chevalier Life Insurance is considering both scenario testing and sensitivity analysis to analyze potential interest rate risk to the company. When using scenario testing, Chevalier would define and test scenarios to answer questions such as, “How are our assets and liabilities likely to change if the market interest rate remains steady at 2%, falls to 1.5%, or rises to 2.5%?”

When using sensitivity analysis, Chevalier would define and test scenarios to answer a question such as, “How much can the market interest rate change before it has a significant effect on company cash flows?”

Insurance companies often use sensitivity analysis to identify the sensitivity of the company’s assets and liabilities to changes in market interest rates. Insurers can then use the results of this analysis to construct investment portfolios and to provide input into technical product design. Sensitivity analysis can also be used to measure the interest sensitivity of product cash flows. Analysis of the effects of various interest-rate scenarios on cash flows is known as interest-sensitive cash-flow testing. Insurers can perform interest-sensitive cash-flow testing on a single product, a block of products, or an entire product line. Insurers often use interest-sensitive cash-flow testing to support various actuarial opinions and memoranda that regulators require.

In addition to scenario testing and sensitivity analysis, actuaries must further analyze and validate the results of the model to ensure the results are actuarially sound and reasonable. The following insight lists some questions actuaries may ask when validating the results of a financial model.

INSIGHT

Validation of Model Results

After running a financial model, actuaries are responsible for validating the results to ensure the outcomes are reasonable in light of the inputs. Actuaries may ask the following questions:

  • Are outputs consistent with inputs?
  • How many errors were generated and what amount was involved?
  • Are the intended assumptions the ones used in the model?
  • Are model assumptions unchanged unless they were meant to be changed?
  • Are results as expected, both in direction and magnitude?
  • If there are several model runs at different dates, are the latest results consistent with the trend?
  • Are the results consistent with the impacts obtained from any sensitivity analysis that was conducted?
  • How do the results for the first projection period compare to the most recent period of actual results for a comparable product?

Keeping pace with change is important in every industry, but it’s especially crucial in the life insurance industry. Examples of changes that affect life insurers include

  • Technological and social changes that affect the types of products and services that customers want

  • Changes in mortality rates due to medical advances

  • Shifts in the economy that affect customers’ purchasing power

  • New competitors entering a market, offering products that raise customer expectations

  • Regulations that impose new requirements on life insurance products

To remain competitive in this environment, a life insurance company must be quick in determining customer needs and bringing products that meet those needs to market. An insurer must also be thorough in its product development process, ensuring that each new product is meticulously researched and supported by an efficient use of company resources.

To create new products quickly enough to meet changing customer needs, a company needs strong planning and efficient processes. In this chapter, we discuss the considerations insurers address when developing new products, as well as the importance of product management and control. We also describe the first two steps in the typical product development process: product planning and comprehensive business analysis. We will discuss the remaining three steps—technical product design, product introduction, and product monitoring—in the following chapter.
