pages.title: Considerations in New Product Development
pages.contents:
Considerations in New Product Development

To develop and launch a new product, an insurance company must spend substantial money now and commit to future obligations in the hope of earning a profit later. The insurer incurs significant upfront costs by establishing reserves, paying sales commissions, utilizing actuarial services, and ensuring compliance.

The conditions surrounding product development, both external and internal, are ever-changing. Economic, demographic, and technological changes occur outside the company, while objectives and technology may change inside the company. Product development requires constant attention to the forces that threaten to pull a product’s objectives in different directions. Figure 5.1 illustrates the opposing forces surrounding new product development for life insurance companies.

Many of the risks detailed in Chapter 2 are risks companies regularly face from in-force life insurance and annuity business. In contrast, new product risk refers to any risk that companies face in developing and supporting new life insurance and annuity products. When developing a new product, a company incurs costs that it must recover, while perhaps losing the opportunity to develop an alternative product or products that might have been more profitable. Many risks comprise new product risk.

The most basic new product risk is that a new product never earns a profit at all. Potential causes of inadequate profits or even losses include

  • Inadequate pricing

  • Incorrect underwriting standards

  • Poor sales volume

  • A product design that becomes quickly obsolete

To estimate the cost for an established product, companies and industry groups accumulate experience data to use in projecting the future costs of supporting the product. For new products, however, there is no history. Without relevant experience data, the actuarial staff must invest more time learning about the new product during product design. The insurer might even have to spend money to hire consulting actuaries who can contribute additional experience. The insurer must set standards for acceptable risk levels and must create administrative control systems for identifying risks, monitoring the status of these risks, and managing the most critical risks—all before the product’s risks are fully understood.

To manage new product risk, insurers consider many factors, including the product development strategy, product portfolio and product mix, shelf life, product complexity, customer experience, product management and control, regulatory factors, and other environmental pressures. Let’s explore each of these factors.

 

Product Development Strategy

In the life insurance industry, products constantly undergo revision and replacement. In this environment, insurers must carefully consider how to position their products for success—and they must do so as early in the product development process as possible. Many insurers begin the process by employing product development strategies.

An insurer may revise or reprice a product in response to shifts in market conditions, regulatory changes, poor product performance, or other circumstances. Many insurers also pursue broader strategies that guide the product development of a product line or even the company as a whole. The following examples describe strategies that insurers can apply to individual products or to entire product lines:

  • Cost Leadership: A simple strategy in many industries is to offer a product at a cost lower than the average cost in the market, or lower than the cost of a comparable product offered by a competitor. A cost leadership strategy requires careful expense control, especially for insurers. In the insurance industry, actuaries must ensure that lower-cost products can still be profitable even if revenues are lower than expected. Insurers may adopt a cost leadership strategy for a new product during times of slow economic growth, when customers with tighter budgets carefully consider the cost of any purchase.

  • Focused Differentiation or Niche: When using a focused differentiation or niche strategy, insurers design products that are targeted at a narrow or specialized section of the market. In the life insurance industry, income level is just one category of potential specialized markets. For example, many term life insurance products are designed as lower-cost offerings for customers with more limited means, while advanced market products are created for affluent customers or organizations.

  • First Mover: Remember from Chapter 1 that a company using a first mover strategy attempts to be the first to offer a particular product or service. A first mover strategy is often referred to as a market leader strategy, since the first company to enter a market has a reasonable chance of capturing and retaining the largest share of that market. A first mover strategy requires innovation and substantial market research, because the company must determine whether sufficient demand exists for a previously unknown product. In the insurance industry, first mover strategies often involve new companies or startups leveraging technological advances to create products for the growing market of digitally literate consumers.

  • Fast Follower: Also remember from Chapter 1 that a fast follower strategy typically involves imitating and iterating on a competitor’s product. The fast follower product is similar to a first mover’s product, but with improvements designed to appeal to a larger portion of potential customers, or refinements based on emerging experience. The fast follower strategy does not require the same degree of market research and innovation that the first mover strategy requires. However, a company needs to be quick and insightful to be able to produce an improved product before the company’s competitors do. In the insurance industry, the fast follower strategy often focuses on taking technological innovations and adapting them to product design.

Note that not all insurers have a clearly defined strategy for product development. An insurer may offer a number of products designed with a cost leadership strategy, yet also develop a new product with a focused differentiation strategy. If the company has the resources and knowledge base to support multiple product development strategies, it can offer a more diverse range of products and therefore appeal to a broader market. This product diversification also aids solvency: when one product line is underperforming, the insurer may still have the revenues from other product lines to help meet its obligations.

 

Product Portfolio and Product Mix

When launching a new product, a company adds to its product portfolio and alters the proportions of its product mix. In this course, we define the two terms as follows:

  • A product portfolio is the array of all products a company offers for sale, categorized by line of business. For example, an insurer might have a life insurance or an annuity portfolio.

  • A product mix is a company’s total assortment of products within each line of business according to a monetary measure of business volume, such as premiums collected, reserves, or in the case of life insurance, face amount in force. An insurer typically measures its product mix by proportion.

Thus, a new annuity product would broaden the annuity product portfolio, but would also alter the proportionate amount of reserves held for annuities as a whole. Watch Video 5.1 for a comparison between two companies’ product portfolios and product mixes.

When a company decides to change its product mix, it makes this decision within the context of

  • Its product lines and overall product portfolio

  • Its strategic goals and risk preferences

  • Any competing products within the financial services industry

Maintaining a balanced product mix is one form of risk management. Consistent with ALM and ERM practices, insurers manage their product mixes using approaches that are suited for managing any portfolio of risks.

 

Shelf Life

In the context of product development, shelf life refers to how long an insurer can offer a product in the marketplace before it becomes obsolete and needs to be revised, repriced, or retired. In the United States, insurers typically revise, reprice, or retire the average life insurance or annuity product after one to five years. 1 Whole life insurance and life insurance products with riders tend to have longer shelf lives than term life insurance and universal life insurance products. Indexed products, such as indexed universal life insurance products and indexed annuity products, are the most prone to revision or retirement, with an average shelf life of about one to two years. Figure 5.2 shows the typical product shelf life for various life insurance product types, as reported in an industry survey. 2

 

Product Complexity

Complex products that contain multiple benefits, new benefits, or new and unfamiliar features create additional risks. Insurers develop complex products for a variety of reasons—for example, to meet the needs of consumers in target markets, to differentiate their products from those offered by industry competitors, and even to compete against products offered by competitors outside the insurance industry. Part of the risk of complex products is determining the proper pricing for the additional benefits. Another part of the risk is that customers find it easier to understand simpler products, even when a more complex product might suit a customer’s needs better. Figure 5.3 illustrates examples of product complexity.

Technological innovation can affect the complexity of product design in multiple ways. For example, consumer-facing technology such as health-tracking wearable devices can provide an insurer with detailed data points on an insured person’s heart rate, activity levels, and so on. This data can inform the underwriting process and allows the insurer to create insurance products that offer lower premiums if the insured maintains a more active lifestyle. The varying premium amounts thus add to a product’s complexity.

Company-facing technological advances also make more complex products possible. As mentioned previously, new products have no experience data for insurers to draw on. For these products, companies have increasingly turned to stochastic modeling processes. As you recall from Chapter 4, stochastic modeling enables users to randomly model unknown future events to gain a better understanding of how a product might perform. Technological advances in computing power allow more companies to make greater use of stochastic modeling. In turn, stochastic modeling allows insurers to create complex products such as variable annuities with living benefit riders, which involve anticipating inflation and other variables 20-40 years into the future. However, stochastic modeling still poses challenges to insurers—even in companies where stochastic modeling is established, the processes require continual learning, and the models are subject to ongoing refinements.

 

Level of Innovation

As we discussed earlier, not all products newly introduced to the market represent a totally new product design. A new product can represent slight stylistic adjustments to an existing product or it can offer notable new benefits.

Loosely, innovation refers to an improvement that adds value to a design or process. We can view innovation as existing in degrees, from a very small improvement to a broad, sweeping change. In the context of product development, innovation usually refers to at least a moderate change, because a small change is not likely to interest customers. At the far extreme, innovation can refer to a breakthrough that renders past designs and practices obsolete.

EXAMPLE

In the insurance industry, a major innovation occurred when companies first offered fixed indexed products. As fixed indexed products gained popularity, insurers modified certain product features—a more limited form of innovation.

 

Speed to Market

The more complex a product development project is, the more time the product takes to get to market. Companies typically evaluate product development projects on the basis of complexity.

  • Simplest: A rate change project, sometimes called a repricing project, involves changing the rates for adjustable policy elements, such as certain fees and charges. Rate change projects require planning, pricing, and possibly changing administration processes, pre-sales illustrations, and testing tools.

  • Intermediate: A product revision project involves broader changes than does a rate change project but fewer changes than does a new product project. Generally speaking, any project that involves changes to an existing product is either a rate change project or a product revision project. Product revision projects also involve regulatory rate filings to reflect the changes. One example of a product revision project is the addition of a rider to an existing product.

  • Most Complex: A new product project is the most complex type of product development project, requiring the company to develop new product features and prepare comprehensive regulatory filings. These filings usually require the submission and evaluation of large amounts of complex information. A new product project requires a full-scale effort in all phases of the product development process.

Not surprisingly, the level of project complexity affects the time required to complete the product development process. Figure 5.4 shows the median time in weeks for new life insurance products at varying levels of complexity. 3

 

Customer Experience

Customer experience has become a vital part of doing business in all industries, including the life insurance industry. The customer experience (frequently abbreviated as CX) is the impression of a company that a customer forms as a result of every interaction the customer has with the company and its representatives. Insurers are finding that customers frequently hold them to a higher standard of customer experience based on their transactions in entirely different industries. Customers often expect to have the same type of positive experience with insurance companies that they have with companies in other industries, such as the retail and service industries.

EXAMPLE

Hari Mahal purchased an automobile through a dealer’s website, without having to physically visit the dealership or haggle over options and interest rates. When Hari later considered purchasing a life insurance policy, he expected a similarly convenient experience, preferring to go through the purchase process from his own home instead of making an appointment with an agent.

Because customer expectations are so high, delivering an exceptional customer experience must be a priority across the company. Many companies use an omnichannel service strategy to seamlessly provide a similar, high-quality customer experience across multiple, integrated communication platforms. This strategy seeks to provide a positive experience at each potential point of contact that a customer might have with the company. For example, many customers would prefer using mobile devices to contact a company, while others prefer email, and still others prefer direct telephone calls. An insurer pursuing this strategy works to make each of these potential points of contact, as well as others, a positive customer experience. Many of the changes an insurer would make to pursue an omnichannel service strategy are outside the scope of this course, but this strategy can affect product development.

In the interest of promoting a stronger customer experience, insurance companies are developing products that are more customizable, allowing customers to purchase individualized products that match their individual needs. Certain CX initiatives can also empower the product development process itself.

EXAMPLE

Blocksmith Life Insurance promotes wearable technology as a means for customers to participate in wellness programs. The customers who opt into these programs receive benefits such as lower premiums for each month they participate. In turn, Blocksmith can use the information collected from the wearable technology to more accurately assess customer risk profiles and to tailor new products and policies.

 

Product Management and Control

Effective product management is essential to the product development process. For example, strong product management can create efficiencies in the process that increase a product’s speed to market despite its complexity. An effective product development process has certain characteristics, such as a

  • Documented product development procedure

  • Development schedule and planned launch date

  • Detailed product development budget and product sales forecasts

  • Formal system for monitoring progress and product performance, including standard project documentation

A product portfolio requires multiple levels of management, and managers must communicate with one another during the product development process. For example, when the company develops a new term life insurance product, the manager of the specific product must coordinate with the manager of the term life product line and the manager of the company’s life insurance business as a whole.

Successful product management also relies on the efforts of groups of specialists, each of which is proficient in a specific technical area. Much of the time, each group works in isolation from the other groups. In product development, however, the company must assemble cross-functional teams.

A cross-functional team comprises representatives from different functional areas of the company, such as investments, underwriting, actuarial, marketing, and IT. Because each functional area uses its own distinct, technical terms, members of a cross-functional team must take steps to communicate clearly. Examples of cross-functional teams include the following:

  • The marketing committee is a senior management group whose primary role is to provide overall guidance and control of the product development process. Typical activities include reviewing new product designs and approving or rejecting further development of each new product design.

  • The risk committee, discussed previously, is a senior management group whose primary role is to provide overall guidance and control of ERM efforts. This group must ensure that all functional units have appropriately understood, measured, and arranged to manage all the risks associated with a new product. The risk committee reviews all risk exposures, risk policies, risk standards, and risk limits associated with the new product. In addition, this committee must express its support for any new product before the product can be launched. The risk committee should not be confused with the audit committee, which operates independently to oversee financial reporting and disclosure.

  • A product development team usually performs hands-on development of a new product. Most large insurance companies have a permanent product development team. Smaller insurers may assemble product development teams on a temporary basis to develop specific products. Product development teams typically include representatives from the company’s marketing, actuarial, underwriting, contract administration, investments, IT, customer service, legal, and accounting areas.

Typically, the product development team in a life insurance company is responsible for the following activities:

  • Conducting research about product features, market demand, competitive activity, target markets, company experience with mortality or morbidity, and customer behavior

  • Planning, budgeting, and scheduling for product development

  • Making product and risk management recommendations about the company’s product mix

  • Designing benefits, financial structures, underwriting standards, and contract features for new products

  • Guiding product implementation, which includes setting up distribution and administrative operations to support a new product

An additional product management consideration at many companies is how best to balance in-house and outsourced tasks. Recall from Chapter 3 that outsourcing offers both benefits and challenges to the insurer. Some of the advantages of outsourcing include

  • Access to highly specialized experts without the company having to train the experts itself

  • Lower labor cost

  • Access to a larger talent pool

Conversely, some of the challenges inherent to outsourcing include

  • Additional effort required for all team members to be in constant, clear communication

  • Less direct control over outsourced work

  • Potential communication barriers due to language differences

  • Increased security vulnerabilities

Reinsurance, while not specifically a form of outsourcing, can also play a role in product management. For example, reinsurers can offer assistance in product development and stress testing.

 

Regulatory Factors

As we discussed in Chapter 2, regulatory risk can be created by changes in the regulatory environment. New or changed laws and regulations can have a profound effect on an insurer’s products. In most instances, a newly passed law or regulation does not take effect immediately—instead, it sets a date in the future by which insurers are expected to be compliant. This practice gives insurers time to make any required changes to their products or processes, but speed is still a key issue for affected insurers. To demonstrate compliance, an insurer makes a policy filing for each of its products. A policy filing is the act of submitting a policy contract form and any other legally required forms and documents to the appropriate state insurance department for approval. Insurers in many U.S. states can also file through the Interstate Insurance Product Regulation Compact (Insurance Compact), which acts as a central point for electronic filing for those states, thus reducing the number of policy filings.

When a company creates a product that is new to the market or to the company, the filing process often takes longer than it would if the company modified an existing product. The more innovative the product, the more time it typically takes for regulators to be satisfied that the new product is fully compliant. As the regulators become familiar with the new product, similar products spend less time in the filing process. Therefore, regulatory issues are likely to have a greater impact on a company pursuing a first mover strategy than they do on a company pursuing a fast follower strategy.

 

Other Environmental Pressures

Regulatory risk is one of the most significant external factors on insurance product development, both for new products and for existing products. However, many other external factors directly affect the market for a new product. Some examples of environmental pressures include the following:

  • Economic: The overall state of the economy affects a person’s willingness to spend money. When inflation outpaces wage growth, for example, consumer budgets become more limited, and fewer consumers see insurance as a priority. In such an environment, a product with new features and correspondingly higher premiums is not likely to be as attractive as a product with lower premiums.

  • Technological: As discussed earlier, customers have increasingly higher expectations for their interactions with a company, especially when it comes to convenience. The ability to purchase an insurance product electronically, for instance, may be the deciding factor in whether a customer purchases a product from a company. However, technological advancements also provide opportunities for product development. Because technological advancements are unlikely to slow down, the opportunities are likely to keep increasing.

EXAMPLE

The introduction of wearable technology that monitors a wearer’s health and activity levels made it possible for Blocksmith Life Insurance to create a product that offers lower premiums for months when the customer exercises more. Blocksmith found the new product was more difficult to price than its other products, given the additional variables of calculating how many customers would be likely to take advantage of this feature, and what effect their increased exercise might have on mortality. However, Blocksmith decided the possibility of earning lower premiums would be highly attractive to potential customers, especially customers who would appreciate an additional incentive to exercise more.

  • Demographic: Different demographics have different purchasing patterns. For instance, younger generations are more likely to prefer purchasing services electronically, while older generations might favor researching services electronically but purchasing them in face-to-face transactions. As demographics shift, product development teams must consider what product features would have greater appeal for the growing sections of the market.

EXAMPLE

Dahlia Life Insurance’s research indicated a growing trend in which people delay starting families until they are older. Dahlia began development on a product designed to benefit new parents in their thirties or forties, as this market seemed to be growing relative to the market of new parents in their twenties.

  • Cultural and Political: Modern communication technology has made it easier for people to share information about a company. Many people want to support companies that demonstrate specific standards of ethical behavior. In addition, different groups of customers may require very different, even contradictory, standards, making it impossible for a company to please all its potential customers. While cultural and political pressures primarily impact a company’s marketing and brand management teams, at some companies they affect product development.

EXAMPLE

Tapir Life Insurance decides to use a portion of a new product’s proceeds to support an ecological advocacy foundation, and designs the product with this goal in mind. Tapir references the ecological foundation when marketing the product to attract attention from customers who value ecological advocacy.

pages.title: Product Development Activities
pages.contents:
Product Development Activities

Development of individual life insurance and annuity products usually begins with product planning and comprehensive business analysis. These activities are designed to identify possible new products and evaluate their potential.

Figure 5.5 depicts the typical process of product development. Note that the actual process differs in details from one company to another, and companies may use their own terms for product development activities.

 

Product Planning

Product planning consists of two main activities: idea generation and idea screening, as seen in Figure 5.6.

 

Idea Generation

Idea generation involves searching for new product ideas that are consistent with the needs of the company’s target markets and the company’s overall product development strategy. The company searches continuously for new ideas by conducting market research, engaging in special projects, monitoring its own products, and monitoring competing products. The company considers totally new product ideas as well as product revisions or product rate changes. Most companies have a formalized process for identifying and considering new product ideas. Creativity is a paramount consideration during idea generation. Many company cultures encourage employees to suggest ideas without spending too much time evaluating them beforehand, as the team can evaluate a proposed product’s practical aspects in the next phase of product development.

Important sources of ideas for new products or enhancements to existing products are the product development team, the sales department, affiliated sales agents, and actuaries. New product ideas also come from research performed by the company’s competitive intelligence unit or units, which usually take the form of a subdivision of a company’s product development team. Competitive intelligence is the systematic collection and analysis of publicly available information about competitors and ongoing developments in the marketing environment. Some companies employ multiple competitive intelligence units to specialize in information about different markets or product types.

 

Idea Screening

During idea screening, a team quickly and inexpensively evaluates new product ideas to separate workable ideas from those that have little or no potential. Many companies apply a predetermined set of screening criteria. Insurance companies use the following criteria for screening new product concepts:

  • Ability to meet customer needs

  • Compatibility with the regulatory environment

  • Marketability to target markets

  • Alignment with the company’s corporate goals and strategies

  • Potential profitability

  • Compatibility with the company’s image

  • Alignment with the company’s current market position

  • Potential for generating additional new sales without displacing or replacing sales of existing products

  • Compatibility with the company’s existing or proposed distribution channels

  • Compatibility with the company’s current actuarial, financial/investment, administrative, accounting, and other systems

  • Understandability for target customers

 

Comprehensive Business Analysis

After quickly eliminating the least promising product ideas, a company subjects the remaining product ideas to a comprehensive business analysis, which is an evaluation of all the factors that are likely to affect the design, production, pricing, marketing, and sales potential of a new product. The comprehensive business analysis evaluates a product’s feasibility: Given the factors potentially affecting the product, is this product a viable option for the company?

In comprehensive business analysis, the product development team identifies the investment strategy that optimizes a proposed product’s performance—such as choosing investments by projected rate of return—and evaluates whether the proposed products can meet all legal and regulatory requirements. Comprehensive business analysis creates a foundation for the following product development activity of technical product design.

During this stage of product development, the product development team must also produce documentation to convince company decision makers that a product idea is worth developing. To support a commitment of company resources, decision makers like to see documentation demonstrating that the product

  • Will satisfy the company’s risk-return requirements and will pay back the company’s investment within a specified time

  • Will have the competitive features required to meet a specified level of sales within the targeted demographic

  • Is likely to be accepted by a sufficient number of captive and independent sales agents who will put their efforts into selling it

  • Is a good fit with the company’s existing expertise and administrative operations

  • Is a good fit with the company’s existing product mix and marketing strategies

  • Can be reliably supported by the company’s existing or planned technological system

Figure 5.7 identifies the elements that are included in a comprehensive business analysis, such as a market analysis, product design objectives, a feasibility study, a marketing plan, marketing projections, and a product proposal.

A market analysis documents an evaluation of all environmental factors that might affect sales of a proposed product. In essence, it represents the company’s effort to demonstrate that market demand exists to support a proposed product. In many cases, an insurer can derive a market analysis for a new product from information already gathered during ongoing market research activities for similar new product ideas. For a product type that is totally new to the company, however, staff must undertake a complete research process.

As a product idea progresses through the product development process, the product development team makes progressively more detailed decisions about the product design. Although the team conceptualizes many aspects of a new product before performing a market analysis, the market analysis provides a foundation that helps in setting product design objectives.

Product design objectives for a life insurance or an annuity product document the product’s basic characteristics, such as its benefits, any limits on the contract amount or the applicant’s age at issue, any special features, the commission range, and any settlement options. These specifications serve as guidelines during technical design of the product. The following insight shows examples of product design objectives.

INSIGHT

Product Design Objectives—Life Insurance and Annuities

Underwriting Specifications

  • Nonmedical limits
  • Any medical questionnaire required above a maximum initial premium amount
  • Standards for any guaranteed or simplified issue basis for life applications, if offered
  • Any minimum and maximum issue age
  • Any maximum dollar limit
  • Smoker/nonsmoker rates
  • Standard/preferred/substandard rates
  • Expected risk-class distribution of business

Risk Specifications

  • Mortality risks and longevity risks
  • Financial and investment risks assumed
  • Interest-rate risk
  • Legal and regulatory risks
  • Policyholder behavior risks, persistency risk, including assumptions as to loans and withdrawals
  • Reinsurance requirements, retention limits

Marketing Specifications

  • Distribution system, marketing channels
  • Commission structures and bonus rates
  • Marketing overhead expense rate
  • Promotion and advertising expense allocation
  • Competitive positioning of product
  • Chargeback schedules
  • Field expenses, if any

Product Specifications (Life Products)

  • Death benefits, settlement options
  • Renewability
  • Convertibility
  • Minimum and maximum face amounts
  • Cash values, surrender benefits, dividend formulas, settlement options
  • Transaction charges, surrender charge schedule
  • Subaccounts for variable products
  • Assumptions as to investment earnings, persistency, average contract size, and expense charges
  • Range of premiums, minimum/maximum
  • Levels of graded premiums
  • Guaranteed or nonguaranteed rates
  • Modes and methods of payment
  • Age bands
  • Policy fees
  • Volume discounts
  • Expense assumptions
  • Premium taxes and other taxes

Product Specifications (Annuities)

  • Asset-based fees
  • Transaction charges
  • Interest-crediting frequency and formula
  • Interest guarantees
  • Withdrawal and surrender benefits
  • Periodic payments (annuitization benefits)
  • Death benefits
  • Secondary guarantees (living benefits)
  • Subaccounts available for variable products

Profit and Risk Specifications

  • Minimum required internal rate of return (IRR)
  • Expected sales volume
  • Expected reserve/expense drain
  • Fewer than X% of scenarios result in a loss

Technology Specifications

  • Omnichannel compatibility
  • Expected system requirements

A feasibility study evaluates whether the company has the capability to take a new product to market. To evaluate a new product’s operational and technical feasibility, the company studies whether the product

  • Can be structured to be competitive and profitable

  • Can be accommodated by the insurer’s operating and distribution systems

  • Can be supported by the insurer’s current resources, employees, and technological capacity

  • Complies with the company’s risk tolerance, underwriting policies, and reinsurance retention strategy

A feasibility study can include a review of the results of another company’s introduction of a similar product. A market analysis can also inform a feasibility study, as the level of potential market demand influences how much resources a company must likely commit to promoting the product. A feasibility study should evaluate and demonstrate how product implementation will compete for resources with other company initiatives and how this interaction might affect the product’s speed to market.

Similar to a feasibility study, a legal and tax review evaluates any legal or tax concerns associated with a new product. The company studies whether a product would comply with all relevant regulations and statutes, and whether the product is likely to cause tax issues for customers.

A marketing plan defines a company’s product, price, distribution, and promotion strategies for reaching potential customers and meeting their needs. The marketing plan typically

  • Outlines the specific, action-oriented tactics the company has developed to support its marketing goals and strategies for the proposed new product

  • Specifies the steps required for accomplishing day-to-day marketing activities, as well as marketing objectives, budgets, and a plan for evaluating progress toward objectives

  • Relies greatly on the information collected during market analysis

A plan developed for a new product is similar to the marketing plans developed for existing products and covers the financial design, promotion, and distribution for the proposed product.

Marketing projections are preliminary sales and financial forecasts that include estimates of potential unit sales, revenues, costs, and profits for a proposed product. A projection specifies an expected or a most likely value—rather than a best-case value or a worst-case value—for an unknown future value, to provide a realistic expectation for a product’s performance. At a preliminary stage of product development, marketers create rough projections of future sales volume, sales revenue, expenses, and profit, which marketers define as follows:

  • Sales volume is the number of units of product sold.

  • Sales revenue is the total dollar volume of sales. Sales revenue is calculated by multiplying the sales volume by the average price per unit.

To project important sales figures, marketers define expenses as the administrative costs the company incurs to support a product, plus the periodic income or benefit payments, cash surrenders, and other benefits the company will pay out.

Projections of these values at an early stage of product development may provide useful data, but data from early projections contain a great deal of uncertainty. As product development progresses, some of this uncertainty disappears, and actuaries are able to revise the projections as they obtain clearer information.

If the comprehensive business analysis indicates strong potential for the proposed product, the product development team prepares a product proposal and presents it to top management for a go/no-go decision on the idea. A product proposal, or business plan, is a document used to present a product idea to an internal team that decides whether to allocate company resources toward developing the product idea. A product proposal describes the following aspects of a product:

  • The product’s purpose

  • Key product features

  • The target market for the product and projected sales volume

  • Differentiation from other products

  • Plans for promotion, advertising, distribution, and sales

  • Requirements for administrative resources, including technology

  • Probability projections and capital needs such as investment changes

  • Regulatory considerations

A product proposal that receives full management approval serves as an overall guide for technical product design and product introduction. We discuss these remaining stages of the product development process, along with product monitoring, in the next chapter.

pages.title: Technical Product Design
pages.contents:
Technical Product Design

For life insurance products, technical product design begins with setting a product’s financial design. Once the design has been established and tested, the development team creates a budget and schedule for the implementation process. Figure 6.1 outlines the technical product design stage.

When designing new life insurance or annuity products, insurers focus on two key objectives: ensuring the timely delivery of benefits to customers and generating profit for the company. Other important objectives of product design include

  • Establishing a level of future benefits that the company can be certain to deliver under unknown future economic and demographic conditions

  • Covering the company’s expenses of supporting the product

  • Providing adequate future investment income to support the company’s financial obligations for products

  • Understanding specific product risks in terms of the company’s risk standards

  • Identifying premium and commission structures that will succeed in the marketplace

  • Providing an adequate return to the company’s owners

  • Enhancing competitive positioning in the marketplace

  • Addressing untapped or under-targeted consumer needs

In terms of managing risk, technical product design is the most important stage of product development. During technical product design, the company fully develops the preliminary plans created during product planning and comprehensive business analysis. The technical product design stage requires the contributions of employees from several areas, such as marketing, finance, and underwriting. However, this chapter focuses largely on product design activities generally performed by the actuarial department. Companies may use staff actuaries or consulting actuaries to develop and design new products.

When possible, the company uses experience data from existing products during technical product design. By comparing experience data from similar products, insurers are more likely to understand customers’ purchase habits and expectations, which increases the odds of creating a financially successful new product. Product design poses a risk to a company because the profitability of a new product depends on using correct product design assumptions. For each new product, technical product design gives the company the opportunity to

  • Improve sales by adding a product that satisfies a customer need

  • Manage risk by appropriately balancing expenses and income and accurately categorizing and pricing risk

  • Increase earnings with a product that generates profit

  • Manage capital needs by creating a cost-efficient product that requires less financing

In the previous chapter, we discussed new product risk and the challenges posed by product complexity and innovation. During the technical product design phase, the company decides how to maximize benefits by fine-tuning specific product features or processes that pose these risks or challenges. For example, initiatives such as using a new distribution channel or significantly relaxing underwriting standards might improve operating efficiency, but they might also increase the level of risk. Effective product design is a matter of deciding what features or processes to include and how best to implement them.

 

Establishing a Financial Design

A product’s financial design begins by building on the product design objectives and other specifications created during the earlier stages of product development. With these specifications in mind, product development actuaries typically model new product designs for life insurance or annuities using product development software. This software uses mathematical modeling to simulate the financial processes and conditions that occur over the time that contracts are in force for a given product. Insurers use product development software to implement deterministic and stochastic approaches to product modeling.

  • Companies typically use deterministic modeling in product design for relatively simple products such as term life insurance, traditional whole life insurance, and fixed immediate annuities.

  • For more complex products such as variable products, companies use stochastic modeling in product design. Stochastic modeling provides detailed information about the volatile risks associated with secondary guarantees and other complicated risks. Many insurers are shifting to primarily stochastic modeling for all products, though regulatory standards may require insurers to apply deterministic modeling in some instances.

Companies can also conduct sensitivity analysis of extreme values to better understand how projected profits may be sensitive to variations in unknown future results. Sensitivity testing involves many model runs, ranging from fewer than a hundred runs for deterministic models to thousands of runs for stochastic models. Sensitivity analysis for a given product may involve both types of model.

Recall that each estimated value used in a life insurance or an annuity product design is known as an actuarial assumption. A typical product design includes actuarial assumptions for investment earnings, the costs of providing benefits, operating expenses, cash flow on existing and new business, expected loss scenarios, and unexpected financial results. Where applicable, insurers compare actuarial assumptions to relevant experience data from similar products.

 

Components of the Financial Design

In determining a product’s financial design, an insurer incorporates several product components, such as expected impacts on the company’s reserves and surplus created by the new product’s sales, as well as a charge for company operating expenses, a charge for the cost of benefits, a provision for investment results, premiums, and a contribution to company earnings. Each of these components must meet the valuation standards specific to the actuarial profession, such as the Actuarial Standards of Practice (ASOPs) set by the Actuarial Standards Board (ASB).

In addition to premiums, considerations from customers may include annuity considerations, premiums for riders, and separate expense charges. Companies generally model the cost of benefits for each rider similarly to how they would model the costs for any other benefit.

In undertaking product modeling, companies can use different approaches. 1 Figure 6.2 illustrates one such approach, an equation that calculates a premium amount.

After the product design team estimates a premium amount, the team can then evaluate this amount to see if it meets product design goals. For instance, if the insurer wishes to create a product with a lower price, the team can lower the required premium amount and then rerun the models to determine if the product is likely to achieve its goals at the new price. Once the team has determined a target amount, it decides how best to set the product elements to reach this goal.

 

Risk and Corporate Risk Statements

Every product design must meet the company’s formal risk guidelines. Risks that can produce negative financial outcomes for products include

  • Unfavorable swings or stagnation in market interest rates.

  • Unfavorable regulatory decisions, unfavorable court decisions, and unfavorable changes in the law, including tax law.

  • Unfavorable deviations from values assumed in a deterministically modeled product design.

  • Unfavorable accounting rules.

  • Negative tail scenarios, which are highly unfavorable scenarios identified in a stochastically modeled product design as potential outcomes. Recall from Chapter 4’s discussion on probability distributions that results more than three standard deviations away from the mean are called tails. A negative tail scenario represents a highly unlikely event on the unfavorable side.

To manage investment risk, actuaries and investment professionals set an investment policy for the assets that will back the new product. In the context of product development, an investment policy limits the asset types—by security, issuer, credit rating, admitted/non-admitted status, and many other features—and the proportions of the assets the company will use to support a product. An investment policy also specifies appropriate strategies for balancing a new product’s liability risks, including mortality risk. When setting investment policies, insurers must also be sure that the policies meet applicable insurance regulatory rules and statutes.

To manage mortality risk, companies develop underwriting guidelines and premium rate tables. Underwriting guidelines establish a structure for risk classes and premium rate structures to ensure that the company charges the correct premiums for the risks it accepts. For life insurance products, actuaries also must state a reinsurance strategy and a retention limit.

Companies use a variety of techniques for addressing risks in product outcomes. In general, approaches vary based on the form of modeling used during product design.

  • For a deterministically modeled product design, any allowances for negative outcomes can consist of a stated amount of money or a degree of conservatism in setting assumed values.

  • For a stochastically modeled product design, companies focus on the probability that the product will meet or exceed the company’s profitability target. The company’s risk processes generally determine, in advance, the minimum acceptable profitability for a product. The resulting product design is acceptable if the percentage of stochastic scenarios that meet or exceed the company’s profitability target is greater than or equal to the minimum percentage.

EXAMPLE

For new products to be approved, Marmalade Life Insurance applies a minimum probability of 80% of achieving the company’s profit target. Upon testing the initial product design for a new product, 77% of the stochastic scenarios met or exceeded the company’s profit target. The product design team then adjusted the product features and tested the design again. This time, 83% of the stochastic scenarios met or exceeded the profit target, and Marmalade approved the product.

 

Charges for Operating Expenses in Product Design

How do actuaries calculate the amount to charge for company expenses? The actuaries estimate the costs—other than the cost of benefits—the company will incur in supporting the product, with allowances for future inflation.

To develop cost estimates, actuaries incorporate information from records of the company’s past expenses—called expense experience—as well as expenses of similar companies offering similar products. The company’s accounting area often develops the expense assumptions used in product design. The accounting area also works with the administrative areas to determine costs for expected transactions such as applications or policy loans. Then actuaries use these expense assumptions as a basis for estimating actual expenses.

The credibility of experience data refers to the predictive value of the data set for a given purpose. For example, past trends have limited credibility because over a long future period, a trend is likely to cease or be supplanted by another trend. Therefore, in making long-term expense projections, actuaries make allowances for inflation and business cycles, or for the possibility that such cycles might be disrupted. For even greater accuracy in estimating future expenses, actuaries can analyze qualitative data such as customer feedback to help decision makers imagine how future events could diverge from established trends.

We discuss incorporating operating expenses into technical product design further in Chapter 9.

 

Cost of Benefits in Product Design

The cost of benefits, sometimes known as the cost of insurance, is the value of the contractually required benefits that a product promises to pay. While benefit expenses are included with other expenses in general accounting, the product design team and actuarial department often need increased granularity, or a finer, point-by-point level of detail. The projected cost of benefits generally equals the sum of each potential benefit payment to a customer multiplied by the expected probability that the benefit will be payable. We can express the projected cost of a single insurance benefit as follows:

EXAMPLE

Projected cost of a single benefit for a given policy year = Potential benefit amount payable × Probability that the benefit will be payable

The death benefit for a specific block of policies is $10,000,000, and the estimated mortality rate for the group of insureds is 5%. Therefore, the projected cost of the block’s death benefits for that year is $10,000,000 x .05 = $500,000.

A single product may offer numerous benefits, and the product’s design must anticipate the costs of each of these benefits throughout the life of the product. The projected cost of all benefits is the sum of the individual benefit costs.

The combinations of benefits differ for various product types, as follows:

  • For life insurance products, the insurer’s benefit obligations for a given policy year are equal to the death benefit amount multiplied by the mortality rate—the rate at which people in a group of insureds die—plus any nonforfeiture benefit and estimated costs associated with available riders.

  • For annuity contracts in the accumulation phase, the main benefit is a contract’s accumulation value. Annuity contracts in the accumulation phase may include surrender charges as well as the costs for any riders elected by the contract owner. For these products, the element of mortality applies to secondary death benefits, such as those provided under a guaranteed minimum death benefit (GMDB) provision.

  • For straight life annuity contracts in the distribution phase, in simple terms, annuity benefits for a given period are equal to the periodic annuity benefit payment multiplied by the annuitant’s probability of living for that period. Other payout options require different approaches for finding the cost of benefits.

Policyholder behavior is a key design consideration for life insurance and annuity products. Recall from Chapter 2 that policyholder behavior refers to the benefit utilization choices of customers who own life insurance or annuities, and policyholder behavior risk refers to the risk that policyholder actions or decisions will adversely affect product performance. For example, more policyholders may stop paying their premiums than the project design team had anticipated for the year. Because circumstances can vary widely from customer to customer and even from month to month, policyholder behavior risks can be difficult to incorporate into deterministic models. However, stochastic product modeling can allow for effective modeling of policyholder behavior when deterministic product modeling is not sufficient.

Some product design features create more policyholder behavior risk than others.

  • Flexible premiums, which allow customers to select the timing and amount of premium payments, can make it harder to predict the timing and amount of premium income.

  • Provisions for surrenders, withdrawals, and lapses may enable customers to terminate or reduce the value of contracts before the insurer has recovered its initial acquisition costs.

  • Options for reinstatement and conversion of life insurance may change the amount of risk the insurer has accepted, and may also change the product mix in force.

  • Secondary guarantees attached to variable annuities generally increase in value as the investments underlying the product decrease in value. We’ll discuss this particular product design risk further in Chapter 11, and general policyholder behavior risk further in Chapter 9.

 

Investment Returns and Interest in Product Design

For fixed and variable products, an insurance company invests premiums in many different assets, such as corporate bonds, government bonds, mortgages, and corporate stocks. The value of these investments can grow substantially over time. Insurers credit investment returns and interest to customer accounts differently, depending on the product, as shown below. We discuss the use of general and separate accounts in more detail in Chapter 7.

 

General Account

Separate Account

Life Insurance

For fixed whole life insurance values and for the fixed funds of variable life insurance, the cash value grows at a guaranteed fixed rate.

For participating policies, the company must pay the guaranteed rate and may also pay a dividend.

For variable subaccount funds, the cash values fully reflect the actual investment results—minus any expense charges—whether increases or decreases.

Annuities

For fixed annuity products and for the fixed funds of variable annuity products, accumulation values grow at a guaranteed minimum crediting rate.

The insurer may credit excess interest to the accounts when investment earnings warrant.

For variable subaccount funds, the accumulation values fully reflect the actual investment results—net of any charges—whether the cash value increases or decreases.

The policyowner may purchase secondary guarantees that apply to the values in the contract.

During technical product design, companies must evaluate what the optimal investment policy for a new product is, and whether that policy is a good fit with the company’s existing investment patterns, currently offered products, and existing investment expertise. If the investment policy is not a good fit, and if the company still wishes to pursue the new product, the company must acquire new competencies, expertise, consulting services, or support software. An insurer must apply particular scrutiny to products that are supported by the general account, for which the insurer has assumed all risk.

For example, new complex design features may require an insurer to use support from hedging programs using investments in derivative securities. As you recall, hedging is an investment strategy that combines different offsetting types of securities in a given investment portfolio in order to reduce the overall riskiness, or volatility, of the portfolio’s asset mix. A derivative security, or derivative, is a financial security, such as a stock option, that derives its value from another security. A hedging program involves hedge costs, which are expenses for trading and holding derivative securities. Hedge costs can magnify the potential profits or losses from a product. For example, a hedge program might have a number of measures in place to control volatility, but in a sufficiently volatile market, the program may make adjustments so frequently that the hedge costs quickly increase. Effective hedging, however, reduces the risks of taking overall losses on products.

 

Premium Structure

Premium structure is a key component of life insurance products’ financial design. A premium structure defines the conditions under which the premium rates for a product may vary from customer to customer, and sets a range for those rates. For example, a premium structure typically requires higher premiums for life insurance policies that have extra benefits, or that are more likely to be paid out sooner. Many companies offer the following variations in premium structures for individual life insurance products:

  • Premium structures may apply different premium rates based on the insured’s risk characteristics. For example, premium rates may vary depending on an insured’s sex, age, and tobacco use behavior. Insurers usually divide these premium rate structures into standard, substandard, and preferred risk classes.

  • An insurer may grade premium rate structures by the policy face amount. In this case, a customer who purchases a high face amount in one policy may pay less in total premiums than would a customer who purchases the same total face amount in multiple policies. In effect, purchasing a high face amount in a single policy is a form of volume discount. This variation is most applicable for term life policies.

  • A contingency pricing structure gives the company mechanisms for adjusting the company’s charges for an in-force product to reflect the company’s financial results for the product. Some insurers use contingency pricing for interest-sensitive whole life products, participating products, and universal life products, as well as for the post-level-term phase in level-premium term life products. Not all insurers use contingency pricing structures.

  • An indeterminate premium structure allows the company to periodically reset premium rates on individual life insurance products while guaranteeing customers that premiums will not exceed a maximum specified level. For these products, the contract language includes a scale of guaranteed maximum premiums. This premium structure allows the company to adjust product charges to reflect the company’s anticipated future interest and mortality experience.

EXAMPLE

Collaboration Life Insurance designed a whole life insurance product with an indeterminate premium structure, and as such charges a “current” premium based on its current assumptions. When Collaboration discovers that the product is underperforming and at risk of not being able to pay out benefits, the company may raise this product’s premium rate. However, Collaboration must adhere to the scale of guaranteed maximum premiums included in the policy contracts.

 

Testing a Product Design

Once an insurer has created a product design, it must test and validate the design. From an actuarial perspective, a product’s design consists of modeling the financial results for one or multiple sets of estimated values and comparing the resulting values to established objectives for the product. The tests typically examine whether the product’s profitability, assets, reserves, and cash flows are adequate. Tests can also examine interest-rate sensitivity as well as other concerns such as surplus strain, which is the decrease in an insurer’s surplus caused by the first-year costs and reserve requirements associated with a new product.

Some product development software packages automatically adjust a product design to meet the stated product objectives. If initial testing of a product design produces unsatisfactory results, actuaries can change some of the assumed values entered into the model—provided the new values are realistic and actuarially sound.

Examples of changes that would ordinarily improve a product model’s profitability, if all other factors remain the same, would be to

  • Decrease benefit costs

  • Increase charges to customers

  • Decrease product expenses

  • Increase assumed investment earnings

The company’s real-world operations must support any design adjustment that an actuary makes to the product design.

EXAMPLE

Countermeasure Life Insurance has two new product designs undergoing adjustment. For the first product, actuaries propose lowering the expense assumptions in the model. Countermeasure’s real-world operations must support this change by finding new, more efficient ways to do business so that actual expenses are reduced.

For the second product, actuaries propose increasing an investment income assumption. Countermeasure must support this assumption by adopting new investment strategies that are likely to produce greater investment income.

As noted above, the adjustments must be realistic in scope. If, for example, a proposal requires a product to lower its expense assumptions beyond what the company’s real-world operations can achieve, the product does not have a realistic probability of earning a profit.

A company may also test a product design using non-actuarial methods, such as marketing the product to a sample group of people to evaluate the possible level of market demand.

 

Budgeting and Scheduling

The budgeting and scheduling process for new products typically consists of (1) preparing a budget for the human, financial, and computer resources needed to implement the product and (2) developing a project schedule.

  • A product development budget is a project planning document that shows the costs, such as staffing requirements, associated with each planned work activity and the anticipated revenue from the new product. The insurer also uses this budget later for monitoring and control.

  • A project schedule is a project planning timetable that shows the times required for the completion of planned tasks and the relationships among these tasks. Creating a project schedule includes identifying which tasks must be completed sequentially and which may be completed concurrently. A product development schedule typically includes very specific technical product design activities, such as drafting initial product specifications, policy forms, policy riders, and any financial exhibits required for initial filing. Certain forms of product management, such as agile product methodology, may not require a fixed project schedule with the same level of detail.

Once the budget and project schedule are complete, the product development team presents the completed product design to decision-makers in the appropriate line of business. This presentation to decision-makers focuses on demonstrating the product design’s capability to meet various company objectives. For example, the team must prove that the proposed pricing structure adequately supports the guarantees the product offers, or that the product will achieve a certain internal rate of return given its capital requirements. The team also must project the capital requirements for the new product. The decision-makers on the executive committee and the heads of the functional areas for the line of business must review and approve further development of the product. The team should demonstrate to the corporate risk committee that the proposed product design fits the company’s risk-return profile and employs appropriate risk management techniques.

pages.contents:
Product Introduction

At product introduction, the company implements the plans and product design and then offers the product for sale. Figure 6.3 illustrates where product introduction fits into the product development cycle.

In this course we break product introduction into two phases: product implementation and product launch. Product implementation consists of establishing the administrative processes necessary to offer the product for sale, while product launch occurs when the company finally offers the product for sale. Many product implementation activities begin as early as the technical product design stage, and occur concurrently through technical product design. Activities necessary for product implementation include

  • Developing standard contract forms and application forms that meet regulatory requirements

  • Obtaining regulatory approval for the product from all appropriate jurisdictions

  • Designing promotional and training materials to support sales activities as well as new business administration and submitting these materials for regulator approval

  • Developing and putting in place all systems needed to market and administer the product

  • Bringing appropriate information systems online, including administrative systems, customer service systems, and self-service systems,

  • Placing approved advertising in appropriate media

  • Distributing press releases and other approved promotional materials

  • Training sales and administrative staff, and disseminating approved training and educational materials

  • Conducting distribution meetings and seminars to introduce the new product to sales, sales support, and customer service staff

In order to speed up the implementation process, companies generally divide product implementation activities into two categories:

  • Day 1 functionality refers to product administration and IT elements that a company must have in place and functioning when the product is first made available for sale. These elements include product illustrations, administration of policy ownership rights that customers can exercise immediately upon issue, premium processing, commission payment, and billing. Day 1 thus refers to the day of product launch.

  • Day 2 functionality refers to product administration and IT elements that are necessary at some future date to service and administer an insurance product, but which can be implemented after the product has been launched. Some typical Day 2 elements are product illustrations based on in force performance, implementation in states where the product was approved after Day 1, and administration of ownership rights that the customer cannot exercise immediately upon policy issue. Day 2 refers to the general period of time after Day 1.

pages.title: Product Monitoring, Evaluation, and Feedback
pages.contents:
Product Monitoring, Evaluation, and Feedback

Insurers are constantly introducing new product ideas into the product development cycle. As a result, they must monitor and evaluate the new products that emerge. In particular, a product’s evaluation continues after a company has introduced it for sale. This activity creates an ongoing feedback process. For example, companies accumulate the actual expense levels the new products generate early in their operation and communicate the emerging data to staff in administrative areas of the company.

Figure 6.4 shows how monitoring, evaluation, and feedback fit into the product development cycle. Note that the feedback from this phase informs the product planning stage for future products, as well as potential refinements for the product being monitored.

The ongoing monitoring, evaluation, and feedback process may result in minor refinements or major innovations. Insurers must track and evaluate the performance of existing products in terms of their impact on the company’s financial performance, the performance of agents and other product distributors, and the marketplace reactions of customers and competitors.

To evaluate a product’s success, companies can monitor the following results:

  • Value and number of contracts sold

  • Actual compared to assumed product profitability

  • Number of new customers

  • Demographic characteristics of purchasers

  • Surrender or withdrawal rates

  • Mortality rates

  • Rates of policy changes such as conversions or reinstatements

  • Sales through various distribution channels or methods

  • Impact of the product on other products—for example, whether product sales augment or replace sales of existing products

Some factors that can contribute to poor sales of a new product include

  • An inadequate compensation structure for sales agents

  • Incorrect interpretation of the needs of the target market

  • Inadequate training of sales agents or customer service representatives about the product

  • Competition from another product offered by the same company or by a competitor

If the results from a product are unsatisfactory, the company has a range of options to explore, from slightly adjusting the product to discontinuing future sales of the product. When modifying a product, an insurer must determine the reasons for the failure of the product. When sales of a new product are poor, a company can take the following corrective actions:

  • Redesigning the product to meet a specific need for customers or sales agents

  • Changing the product’s underwriting guidelines

  • Using a different distribution system

  • Pulling the product from the market while determining how best to service the products already issued

  • Providing additional training for sales agents

Most of these actions require the insurer to rerun financial models to ensure that the changes made are likely to produce the needed results.

EXAMPLE

Example. Traffic Life Insurance released a universal life insurance product that is not performing to the company’s satisfaction. The company considers several possible modifications, such as adding a desirable feature or raising the interest-crediting rate. Traffic decides to offer a new rider and modifies the product accordingly. If the modification does not attract enough additional customers to produce satisfactory results, Traffic will consider another corrective action, such as increasing the interest-crediting rate or discontinuing new sales of the product entirely.

After a company accumulates experience with a product, the company can compare the actual values from experience against the expected (or assumed) values used in product design. The company creates tables of actual and expected values and then conducts actual-to-expected (A/E) analysis for each of many different financial variables—such as the cost of benefits, company expenses, internal rate of return, investment earnings for fixed-rate products, and premium collections.

Note that expected values and assumed values can be different concepts. We discuss the difference between expected mortality values and assumed mortality values in Chapter 8.

Actuarial software can access a company’s product experience data and calculate A/E values for many combinations of data. For example, software can report actual lapses and surrenders according to the reasons for the terminations, and swiftly organize this feedback so that decision-makers can quickly see which reasons for lapses and surrenders are most common.

In comparisons of actual and expected values, a difference between the values is a deviation. Deviations can be favorable or adverse. In product operations, an adverse deviation produces a decrease in actual product profitability compared to assumed product profitability. Any amount included in the assumption values to provide an allowance for unexpected negative outcomes is known as a provision for adverse deviation (PAD). Adverse deviations are the reason for including PADs in a deterministic product design. An adverse deviation arises whenever a specific product result differs from the modeled assumptions so that

  • Product revenue is lower than assumed

  • Benefits payments are greater than assumed

  • Product expenses are greater than assumed

If large adverse deviations develop, then the insurer must try to identify the reasons for them and, if possible, take corrective action, such as cutting operating expenses. If an insurer is able to regularly update the assumptions used to estimate its future policy benefits, there is less need for the estimate to include a PAD.

In product operations, a favorable deviation is a difference between actual and assumed product values that produces an increase in actual product profitability relative to assumed product profitability. A favorable deviation occurs whenever a specific product result differs from the assumptions used in product design so that

  • Product revenue is greater than assumed

  • Benefits payments are lower than assumed

  • Product expenses are lower than assumed

As the term suggests, a favorable deviation requires no corrective action, though further study may indicate ways that future product design can capitalize on such deviations. Note that a reliable A/E analysis requires years of data, which can pose difficulties for insurers; a company may be selling a product for years before reliably learning whether the deviations are favorable or not.

Figure 6.5 summarizes the sources of adverse deviations and favorable deviations in product operations.

  • 7F Explain how actuaries account for cash values and accumulated values in product design

A basic tenet of the life insurance industry is that premium income alone is not sufficient to meet all of a company’s financial needs. If an insurer were to rely only on premium income to pay its expenses and meet its contractual obligations, the premiums for all its products would have to be much higher than they would otherwise be—higher, probably, than most customers would be willing to pay. Instead, an insurer uses the premiums it collects to purchase assets for its investment portfolios, which accumulate value over time. The insurer then uses these assets and their associated earnings to cover the company’s expenses and establish the reserves necessary to meet the company’s contractual obligations.

To properly operate within this financial structure, an insurer must incorporate assumptions about its investment earnings into product development. Actuaries project the potential earnings of various investments over time and compare them to products’ projected liabilities under a variety of conditions to design product features and estimate potential profitability.
