pages.title: Investment Earnings
pages.contents:
Investment Earnings

Most of an insurance company’s investable capital comes from the premiums that the company receives. An insurer typically divides its assets into two main types of accounts: a general account and one or more separate accounts.

All insurers have a general account, also known as a general account portfolio, for assets that support the insurer’s contractual obligations to policyholders and contract owners of the company’s guaranteed products, including whole life insurance, term life insurance, fixed-rate annuities, and other nonvariable products. General account assets also support any guarantees found in variable products. Insurance companies, not policyholders and contract owners, bear the investment risk associated with the general account. To manage this risk and to comply with various regulatory and rating agency requirements, life insurers generally invest the general account in high-quality bonds and other conservative, highly liquid assets. An insurer may manage its general account assets internally, employ a third party to do so, or use a combination of the two approaches. Insurers may also purchase reinsurance on blocks of policies supported by the general account in order to reduce the company’s risk of insolvency.

Insurers that offer variable products maintain one or more separate accounts, also known as separate account portfolios or segregated funds portfolios, for assets that support such products as variable life insurance and variable annuities. A company typically divides separate accounts into smaller subaccounts, each of which consists of a pool of investments with a distinct risk-return profile, usually known as a fund style. Unlike the general account, separate account subaccounts may contain more equity securities, such as stocks, than debt securities, such as bonds and mortgages.

The customer, rather than the insurer, determines how premiums are applied to subaccounts. The customer also bears the investment risks associated with a variable product that is funded by a separate account. While some of the fund styles available to customers are conservative, insurers design separate accounts with an overall higher risk appetite than the risk appetite they assign to the general account. The insurer manages the purchase and sale of assets in the subaccounts according to the customer’s allocation choices and covers the expenses incurred for designing, distributing, and administering the variable products through explicit fees and charges.

 

Price Appreciation

Changes in the value of invested assets are the result of gains or losses. An investor realizes a gain when an asset’s selling price is higher than the asset’s price at purchase. Gains generally result from price appreciation, which is an increase in the market value of an invested asset. Conversely, losses occur when an asset’s selling price is lower than the asset’s price when originally purchased. These losses generally result from price depreciation, which is a decrease in the market value of an invested asset.

 

Income Payments

Insurers receive payments of interest, dividends, or rental income from certain investments.

  • Interest is a fee that an institution, such as a bank or government, pays for the use of money. An investment that pays simple interest pays interest only on the principal. Many bonds pay simple interest. In many situations, the interest on loans and other investments is compound interest, which occurs when an investment pays interest on both the principal and on the interest earnings that the investment accumulates. When an insurer reinvests the interest payments it receives from an investment that pays simple interest, the insurer can compound the interest. Because interest is a steady and reliable source of income, insurers invest heavily in interest-bearing investments such as bonds and mortgages. We’ll discuss factors specific to interest earnings in more detail later in this chapter.

  • An insurer typically receives dividends when the insurer holds stock in a company and the company pays a share of its profits to its stockholders. The insurer receives dividend income for holding on to stock, as opposed to capital gains, which the insurer receives for selling stock for a price higher than it paid for the stock.

  • An insurer may receive rental income for the use of any real estate the insurer owns. Compared to most stocks and bonds, real estate is relatively illiquid. So, although an insurer may have investments in commercial real estate, especially as part of the general account, these investments are usually a smaller portion of the insurer’s invested assets.

When investment earnings are expressed as a percentage of the principal, they are called the rate of return on the investment. If an asset earns more than one form of earnings, the total rate of return is determined by summing all of the earnings and dividing by the principal. Note that the total return on an investment is the sum of all the investment’s earnings.

Oceanic Life Insurance purchases $100,000 worth of stock in the Puffin Corporation. Oceanic holds the stock for a year, over which time the company earns $5,000 in dividends from the stock. At the end of the year, Oceanic sells the stock for $110,000. Because the sales price is higher than the purchase price, Oceanic earns a gain. The total return on the investment, therefore, is the sum of Oceanic’s dividend earnings of $5,000 and its $10,000 gain upon the sale of the stock ($110,000 – $100,000). The investment’s total rate of return is the total earnings of $15,000 expressed as a percentage of the stock’s purchase price of $100,000, or 15% ($15,000 ÷ $100,000 = 0.15).

 

The Time Value of Money

Investment growth is based on a concept known as the time value of money, which states that the value of a sum of money changes over time as a result of the effects of interest. This chapter’s discussion of the time value of money refers specifically to interest earnings. The time value of money concept also assumes that interest earnings are positive. According to this concept, a sum of money received in the present is worth more than the same sum of money received in the future—because the sum of money received in the present will be invested and earn interest.

Oceanic Life Insurance was given the option of receiving $100,000 now, or receiving $100,000 one year in the future. As we’ve seen, when Oceanic invested $100,000 for one year, it earned an additional $5,000 in dividends. The $100,000 sum of money, properly invested, was worth $105,000 after one year even before Oceanic sold the investment and received capital gains. Therefore, the $100,000 sum, received now, is worth more than the $100,000 sum received one year from now, because a sum received now can potentially gain an additional year of earnings.

We generally express the effects of the time value of money by calculating one of two values:

  • The future value (FV) of a sum of money is the amount that the original sum is expected to be worth at a specified future date, given a specified interest rate. Future value calculations are useful when an insurer knows the specific sum it intends to invest and needs to know how much the investment is likely to earn. When calculating future value, each period that interest is paid is known as a compounding period.

  • The present value (PV) of a sum of money is the amount that, if invested at a specified interest rate on a specified date, would grow to equal a specified future amount. Present value calculations are useful when an insurer has identified a specific sum as a future goal and needs to know how much to invest to achieve that goal. Each period used in present value calculations is known as a discounting period.

In simple terms, the present value is the principal of an investment, and the future value is the principal plus accumulated earnings. Because we are assuming that interest is always positive, the future value of a principal sum invested at interest is always greater than the sum’s present value, because future value takes into account the interest earned. Present value and future value calculations also assume compound interest, which is why compounding periods and discounting periods are relevant. For examples of a few general rules that govern the present value and future value of a sum invested at interest, watch Video 7.1.

While actuaries are capable of calculating future value and present value by hand, in practice they, like most people, typically use financial calculators and computers to speed up the calculations. During product design, an insurer must test numerous variables and combinations of variables for every potential product: possible interest rates, the number of compounding or discounting periods, regular and irregular streams of payments, and so on. An in-depth presentation of the various calculations used is beyond the scope of this course. However, the basic principles behind these calculations are helpful for understanding how quickly or slowly a given investment’s earnings are likely to grow. If you would like to refresh your knowledge of these calculations, please complete the Time Value of Money course on the LOMA 371 portal.

 

Future Value

The most basic future value calculation is determining the future value of a single amount for one period, which is equal to the principal plus the interest earned for one period. Analysts typically substitute present value for principal because, like principal, present value represents a sum of money before it earns interest.

Future Value (FV) = Present Value (PV) + Interest earned

For a one-year period, the amount of interest earned is equal to the present value multiplied by the interest rate, i.

Interest earned = PV × i

Incorporating the formula for interest into the basic future value formula results in the following equation:

FV = PV + Interest Earned
FV = PV + (PV × i)
FV = PV × (1 + i)

So, to determine the future value of a single amount for one period, we simply multiply the principal by (1 + i).

Amara plans to invest $1,000 at a 5% interest rate for one year. To determine the future value of her investment, she performs the following calculation:

FV = PV × (1 + i)
$1,050 = $1,000 × 1.05
$1,050 = $1,000 × 1.05

Insurers often calculate the future value of a single amount over multiple periods—as with a single-premium life insurance or annuity product. In this situation, the investment will pay interest on both the principal and the accumulated interest each period, thus increasing the amount of the interest paid. The present value is multiplied by (1 + i) one time for each interest period (n) in which interest is applied.

FV = PV × (1 + i) n

To simplify these calculations, analysts use future value interest factors and future value interest factor tables. A future value interest factor (FVIF) is the future value of $1.00 at a given interest rate for a stated number of periods. We express the FVIF for a specified interest period, n, and a specified interest rate, i, as FVIF(n, i). A table that lists future value interest factors is called a future value interest factors (FVIF) table. For example, all other factors being equal, a four-year investment with six-month compounding periods will earn more than a four-year investment with one-year compounding periods. By using software or dedicated financial calculators, we can calculate a future value quickly by inputting the amount of principal, the interest rate per period, and the number of compounding periods. In recent years, many websites and mobile applications have made specialized financial calculators freely available to the general public as well.

For some situations, insurers must also calculate the future value of a series of payments. Financial analysts refer to any series of equal payments made at regular intervals over a specified time period as an annuity, a definition that includes both the payments an insurer makes to contract owners and the premiums contract owners pay to the insurer. The future value of an annuity at any given future date is the amount that a series of equal payments earning compound interest will accumulate by that date.

The future value of an annuity is a more complicated calculation than calculating the future value of a single amount because each payment in the series will earn a different amount of interest. In addition, the amount of payments that earn interest varies between an ordinary annuity and an annuity due, because of the difference in the timing of the payments.

  • An ordinary annuity is a series of equal periodic payments for which the payment occurs at the end of each specified payment period. Two examples of an ordinary annuity are an employee’s paycheck paid at the end of each work period and a bond interest payment received one period after the bond is issued. When calculating the future value of an ordinary annuity, the final payment earns no interest because it is paid at the end of the last compounding period.

  • An annuity due is a series of equal periodic payments for which the payment occurs at the beginning of each specified payment period. Two examples of an annuity due are a series of rent payments and a level series of whole life insurance premiums. When calculating the future value of an annuity due, all payments, including the final payment, earn interest for at least one compounding period.

Figure 7.1 illustrates an ordinary annuity and an annuity due, and the effects of interest on each.

Analysts can use compound value interest factors to simplify these calculations, just as they use FVIFs to simplify other future value calculations. These interest factors, called future value interest factors for an annuity (FVIFAs), represent the future value of a $1.00 annuity at a given rate of interest for a certain number of periods. A future value interest factors for an annuity (FVIFA) table lists values of FVIFAs for varying interest rates and interest compounding periods.

Calculating the future value of a sum of money is a critical part of designing annuities, cash value life insurance, and other such products. Insurer applications for calculating the future value of a sum of money include

  • Matching projected earnings with projected liabilities. The most basic use of future values is estimating the amount of earnings from investments a company will have as its liabilities come due. Because life insurance contracts can be in force for decades, insurers in particular must plan their investments over the long term. This practice is critical for ALM.

  • Projecting benefits for products that credit an interest rate to customers. If an insurer offers products that allow customers to earn interest, future value calculations help estimate the total amount of benefits the insurer is likely to pay on these products.

  • Calculating cash values. As we’ll discuss later in this chapter, one way to determine the cash value of a product involves calculating the future value of past premiums and benefits.

  • Tracking investment performance. Calculating future values creates a performance target, which can be compared to actual performance over time. For example, calculating the future value of an investment at regular one-year intervals can help an insurer review the investment’s performance each year and determine if it is still likely to meet its long-term goals.

  • Projecting the future value of premium payments. An insurer can use future value calculations to determine what the total value of a series of premium payments would be when invested at interest.

 

Present Value

Future value calculations help determine the likely result of investing a known principal, or present value, in a specific investment. By comparison, present value calculations are useful for determining the likely amount of principal needed for an investment to reach a specific goal. In other words, future value calculations start with a stated principal and work forward to the result, whereas present value calculations start with a stated goal and work backwards to the principal.

Vigorous Life Insurance intends to repay a $500,000 loan at the end of three years, and it has found an investment to help with this repayment. By inputting the investment’s interest rates and discounting periods, Vigorous can calculate the present value of the $500,000 sum—the future value—to determine how much to invest to reach the goal on schedule.

The basic calculation for present value involves multiplying the future value (or desired goal) by 1 divided by the sum of 1 + the interest rate (often represented as ). We record the basic calculation for present value as follows:

PV = FV × 

Insurers can use this calculation as the basis for determining present values for a single amount over one or more periods or for an annuity. As with future values, actuaries use financial calculators or software to find the values quickly.

Vigorous has chosen an investment with 4% interest, compounded annually. Because Vigorous knows the future value of $500,000, the number of discounting periods (three), and the interest rate of 4%, the insurer performs the following calculation:

$500,000 × () 3  = present value
$500,000 ×  ×  ×  = present value
$500,000 × 0.8890 = $444,500

Therefore, with a 4% interest rate, Vigorous would have to invest a principal amount of $444,500 now to receive $500,000 in three years.

As when calculating future value, software and financial calculators are common tools for determining the present value for single amounts or annuities. Present value interest factors and present value interest factor tables are also available, both separately and incorporated into such electronic tools. A present value interest factor (PVIF) is the present value of $1.00 discounted at a given interest rate for a stated number of periods. As with FVIFs, we express the PVIF for a specified interest period, n, and a specified interest rate, i, as PVIF(n, i). Actuaries also make use of present value interest factors for annuities (PVIFAs) and present value interest factor for annuities tables (PVIFA tables). Possible applications for calculating the present value of a sum of money include the following:

  • Setting premium rates. If a product such as an annuity offers to make specific payments to the contract owner in the future, calculating the present value of those payments is essential in determining how much the contract owner must pay in premiums, which provide the sum to be invested.

  • Developing an investment budget. By calculating the most likely sum of money to invest to reach a target goal, a company can avoid investing an inadequate amount to reach the target, or investing more than is necessary.

  • Calculating cash values. As we’ll discuss later in this chapter, another way to determine a product’s cash value is by calculating the present value of a product’s future benefits and premiums.

  • Measuring profitability. As we’ll explore later in this chapter, present value calculations are fundamental to measuring profitability using a product’s net present value or profit margin.

pages.title: Crediting Rates and Interest Spreads
pages.contents:
Crediting Rates and Interest Spreads

As noted earlier, an insurer gains much of its investment earnings in the form of interest. In addition to calculating how much interest they will earn on their investments, insurers also need to determine how much interest to credit to customers who own certain products.

Therefore, interest rates affect both how much money an insurer expects to receive from its customers and how much it expects to pay to its customers. The relationship between the amount of interest received and the amount of interest paid out is critical to a profitable product design, as we’ll explore.

The interest rate credited to products on behalf of customers is called the interest-crediting rate, or crediting rate. For certain products, insurers may also declare more specific interest-crediting rates:

  • A minimum guaranteed interest-crediting rate is the minimum rate the insurer must pay on the contract’s accumulated value. This rate commonly ranges from 1-3%.

  • Most contracts also provide for a higher interest rate known as a current interest-crediting rate, which is the rate the insurer declares and pays. In general, companies offer higher current interest rates for longer interest-crediting periods, and they set a new current interest rate at the end of the current interest-crediting period based on current market conditions. The new current rate can be higher or lower than the previous current rate, but it can never be lower than the guaranteed interest-crediting rate.

When market interest rates change, their relationship to a product’s crediting rate affects the product’s interest spread. The interest spread, also known as the interest margin or interest-rate margin, is the difference between the rate of return an insurer earns on its investments and the interest-crediting rate. The interest spread is one measure of a product’s potential rate of return; the higher the interest spread, the more profitable the product is likely to be. The formula for the interest spread is as follows:

Interest spread = Interest rate earned – Interest-crediting rate

So how do insurers determine the interest-crediting rate for a product? Generally speaking, the interest rate used in the product design is known as the interest-rate assumption or the assumed interest rate. The insurer projects an expected interest rate on the product’s associated investments and sets a lower assumed interest rate in order to earn an expected level of profit on the product. We can express this relationship as follows:

Expected profit margin = Expected interest rate – Assumed interest rate

During product design, the insurer must set a premium amount that, along with investment earnings, will produce enough money to cover the cost of promised benefits when due. Present value calculations are vital to this process, as is the insurer’s understanding of customer needs. If the premium amount is too low, the investment earnings could be inadequate to pay the product’s benefits, or they could provide an insufficient profit. If the premium amount is too high, it may be difficult to sell the product.

For some products, such as fixed universal life insurance, insurers periodically declare a crediting rate and apply it to the product’s cash value. For example, an insurer may credit the cash value of a fixed universal life policy with interest once each month, and declare a new crediting rate, if appropriate, once a year. To provide for an acceptable overall level of profit, insurers can use a product design that provides for a small interest spread but possibly a larger spread for expenses or mortality.

 

Life Insurance Products and Cash Values

Permanent life insurance products are often referred to as cash value insurance products because they offer the additional feature of equity in the form of a cash value, which contract owners can access in the form of policy loans, withdrawal and surrender benefits, or nonforfeiture benefits. The general account generally funds a product’s cash value if the product is a fixed contract—which typically guarantees a minimum interest rate and the contract’s investment principal. If the product is a variable contract, the insurer’s separate account funds the cash value, as we’ll discuss later in this chapter.

 

Fixed Life Insurance Products

Insurers set a cash value for fixed life insurance products based on the amount of premiums paid on the policy, the face amount of the policy, and the amount of time the policy has been in force. Insurers can use either prospective or retrospective valuation methods to calculate this cash value. The great majority of insurers use the prospective valuation method, which looks at a product’s future cash flows—that is, its future benefits and future premiums. The prospective valuation formula for determining the cash value of a fixed life insurance product is as follows:

Cash value = Present value of future benefits – Present value of future premiums

In effect, the prospective valuation method depends on deriving the present value of future sums. By contrast, a retrospective valuation method looks at a product’s past cash flows. This method uses future value, or accumulated value, techniques to base cash value on past performance. Though prospective and retrospective valuation both arrive at the same cash values, regulations require most insurers to use prospective valuation for new products.

 

Other Product Forms

The formulas for fixed products do not readily apply to flexible-premium life products, universal life products, or variable life products. For these forms of life insurance, an insurer calculates cash value by subtracting the remaining unamortized first-year expenses from the policy’s account value, as shown:

Cash value = Account value – Remaining unamortized first-year expenses

In effect, the cash value is essentially the value of the account once all first-year expenses have been paid.

 

Annuity Products and Investment Earnings

A deferred annuity—whether fixed or variable—generally has an accumulation phase during which the insurer collects and invests premiums paid by the contract owner, and the invested premiums accumulate earnings. (Fixed indexed annuities operate differently; we will discuss the design of these annuities further in Chapter Eleven.) The total amount of premiums and earnings under the deferred annuity contract, less the amount of any withdrawals and charges assessed by the insurer, is the accumulated value, or account value. Like the cash value of a life insurance policy, the accumulated value represents the owner’s equity in the contract. However, while a life insurance policy’s cash value is generally separate from the policy’s face amount, the accumulated value represents the current value of the annuity contract. How an insurer incorporates investment earnings into an annuity contract depends on whether the contract is fixed or variable.

 

Fixed-Rate Deferred Annuities

Fixed-rate deferred annuities accumulate value through interest. The insurer applies the current interest-crediting rate to annuity contract values to determine the accumulated value.

 

Variable Deferred Annuities

When contract owners pay premiums into a variable deferred annuity, they specify how they wish their premiums to be invested. Most insurers offer both fixed accounts, which are guaranteed, and variable subaccounts, which are nonguaranteed but have a higher potential for gain.

Fixed Accounts in Variable Annuities

The fixed account directs premium payments to the insurer’s general account. If the contract specifies a current interest-crediting rate, the insurer credits interest to the contract using that rate. Otherwise the insurer credits the contract with the guaranteed interest-crediting rate. As with other general account investments, the insurer bears all the investment risk for money in the fixed account, and is responsible for any losses that occur if market rates fall below the interest rate needed to support the credited rate. In general, customers place a relatively small portion of their premium into a fixed fund.

Subaccounts in Variable Annuities

The insurer uses premiums allocated to subaccounts to purchase accumulation units, which represent ownership shares in the selected subaccounts. The amount of return each subaccount earns is equal to the market return on the subaccount investments, less investment management fees, mortality and expense (M&E) risk charges, administrative expense charges, and any other charges that the insurer assesses. The value of a contract owner’s accumulation units is not guaranteed. Accumulation units increase or decrease in value based on the performance of subaccount investments. Regardless of market conditions, the number of accumulation units still increases as the contract owner pays more premiums, which are used to purchase more units.

The accumulated value of a variable annuity contract is determined by the current value and number of accumulation units the contract owner has in each subaccount investment. Interest-Rate Risk

Recall from Chapter 2 that changes in market interest rates cause the value of investments to change. These changes also affect the interest spread on products that offer interest-crediting rates. Here we’ll examine the risks that accompany increases or decreases in market interest rates, as well as the risks associated with market interest rates remaining flat over an extended period of time.

One factor that recently affected insurers’ vulnerability to interest-rate risk is the environmental shift away from predictable rise-and-fall cycles for market interest rates. When market interest rates fell, many insurers assumed that they would rise again in the near future, and priced products accordingly. When market interest rates failed to rise as expected, or fell even further, many long-term life insurance and annuity products performed far below the insurers’ expectations.

 

Increases in Market Interest Rates

Recall that when market interest rates increase, insurers can be adversely affected. For instance, an insurer would have difficulty selling its existing bonds, which have lower interest rates than the market, unless the insurer was willing to accept a loss by selling the bonds at a discount. These potential negative effects are a result of various market risks such as interest-rate risk and reinvestment-rate risk.

One significant impact that rising market interest rates may have on an insurer is that the insurer’s interest spread may narrow. When an insurer’s interest spread narrows, we refer to the phenomenon as spread compression. Spread compression typically occurs in an increasing interest-rate environment when customers immediately demand the higher market interest rate. At the same time, the average rate of return on the insurer’s existing invested assets rises only slowly, because these assets continue to earn the lower interest rates that were available in the financial markets when the insurer purchased the assets.

Spread compression does not occur automatically when market rates are increasing, because an insurer can offer lower interest rates to keep its spread constant. However, if an insurer chooses to keep its spread constant by refusing to offer customers the higher market interest rate, existing customers are less likely to continue business with the insurer, and new customers may be harder to attract. Insurers may have to choose between (1) increasing their current interest-crediting rates and accepting a lower interest spread in an effort to retain their customers’ business, (2) leaving their current interest-crediting rates at lower levels so as to avoid a lower-than-acceptable interest spread, or (3) finding a course of action somewhere between the two. A product design can include elements such as surrender charges to offset some of this risk; we discuss these elements further in Chapter 9.

When the Fluorite Life Insurance Company priced its fixed deferred annuity product, it determined that it needed a 1.5% interest spread in order to meet its goals. When Fluorite issued the contracts, it was earning 4.5% interest on the investments supporting this product. Therefore, Fluorite set the initial interest-crediting rate at 3% (4.5% earned rate – 1.5% interest spread).

Two years later, market interest rates had increased by 1%. Some of Fluorite’s competitors were now crediting 3.5% interest on their fixed deferred annuities. Fluorite had to decide whether to increase its rates to match its competitors. Fluorite was still earning 4.5% on the investments supporting its fixed deferred annuity product. If it raised its interest-crediting rate to 3.5%, the company would face a reduced interest spread of 1% (4.5% earned rate – 3.5% credited rate). This reduced spread would be lower than the spread Fluorite needed to meet its profit target.

In addition, when market interest rates increase, new interest-bearing investments in the general account earn the higher market rate. An insurer with capital available to invest in new interest-bearing securities has the opportunity to make more profitable investments in a high-interest environment.

If Fluorite had the capital to invest in new securities after market rates had risen by 1%, the company could purchase investments bearing a 5.5% interest rate for prices comparable to what the company paid two years ago for its investments bearing a 4.5% interest rate.

Figure 7.2 summarizes the potential effects of increases in market interest rates.

 

Decreases in Market Interest Rates

When market interest rates decrease, the price of existing interest-bearing investments increases. If an insurer purchased bonds during a period of higher interest rates, the insurer can sell these bonds before maturity for a higher price, and such bonds held in the insurer’s general account increase in market value.

Low interest rates strongly benefit borrowers. In a low interest rate environment, borrowers pay less overall interest on new loans. However, this means that lenders have more difficulty in a low interest rate environment. In such an environment, interest-bearing investments have a much lower rate of return over time. Thus, insurers cannot rely as heavily on investments to ensure their solvency, and they must consider raising prices or fees, adjusting rates, reducing operating expenses, or other such measures to compensate for lost investment income.

For these reasons, when market interest rates are decreasing, one potential negative outcome for insurers is that their liabilities may lengthen. Liabilities lengthen when fixed-rate products, such as fixed deferred annuities, remain in force for longer than the insurer assumed, because the company’s current interest-crediting rate is higher than market interest rates. When a liability is in force longer than the insurer had anticipated, the insurer’s assets are less likely to match the liability throughout the increased period.

Fluorite’s fixed deferred annuity products provide a current interest-crediting rate of 3%. When market interest rates fell to 2%, customers held on to these annuity products because they were receiving a return greater than the market was currently yielding. Therefore, Fluorite may have more liabilities than the company had anticipated, and may not have sufficient assets to adequately cover these liabilities over time.

When market interest rates are decreasing, companies can experience spread compression or spread expansion. The results depend on the company’s actions and its existing investments; an insurer might experience spread compression on some products and spread expansion on others.

Spread expansion is the widening of an insurer’s interest spread. Spread expansion typically occurs when market interest rates fall, but the insurer has investments that still earn interest at a higher rate. The insurer therefore can choose to reduce its interest-crediting rates to match the market interest rates.

One of Fluorite’s products is supported by invested assets earning 4.5% interest. Previously, Fluorite had set the product’s interest-crediting rate at 3%, in order to earn a 1.5% interest spread. When market interest rates fell by 1%, Fluorite chose to lower the product’s interest-crediting rate to 2%. The interest spread on that product then rose to 2.5% (4.5% interest earned – 2% interest-crediting rate = 2.5% interest spread).

While decreasing interest rates create the opportunity for spread expansion, they do not guarantee it. Borrowers who are paying older and higher interest rates may choose to repay their debts in full before repayment is due. Those same borrowers can usually refinance—that is, make new borrowing arrangements at the new lower prevailing interest rates. In such a situation, the insurer would lose the higher-yielding older assets. This circumstance would cause spread compression on life insurance and annuity products with long-term guarantees. To avoid spread compression during periods of decreasing market interest rates, insurers typically match their products having long-term guarantees with assets that are unlikely to be refinanced. For example, the issuer of a noncallable bond cannot redeem the bond early without paying a penalty, which makes noncallable bonds a prudent match for products with long-term guarantees.

Another of Fluorite’s products is supported by invested assets that provided a return of 4% interest. Fluorite had set the interest-crediting rate on this product to 2% to earn a 2% interest spread. When market interest rates fell by 1%, the borrower chose to repay Fluorite in full. Without the additional income from steady interest, Fluorite was required to make a new investment to support the product. Because market interest rates were generally lower, the best investment for the product that Fluorite could find paid 2.5% interest. This product’s spread therefore fell to 0.5% (2.5% interest earned – 2% interest-crediting rate = 0.5% interest spread).

Figure 7.3 summarizes the potential effects of decreases in market interest rates.

 

Sustained Low Market Interest Rates

While many risks take the form of unexpected changes, in some cases the risk is that an environmental factor will remain the same when change is expected. One such risk is that market interest rates will remain level at a low rate rather than increasing as expected. This risk has proven very relevant to financial services companies in recent years. Much of the global economy has seen a sustained low interest rate environment since the financial crisis of 2008. Such an environment causes significant challenges for insurance companies.

The risks inherent in an environment where market interest rates remain low are similar to the risks inherent in decreasing market interest rates. In particular, spread compression is a common occurrence when market interest rates fail to rise as anticipated.

A critical risk associated with ongoing low market interest rates is that a company does not successfully plan for the possibility that interest rates do not rise. Companies that rely too strongly on historical data to guide their interest rate assumptions face the greatest challenge when interest rates fail to rise according to past precedent. In such a case, an insurer may have invested resources in developing a product that is not priced to be profitable in the current market, even though it would have been profitable in the market the insurer had anticipated.

The long-term nature of life insurance and annuity products means that even the most prudent insurer is at some risk during sustained periods of low market interest rates. An insurer may still be contractually bound by products designed and sold ten, twenty, thirty, or more years ago. In addition, insurers traditionally hold bonds and other debt securities to maturity. This practice is more conservative than selling before maturity in the assumption that market interest rates will fall, and therefore mitigates some risk. However, this practice also prevents the insurer from mitigating potential losses if market interest rates are low at the time the security matures.

 

Strategies for Managing Interest-Rate Risk

To manage interest-rate risk associated with the general account, life insurance companies rely on a simple control cycle. The typical control cycle consists of three specific types of controls:

  • Steering controls are established in advance and describe the company’s expectations of performance. Examples include policies, procedures, risk tolerances, and codes of conduct. A typical steering control for interest-rate risk is the initial interest-crediting rate on a product.

  • Concurrent controls address a company’s current activities by continuously monitoring them. A typical example of a concurrent control is the automatic checks in a system.

  • Feedback controls compare actual performance or output with established standards, typically at the end of a measurement period. A typical example of a feedback control is an internal audit.

As with other control cycles used in a company, a robust risk management cycle begins with appropriate policies, procedures, and standards. Some methods of managing interest-rate risk can be implemented during product design. Examples include

  • Employing floating interest rates for policy loans

  • Incorporating nonguaranteed elements in product design, such as policy dividends on participating fixed premium life insurance policies

  • Designing a lower minimum guaranteed interest-crediting rate, where regulations permit

  • Shortening the guarantee period for minimum guaranteed interest-crediting rates

Concurrent and feedback controls ensure adherence to the policies, procedures, and standards set as steering controls. External and internal audits are valuable tools for this purpose. ALM programs such as those described in Chapter 3 are also essential for managing interest-rate risk. The following insight discusses one way that insurers can manage risk by anticipating changes in interest rates.

INSIGHT

Economic Scenario Generators

A common tool for modeling changes in interest rates is an economic scenario generator (ESG), which is a software program that models economic environments based on the behavior of financial market values and economic variables. Life insurers primarily use economic scenario generators to model

  • Potential interactions between interest rate changes and policyowner behavior such as lapses and policy loans
  • The interaction of investment performance on assets built up from the collection of premiums
  • The payout of liabilities based on mortality or policy surrender

The Society of Actuaries and the American Academy of Actuaries manage ESGs used in regulatory reserve and capital calculations. These generators, such as the Academy Interest Rate Generator (AIRG), are available to insurers for their own use, although many insurers prefer to use these tools to supplement their own proprietary models. By anticipating potential long-term changes—or lack of changes—in market interest rates, insurers can be better prepared to manage the risks inherent in increases, decreases, or stagnation in market interest rates.

Companies can take a number of corrective actions to address potential deviations from the company’s interest-rate risk standards. These corrective actions include

  • Specifying the interest-rate characteristics of new purchases of bonds and mortgages

  • Decreasing current interest-crediting rates within allowable limits

  • Directing changes in nonguaranteed elements or other product features that render a given interest-rate condition risky

  • Offsetting specified interest-rate risks with purchases of derivative securities

Ultimately, insurers must use a wide variety of controls to manage interest-rate risk, with the understanding that market interest rates are beyond an insurer’s control. Similar controls are useful in managing mortality risk, as we’ll explore in a later chapter.

Measuring Product Profitability

The actuarial techniques that estimate a product’s potential earnings—and therefore inform technical product design—are also useful for determining a product’s actual earnings. Once an insurer releases a product, it can use present value calculations to model how profitable the product has become. To be successful, a new product must generate at least enough money to cover the product’s initial investment, or the amount of capital that an insurer must invest to establish the product. This investment includes the insurer’s costs of developing, pricing, and marketing the product; its costs of establishing reserves and administrative processes for the product; and its costs of issuing and underwriting contracts and compensating sales agents.

A company generally measures profits for a new product in terms of either the net cash flow or the earnings that the new product is expected to generate.

  • Net cash flow is a product’s total cash inflows generated from premiums, investments, and other sources, minus the total cash outflows generated by such items as commissions, expenses, and benefit payments. Net cash flow focuses only on cash. Because initial product sales generally are not high enough to recover all the costs associated with the initial investment, an insurance product’s first-year net cash flow is typically negative.

  • Earnings for a product are the amount that the product adds to the insurance company’s capital in a given period. Unlike net cash flow, earnings reflect noncash adjustments that figure into a product’s contribution to capital.

Like other companies, insurers typically use several tools for evaluating product profitability, such as net present value (NPV), internal rate of return (IRR), and profit margin. Note that because insurers typically perform these calculations at the beginning of a product’s life, the profitability evaluations are estimates and targets rather than certainties.

 

Net Present Value

An insurer calculates the net present value (NPV) of an investment project by subtracting the project’s initial investment from the present value of the product’s earnings over a certain period, usually the entire expected life of the product, as follows:

NPV = PV of earnings – Initial investment

If NPV is a positive number, then the product is expected to earn a profit as long as the assumptions are accurate. The general rule for NPV is that as long as a proposed product’s NPV is positive, the insurer should consider pursuing the product.

The NPV approach uses present value calculations. When calculating the PV of earnings, an insurer selects an interest rate, i, that reflects the return the company believes would be necessary to accept the risk inherent in the product. So, for instance, if an insurer selects a 10 percent interest rate, the company has decided it is willing to accept the risk the new product represents as long as the product’s estimated return over the period is at least 10 percent. Insurers generally select lower interest rates for products that represent lower risks and higher interest rates for products that represent higher risks, with a general eye towards conservatism.

The insight below demonstrates how changes in interest rates affect NPV.

INSIGHT

Internal Rate of Return

When selecting an interest rate to calculate the present value of earnings, a company typically considers the internal rate of return in conjunction with NPV. The internal rate of return (IRR) is the interest rate, i, at which the product’s net cash flows must be discounted, using present value techniques, in order to exactly repay the insurer’s initial investment in the product. In other words, the IRR for a product is the interest rate at which the product’s PV of earnings is equal to its initial investment, and its NPV is equal to zero. Some insurers refer to the IRR as the return on investment (ROI).

Using present value calculators, employees of Amaranth Life Insurance determined that the NPV for its proposed new product would be equal to zero when the interest rate is 8.54 percent. Therefore, the projected IRR for the product is 8.54 percent.

An insurer can instead use the company’s hurdle rate as its required IRR. A hurdle rate, or required return, is a minimum percentage rate of return on capital that an insurer must earn to cover its cost of capital. From an insurer’s perspective, cost of capital is the overall percentage cost the insurer pays for the funds it employs. Although the methods used to calculate the cost of capital vary, they generally involve a combination of the various interest costs, transaction costs, and cost of equity an insurer pays for funds. An insurer’s hurdle rate, which is independent of product risk, typically applies to all products and all lines of business.

IRR is not suited for making subtle distinctions, because it relies on a large number of assumptions such as whether or not assets can be reinvested at comparable interest rates. Moreover, IRR does not automatically incorporate the risk involved with a given product. Insurers wishing to take into consideration the level of risk in a product’s cash flows can set a risk-adjusted minimum IRR for a product and then compare the product’s projected IRR to the risk-adjusted minimum IRR.

Whether a product’s projected IRR is acceptable for the level of risk it represents depends on the decision rule the insurer establishes. A simple decision rule is to require that the projected IRR be equal or greater to the insurer’s risk-adjusted minimum IRR for the product. Therefore, if the projected IRR is less than the risk-adjusted minimum IRR, then the insurer will likely not proceed with developing the product as is. We can summarize this rule as follows:

ACCEPT if Projected IRR ≥ Risk-adjusted minimum IRR

REJECT if Projected IRR < Risk-adjusted minimum IRR

After taking into account the level of risk in their new product’s cash flows, Amaranth determined that the risk-adjusted minimum IRR for its new product would be 9.50 percent. Because the product’s projected IRR of 8.54 is less than this number, the product’s current design would likely not be profitable. Amaranth decides to make changes to the product design before pursuing further development.

 

Profit Margin

Profit margin in a general business sense is very different from interest margin. We calculate interest margin via subtraction, but the profit margin is the ratio of profits to sales revenue.

Profit margin =

For a life insurance or annuity product, profit is equal to the product’s net cash flow, adjusted for investment earnings and reserves. Sales revenues for an insurance product are represented by premiums. Because cash flows and premiums are generated over many years, an insurer must use present value calculations to determine profit margin.

Therefore, for a multiple-premium life insurance or annuity product, profit margin is the present value of profits divided by the present value of premiums, as shown:

Profit margin =

When calculating the PV of profits and premiums to determine profit margin, an insurer usually sets the interest rate equal to the rate of return the insurer earns or expects to earn on the invested assets that support the product. Once a company has calculated the projected profit margin for a product, it compares the projected profit margin to the company’s target for profit margin. For instance, a company might require a product to have a minimum profit margin of 7 percent. For an example of calculating the profit margin for a deferred annuity product, watch Video 7.2.

  2. A person who has been recently underwritten for a life insurance policy will generally live longer than a person who has not been recently underwritten for a policy.

Check your answer

The cost of benefits is a vital element of product design for both life insurance and annuities. To estimate the amount and timing of future benefit payments as accurately as possible, an insurer must make assumptions regarding mortality. Mortality affects the timing and amount of benefit payments in a variety of ways:

  • For life insurance policies, mortality determines when an insurer must make benefit payments. Insurers project death benefits using historical mortality data to estimate the pattern of deaths in an insured group. They also project life insurance terminations for causes other than death using historical lapse data.

  • For annuities in the accumulation phase, contract terminations from all causes are an important influence on the cost of benefits. In general, the effect of mortality on the cost of benefits is limited to any account values payable on the death of the contract owner. Mortality estimates affect the payout factors guaranteed in the contract and also affect the pricing of death benefit options under optional rider benefits and guaranteed death benefits.

  • For life annuities in the payout phase, calculating mortality helps an insurer determine its cost to provide periodic payments, establish annuity reserves, and set annuity payout factors, which are used to determine the periodic payment.

To calculate the mortality associated with a product, and therefore price the product accordingly, insurers use mortality rates. A mortality rate is the rate at which death occurs among a defined group, or cohort, of people during a specified period, usually one year. Cohorts may be classified by age, gender, tobacco use (smoking) status, or other characteristics. Actuaries organize mortality rates in mortality tables. Recall from Chapter One that a mortality table, or life table, shows the mortality rate for each age of a given group of people—that is, how many deaths may be expected within the group at each age. Actuaries project the rate at which people in a given cohort are expected to die. The mortality rates that are shown in mortality tables are known as tabular mortality rates. Insurers have access to their own mortality research as well as the mortality research supplied by industry organizations. However, developing mortality assumptions for a life insurance or annuity product is not as simple as selecting a pre-existing mortality table and using the provided values.

pages.title: Developing Mortality Assumptions
pages.contents:
Developing Mortality Assumptions

Actuaries develop mortality assumptions for a variety of purposes, including pricing, reserving, and product modeling, The basic process of developing mortality assumptions for a life insurance or annuity product is to take known mortality experience and adjust it to make it relevant to a given product. In general, the process follows four steps, which we describe below.

 

Calculate Experience Mortality Rates

An actuary begins the process of developing mortality assumptions for a product by identifying appropriate mortality experience and calculating experience mortality rates. Mortality experience refers to the number of deaths that actually occur in a given group of people. Accordingly, experience mortality rates are the historical rates of death in a given cohort. When developing mortality assumptions for a product, the most relevant mortality experience comes from cohorts that match the cohorts of potential buyers of the new product. An actuary derives relevant mortality experience from internal data, industry data, or any other appropriate source. The actuary may then adjust the mortality experience to suit a specific product.

 

Develop Basic Mortality Rates

If necessary, the actuary then creates a table of basic mortality rates that provide a best fit with the experience mortality rates relevant to the proposed product. These basic mortality rates reflect a smoothing of the experience mortality rates to minimize any extreme values.

 

Create a Curve of Expected Mortality Rates

Extrapolating from the basic mortality rates, the actuary creates a curve of expected mortality rates. Expected mortality refers to the number or rate of deaths statistically likely to occur in a group of people at a given age.

 

Adjust Expected Mortality

The actuary may be able to use the curve of expected mortality rates without further adjustment. However, adjustment may be necessary to ensure that the data is credible enough for the insurer to rely on it. For example, a company’s internal experience mortality data might be insufficient as a basis for extrapolation if the company has experienced relatively few deaths at a given age. The insurer might not be able to tell how well internal mortality experience fits with industry mortality experience.

By adjusting expected mortality, the actuary creates useful mortality assumptions in the form of assumed mortality rates. Assumed mortality refers to the hypothetical or assumed number or rate of deaths in a given group of people. An assumed mortality rate is the rate entered into an actuarial model of a product. When calculating assumed mortality rates, the actuary may need to adjust the expected mortality curve to address any of the following considerations:

  • To acknowledge any reasonable expectation that policy design, underwriting, the risk selection process, or policyholder behavior will likely lead to future mortality results that vary from mortality experience, including any uncertainty in the projections attached to the specified business segment under consideration

  • To acknowledge any future trends in population mortality

  • To acknowledge any desired specific allowance for adverse deviation in mortality

Most U.S. companies create mortality tables for pricing by modifying basic tables to reflect their research with respect to risk class, smoking status, policy duration, age, sex, and policy size. Watch Video 8.1 for an illustration of the process of developing mortality assumptions.

Interpreting Mortality Data

Actuaries design mortality tables in a number of formats, some of which are as simple as two columns: an age and a mortality rate. Mortality rates are often expressed in terms of deaths per thousand lives for a specific period, usually a year. To illustrate mortality rates and survival rates, we will refer to this excerpt from a mortality table for men.

Calculating Mortality Rates

The listed probability of death for men age 65 tells us that the number of men within the age 65 cohort who are expected to die is roughly 15.8 per thousand (calculated as 0.015808 × 1,000). Actuaries calculate the mortality rate by dividing the number of deaths by a number representing the size of the cohort. The number representing the size of the cohort is based on the concept of exposure, or how many individuals in the age group were “exposed” to death during the time period in question. This distinction is necessary for insurers because if an insured surrenders, lapses, or otherwise ends his policy, the insurer can no longer accurately track that individual’s mortality after the policy ends. The size of the cohort changes each year as cohort members die.

At the age of 65, Judd Sassone purchased an insurance policy on his own life from Metric Life Insurance. Three months later, Mr. Sassone surrendered the policy. Metric later creates a mortality table based on a five-year study, with mortality rates expressed in one-year periods. When calculating the size of the cohort for men age 65, Mr. Sassone contributes 0.25 to the cohort’s exposure, because he was exposed to death for only three months—one-quarter, or 25% of a full one-year period—while insured by Metric.

We can see from the next year’s statistics that 1,263 members are expected to die over the course of the year (79,893 – 78,630 = 1,263). These calculations are the foundation of mortality tables.

 

Calculating Survival Rates

Mortality tables can also provide survival rates for each age, which are particularly useful for designing annuities. A survival rate is the percentage of people within a cohort who have attained a given age and are expected to be alive at their next birthday. We calculate the survival rate by dividing the number of survivors by the size of the cohort. The calculation for the survival rate for the age 65 cohort is as follows:

Mortality rate + Survival rate = 1

Therefore, the survival rate for men at age 65 would equal 0.984, calculated as 1 – 0.016.

pages.contents:
Types of Mortality Tables

An insurer chooses the type of mortality table to use depending on the product type, the purpose of the calculation, the characteristics of the population being studied, and the availability of appropriate statistics based on the insurance company’s own experience. Mortality tables can be very specific: a single table might represent a population of non-smoking male annuitants, for instance. Types of mortality tables also frequently overlap. For example, a single table might be classified as a select mortality table, a sex-distinct mortality table, and a valuation mortality table. In this section, we discuss some of the general categories and criteria that insurers use to select and build mortality tables that best meet the needs of product development.

 

Group-Specific Mortality Tables

A population mortality table shows mortality statistics for all members of a given population. Population mortality differs by country, so a mortality table valid in one country may not be valid in another country. Population mortality tables may provide a variety of data, including life expectancy, or the average number of years of life remaining for a group of people. The following insight shows average life expectancies at birth for various countries in 2019.

Product-Differentiated Mortality Tables

Insurers don’t use the same sets of mortality data in life insurance product design as they do in annuity product design. Annuitants tend to live longer than do life insureds, so insurers use lower mortality rates for annuity benefit design than for death benefit pricing. A life insurance mortality table shows the projected mortality rates and survival rates for a population of life insureds only. An annuity mortality table shows the projected mortality rates and survival rates for a population of annuitants only.

When life expectancy increases for the general population, or for a subset of the population, insurers experience a decrease in benefit costs for associated life insurance policies, but an increase in benefit costs for associated life annuities. The risk this trend poses for issuers of life annuities is sometimes called longevity risk.

Individuals may also face longevity risk. When we discuss the longevity risk of an individual, we are referring to the risk that he or she will outlive his or her assets.

The techniques used to manage mortality risk do not necessarily apply to longevity risk. A few effective techniques for managing longevity risk include

  • Monitoring external and internal sources of longevity data and incorporating estimated future longevity increases into the pricing for life annuities

  • Monitoring the company’s own sales of life annuities and evaluating the popularity of these products to determine whether the products are reasonably priced relative to those of competitors

  • Updating prices regularly, where applicable, to reflect the company’s latest understanding of longevity trends

  • Setting a maximum premium volume of life annuity business that the company will issue in any particular time period

Finally, insurers sometimes use different sets of mortality data for different products within a line of business and for different classes of underwriting risk within a product. For example, insurers often use lower mortality rates for individual annuities than they do for group annuities, because annuitants of individual annuities tend to live longer than do annuitants of group annuities.

Why do annuitants of individual annuities tend to live longer than annuitants of group annuities—or, for that matter, why do annuitants tend to live longer than life insureds? It may depend partly on lifestyle, income level, or the type of job the annuitant had during his or her working years. Annuitants of individual annuities tend to be in higher income or wealth brackets, which generally contribute to longevity.

In addition, customers purchase individual annuities to plan for the future—a decision that is more likely if a person has reason to believe that she will live long enough to require additional financial security. An annuitant may expect to live longer because of family medical history, personal health regimen, or other factors. People who are less optimistic about their life expectancy are less likely to purchase annuities.

Note also that life insureds tend to live longer than uninsured people. This difference could be partly due to the typical underwriting requirement for medical examinations: the healthier a person is, the more likely that the insurance company will approve her application for life insurance.

 

Basic and Valuation Mortality Tables

Insurers create some mortality tables to fulfill specific functions, in particular estimating the cost of a product’s benefit payments and calculating the amount of required reserves. The difference between the tables designed for these two purposes is the presence of a safety margin. This margin is the difference between the mortality rate that the insurer expects and the mortality rate that the insurer wishes to prepare for. In other words, an insurer using a safety margin is better prepared (or “safer”) if actual mortality experience varies from the expected mortality rate.

  • Primarily used for technical product design, basic mortality tables are mortality tables with no safety margin built into the rates. Basic mortality tables provide realistic mortality rates so that an insurer can best estimate future mortality costs.

  • Primarily used to calculate policy reserves, valuation mortality tables are mortality tables with a margin built into the rates. Because they have a safety margin built into their rates, valuation mortality tables are inherently more conservative than are basic mortality tables. Many of the values in valuation mortality tables are either determined or approved by regulators. This practice helps an insurer prepare sufficient reserves in the event that actual mortality varies from the insurer’s expectations:

  • For life annuities, the mortality margin reduces the assumed mortality rates and increases the assumed survivorship.

  • For life insurance, the mortality margin increases the assumed mortality rates and decreases the assumed survivorship.

 

Select and Ultimate Mortality Tables

Actuaries can also construct mortality tables to reflect the effects of recent underwriting evaluations on mortality. Insurers use these tables for pricing and reserve valuation. Tables that reflect the effects of underwriting are select mortality tables, ultimate mortality tables, and select and ultimate mortality tables.

  • A select mortality table shows the expected mortality rates of people who have recently been underwritten for insurance policies. People whose risk characteristics have been evaluated recently are likely to have better mortality risk characteristics during a specified select mortality period following the underwriting evaluation than do people who have not recently undergone an underwriting selection process. (Better mortality risk characteristics for life insurance are risk characteristics that indicate lower mortality.) For mortality tables used in pricing, the select mortality period can range from three to up to 25 years.

  • An ultimate mortality table shows the expected mortality rates of people who have not recently been underwritten for insurance policies. Several years after a person has been examined in an underwriting process, the person could develop new risk characteristics. After this time, the risk inherent in the mortality estimate increases. In this context, the ultimate mortality period is the period of time after the select mortality period has ended. The ultimate mortality period has no formal length, as it reflects the remaining years after the effects of underwriting have diminished.

  • A select and ultimate mortality table, also called an aggregate mortality table, combines coordinated sets of select mortality rates and ultimate mortality rates. For periods in the next few years, the select and ultimate table shows select rates. For longer periods, the select and ultimate table shows a blend of select and ultimate rates. For periods after the effects of underwriting have diminished, the select and ultimate table shows ultimate mortality rates.

 

Sex-Distinct and Unisex Mortality Tables

Actuaries can construct mortality tables on a sex-distinct or unisex basis.

  • Sex-distinct mortality tables are mortality tables that show different mortality rates for males and females.

  • Unisex mortality tables are mortality tables that show a single set of mortality rates to be used for both males and females. When an insurer uses unisex mortality tables, men and women of the same age are charged the same rates for the same type and amount of coverage. In the United States, most group insurance products are based on unisex mortality rates because courts have generally held that the use of sex-distinct mortality tables constitutes unlawful discrimination in employment. The EU, and some states in the United States, require the use of unisex mortality tables.

Actual mortality rates and life expectancies differ by sex; on average, women live longer than do men. Thus, insurers must generally pay annuity benefits to women as a group for a longer period than to men as a group. For the same reason, insurers must pay death benefits on insured men at earlier ages on the average than for insured women. The mortality rate of women at any given age—up to the end of a mortality table—is generally lower than that for men.

Life annuity premium rates based on sex-distinct mortality tables are generally higher for women than for men having otherwise similar characteristics. Insurers sometimes compensate for female annuitants’ lower mortality rates—and longer life expectancy—by charging female annuitants higher premiums than they charge male annuitants having otherwise similar characteristics. Similarly, insurers generally compensate for the higher mortality rates among men by charging higher life insurance premiums for men than they charge for women having otherwise similar characteristics.

 

Proprietary and Published Mortality Tables

Insurers use both proprietary and published mortality tables.

  • Proprietary mortality tables are the mortality tables a single insurance company develops for internal use, based largely on its experience with its own customers. Larger insurance companies are more likely to develop proprietary mortality tables than are smaller insurers.

  • Published mortality tables, also called public mortality tables, are mortality tables that are made available to the general public through printed documents and electronic sources. Published mortality tables are based on the mortality of the public at large or a broad cross-section of the population. The mortality tables compiled and published by the Society of Actuaries are examples of published mortality tables.

Large and small insurers use published mortality tables for calculating net premiums, reserves, and cash values. Insurance companies can also use published industry mortality tables for benchmarking purposes. In addition, if a company has too little business in a given segment or is otherwise too small to have credible data from its own experience, it can supplement its experience with published mortality tables. However, recall from Chapter 2 that insurers have been moving toward principles-based reserving (PBR), in which actuarial assumptions and reserve levels change as risk factors change. The use of PBR favors proprietary mortality tables, as they better capture the risks specific to a company.

pages.title: Adjusting Tabular Mortality Rates
pages.contents:
Adjusting Tabular Mortality Rates

As noted earlier, when developing mortality assumptions, actuaries may adjust mortality rates to acknowledge trends or other factors that may cause future mortality to differ from actual mortality experience. For example, demographers have noted a long-term trend of small decreases in mortality over time. Because of this trend, mortality rates and tables based on experience alone generally may not reliably indicate future mortality.

Mortality tables that have not been adjusted to account for future changes in mortality are called static mortality tables. By contrast, a common form of adjusted mortality table is the generational mortality table , or dynamic mortality table, in which mortality rates are dependent on both the person’s age and the year the person attains that age. For example, a static mortality table assumes that a 65-year-old in 2040 will have the same life expectancy as a 65-year-old in 2020. In contrast, a generational mortality table generally assumes that a group of 65-year-olds in 2040 will have a lower mortality rate than 65-year-olds in 2020, or in some cases, a higher mortality rate. Generational mortality tables are more complicated to create and use than are static mortality tables, but offer more precise estimations of how longevity may change between generations. Many insurers use a blend of the two approaches by taking a static mortality table and applying a mortality improvement scale, which is a published set of recommended adjustments to mortality tables. The recommended adjustments in a mortality improvement scale are based on recent projections of mortality trends. Industry organizations such as the SOA are the most common source of mortality improvement scales.

Insurers can use a number of statistical approaches for estimating future changes in mortality. Two simple methods for modifying tabular mortality rates to reflect mortality changes are the projection method and the setback method. The projection method is more complicated than the setback method, but also generally produces more accurate and subtle results than does the setback method.

 

Projection Method

The projection method for adjusting tabular mortality involves multiplying the tabular mortality rates by a chosen percentage. Tables that have been adjusted using the projection method to account for future changes in mortality are called mortality tables with projection.

The projection method requires the insurer to choose a percentage that matches the insurer’s expectations for future mortality. For example,

  • If the insurer expects people in the specified group to die sooner than the tabular rates indicate, the insurer would multiply the tabular rates by a factor larger than 100 percent.

  • If the insurer expects people in the specified group to live longer than the tabular mortality rates indicate, the insurer would multiply the tabular rates by a factor smaller than 100 percent.

When designing a new annuity product, Comet Life Insurance decides to use the projection method to reflect longevity trends that are likely to affect the specified group of potential annuitants. Comet multiplies the tabular rates by 80%, which indicates that Comet expects the group to live longer than expected.

Figure 8.1 compares a portion of a mortality curve based on industry mortality tables with a portion of a mortality curve that is also based on the same tables, but that has also been modified with projection. The curve with projection has been multiplied by a factor of 30 percent, indicating that the insurer is expecting people in the group to live longer. Note that, near age 100, when the unmodified mortality curve has a steep upward slope, the curve with projection has a more gradual slope. Most of the difference at the higher ages reflects a distortion of the curve caused by the projection.

 

Setback Method

The setback method of adjusting tabular mortality rates consists of showing future decreases in mortality for people of a given age by using the tabular mortality rate for a younger age. When applying an age setback, insurers typically use values of one to five years. Generally, insurers avoid using a setback of greater than five years, as a large setback could distort the mortality curve.

When adjusting a mortality table for a new life insurance product, Comet Life Insurance decides it should use a reduced mortality rate relative to tabular rates for age 35. Comet settles on a two-year age setback for age 35, which uses an age two years younger than the attained age. Comet therefore applies the tabular mortality rate for the group at age 33 to the group at age 35.
