pages.title: Cost of Benefits in Technical Product Design
pages.contents:
Cost of Benefits in Technical Product Design

As noted earlier, mortality rates affect a product’s cost of benefits if the benefit involves mortality risk for life insurance products or longevity risk for life annuity products. For some products such as term life insurance, insurers directly incorporate the mortality cost into the product’s overall pricing. Other products, such as variable universal life, assess an explicit charge—usually called a mortality and expense charge, or a cost of insurance charge—to cover the product’s mortality cost. A separate charge for mortality cost is necessary for products with cash values, so that the customer can clearly see what portion of the premium covers the cost of insurance and what portion of the premium increases the product’s cash value.

To build mortality cost into a product’s pricing, an insurer typically follows two steps:

  • Estimate base mortality costs (for life insurance) or base annuity benefit costs (for life annuities)

  • Apply a mortality margin (discussed later in this chapter)

To find the base mortality cost/annuity benefit cost, we estimate the number and the amount of the average benefit payment expected in a given period. Then we multiply these amounts, as shown:

Benefit cost = Expected number of benefit payments × Amount of the average benefit payment

The calculations to apply this approach vary between a life insurance product and a life annuity.

 

Mortality Cost for Life Insurance

For a one-year term life insurance policy, the potential claim is equal to the policy’s face amount. We can estimate the number of claims—or, in the case of one policy, the probability of a claim—by using the mortality rate. So, the estimated mortality cost of a $100,000 one-year term policy issued to a male age 35 is the mortality rate for a 35-year-old male (0.002125), multiplied by the $100,000 face amount, as shown below:

Mortality cost = Probability of dying × Average face amount
Mortality cost = 0.002125 × $100,000
Mortality cost = $212.50

This calculation shows that the mortality cost of life insurance benefits is $212.50 for a $100,000 one-year term life insurance policy issued to a male age 35. A simplified mortality cost calculation can arrive at the same result by multiplying the number of deaths per thousand (for 35-year-old males, 2.125) by the average face amount measured in units of $1,000, or:

Mortality cost = Deaths per thousand × Average face amount (in $1,000s)
Mortality cost = 2.125 × $100
Mortality cost = $212.50

Note that this calculation produces a statistically weighted expectation of loss per policy in a block of policies. If actual mortality is higher than expected, then the mortality charges in the product’s design may not be sufficient to pay for the product’s actual mortality cost. To protect the insurer against adverse experience, the product design typically includes a mortality margin, which we will discuss momentarily.

Insurers build mortality cost into a product’s pricing in different ways depending on whether the product is a term life, whole life, or universal life product. We discuss life insurance technical product design in more detail in Chapter 10.

 

Annuity Benefit Cost for a Life Annuity

For a life annuity, the annuity benefit cost equals the value of the benefits promised under the contract. For one year of a single life annuity contract, the insurer’s probability of having to pay the yearly benefit amount is equal to the annuitant’s probability of surviving that year. Remember that an annuitant’s probability of surviving each year is equal to 1 minus the appropriate tabular mortality rate.

Using a product-differentiated mortality table for annuitants, the calculation of the one-year annuity benefit cost for a $1,000 annual income payment on a life annuity issued to a male age 65 is shown below:

Annuity benefit cost = Probability of living × Average annual income payment
Annuity benefit cost = (1 – Mortality rate, male age 65) × $1,000
Annuity benefit cost = (1 – 0.0132) × $1,000
Annuity benefit cost = 0.9868 × $1,000
Annuity benefit cost = $986.80

The cost of benefits—in this case, the annuity benefit cost—is $986.80 for this particular year of a life annuity with a yearly income payment of $1,000. To find the total cost of benefits for an annuitant’s lifetime, the insurer performs a similar calculation for each year, continuing to the end of the mortality table, and then finds the discounted value of the periodic payments. As with life insurance products, the total mortality charge typically includes a mortality margin to protect against adverse experience. Note that some life insurance products allow the option to receive benefit payments as a stream of income payments, which are effectively annuity payments and influence the product’s pricing accordingly.

When pricing an annuity product, the payout schedule is also a factor. With a deferred annuity, which begins making payments at least one annuity period—in this context, one year—after the contract is purchased, the insurer can invest the purchase premium and build any expected gains on the investments into the product’s pricing. In the case of an immediate annuity, which begins making payments within a year after the contract is purchased, the insurer has less opportunity for investments to gain value. Insurers therefore hedge their risk with immediate annuities by using mortality credits. A mortality credit is a monetary value that an insurer (1) allotted to payments for an annuity, and (2) did not pay in full due to the death of the annuitant. When an annuitant dies before the insurer has paid all the potential payments from his annuity, the insurer can use the resulting mortality credits to fund payments for other annuity contracts.

We discuss deferred annuities and annuity product design in more detail in Chapter 11.

 

The Mortality Margin

For insurance companies, a mortality margin is a provision for conservatism in mortality risk projections. Building an expected mortality margin into a life insurance or an annuity product’s technical design may help the insurer meet its benefit obligations if actual mortality rates turn out to be different from what was expected. A positive mortality margin can be a source of company profits. Mortality margins differ for life insurance products and life annuities.

  • Life Insurance: A positive mortality margin for a death benefit results from applying a higher mortality rate than would be found in a basic mortality table. By assuming that more insureds will die, the insurer prepares for potential high-mortality scenarios where it would have to pay more claims. If actual mortality turns out to be lower than the margin-adjusted mortality rates, the product’s profits will be higher.

  • Annuities: A positive mortality margin for a life annuity payout results from applying a lower mortality rate than would be found in a basic mortality table. By assuming that more annuitants will survive to collect benefits, the insurer prepares for potential low-mortality scenarios where the insurer’s cost of benefits is high. If actual mortality rates are higher than the margin-adjusted mortality rates, the product’s profits will be higher.

Once the insurer has determined the appropriate mortality cost/annuity benefit cost and set a mortality margin, the insurer can then incorporate the total mortality cost into the product’s pricing or set an appropriate mortality charge.

The cost of benefits is the main expense related to an insurance or annuity product. However, operating expenses and expenses associated with policyholder behavior also influence the profitability of such products. In 2018, operating expenses made up an average of 13% of insurers’ expenditures. 1 To ensure their products are profitable, insurers must incorporate operating expenses into product design and anticipate policyholder actions that would increase expenses or reduce income.

In Chapter 2, we stated that insurers build operating expenses into product design, often in the form of charges. The particular charges and processes vary from company to company, but the process generally includes four steps:

  • Describing the characteristics of and future policyholder behaviors associated with the operating expenses that are most likely to affect the product

  • Assigning relevant operating expenses to products and product lines

  • Controlling commission expenses and setting margins for risks and profits

  • Incorporating operating expenses into product design

In this chapter, we’ll describe these steps and look at product features that a technical product design team can build into complex products to mitigate risks, including policyholder behavior risks.

pages.title: Describing Operating Expenses
pages.contents:
Describing Operating Expenses

A company incurs many of its operating expenses as a result of developing, administering, and maintaining its products. The first step in determining operating expenses in product design is identifying which operating expenses are directly relevant to the insurer’s products. The company then gathers and analyzes information about relevant expenses to determine how these expenses are likely to affect profitability over time.

 

Identifying Relevant Operating Expenses

The operating expenses that are relevant to product design can be divided into four broad categories:

  • Development expenses, also known as research and development expenses, which the insurer incurs in starting a new product or product line.

  • Acquisition expenses, which the insurer incurs to obtain and issue new life insurance policies and annuity contracts.

  • Maintenance expenses, or renewal expenses, which the insurer incurs while a contract is in force.

  • Overhead expenses, which the insurer incurs during normal business operations. Overhead expenses are not directly connected to a specific product.

For expense control purposes, companies further divide operating expenses into controllable and noncontrollable expenses, direct and indirect expenses, and variable and fixed expenses.

  • A controllable expense is a cost over which a specified manager or organizational unit has power and influence. Examples of controllable expenses include the cost of advertising, technology purchases, overtime compensation, accounting services, and various other administrative services.

  • A noncontrollable expense is a cost over which no specified manager or organizational unit has power or influence. Examples of noncontrollable expenses include depreciation on equipment, taxes, and the costs of business licenses.

  • Direct expenses, also known as traceable costs, are product expenses incurred for or physically traceable to a specified life insurance or annuity product. Examples of direct expenses include expenses for sales commissions, transaction processing, premium taxes for most products, and product implementation.

  • Indirect expenses, also called common costs, are expenses that cannot be traced to or that are not incurred for one specific product. Indirect expenses result from activities that relate to several or all of an insurer’s products. An insurer incurs the same amount of indirect expenses whether it offers a specific product. Examples of indirect expenses include expenses for accounting systems, rent, executive salaries, property taxes, and some information systems.

  • A variable expense is an expense amount that varies in direct proportion to some variation in a specified level of operating activity. Examples of variable expenses include expenses for sales commissions, premium accounting, policy issue costs, transaction accounting, and premium taxes for most products.

  • A fixed expense is an expense that remains relatively constant regardless of the number of policies or contracts sold or the level of operating activity. Examples of fixed expenses include expenses for rent, executive salaries, property taxes, marketing research, and office equipment.

A typical expense falls into multiple categories. For example, the cost of product advertising is an acquisition expense, a controllable expense, a direct expense, and a variable expense. Direct expenses often are also variable expenses and indirect expenses often are also fixed expenses. Keep in mind that over time, all expenses tend to become variable, and thus the distinction between fixed and variable expenses is generally useful only in the short term, such as within a typical reporting period. Nonetheless, the process of categorizing expenses in this fashion helps companies perform the more in-depth expense analysis necessary for product design.

 

Gathering Expense Data

To understand how known expenses are likely to behave and therefore affect profitability, insurers must collect and analyze internal and external expense experience data. Experience data describe real-world observations of specified phenomena. Internal experience data reflect the characteristics and patterns of a company’s own historical expense experience, while external experience data reflect the characteristics and patterns of other companies’ historical expense experience.

To gather internal expense data, a company uses its own accounting information systems, which gather and store historical, company-specific accounting information. For example, an insurer’s systems contain historical records of premiums paid, lapses, claim costs, the cost of various underwriting reports, and many other forms of information that comprise the costs associated with a product. One particularly important accounting subsystem is the cost accounting system, which accumulates expense data for the dual purposes of effective cost control and accurate product design activities. The cost accounting system enables cost accumulation, which is the process of capturing all company costs and classifying them in meaningful ways.

A company may have limited expense experience with a particular type of product. To bolster its internal expense data, a company acquires and analyzes external experience data to learn from other companies’ historical information. A company can gain external expense experience data from experience studies, benchmarking studies, and research conducted by independent consultants and by industry organizations such as the MIB Group Inc. (MIB), LIMRA International, and the Society of Actuaries (SOA).

 

Developing Expense Projections

The foundation for estimating future expenses is historical expense data. But future expense patterns do not always reliably follow historical expense data. The factors surrounding a company’s business are constantly changing, and expenses change with them. To develop expense projections that are more likely to match currently unknown future expense patterns, companies require expense analysis. For product design, expense analysis is a process in which insurers study relevant costs and project the characteristics and behaviors of those costs over a proposed product’s lifetime.

Financial modeling is a vital part of expense analysis. As we described in Chapter 4, insurers use financial modeling—both deterministic modeling and, increasingly, stochastic modeling—to estimate future financial performance by projecting potential income and potential costs. Stochastic modeling is increasingly useful because it can address the wider range of potential outcomes associated with the variability of policyholder behavior.

Although insurers must include expense projections in all new product designs, not all of the expenses that affect a company’s new products require extensive expense analysis and modeling. If a particular operating activity is the same for all products or if a new product is sufficiently similar to one of the insurer’s existing products, the insurer may base its expense assumptions on standard costs. Standard costs are cost estimates representing the average amount of a given type of expenditure for normal business operations. Standard costs can efficiently estimate certain costs for product design, such as the cost of mailing policy documents. Standard costs may be direct, such as the cost of mailings, or indirect, such as rent and office equipment. However, insurers must review standard costs periodically to ensure that the costs continue to accurately reflect actual conditions.

Executive salaries are an example of a/an (direct / indirect) cost and a (fixed / variable) cost.

pages.title: Assigning Expenses to Products or Product Lines
pages.contents:
Assigning Expenses to Products or Product Lines

Once the insurer has identified the specific expenses that are relevant to product design and projected the monetary amounts of those expenses, the insurer calculates unit costs and assigns the expenses both fairly and efficiently to particular products or product lines.

 

Calculating Unit Costs

To determine the amount of expenses to assign to a particular product, an insurer must translate total costs into unit costs. A unit cost is the amount of incurred expense attributable to a single measured amount of product. A unit cost is found by dividing the total relevant cost by the number of designated units of products, as shown below.

Unit cost = Total cost
Number of units

Unit costs can then be incorporated into the product’s financial design. For example, if an insurer knows the unit cost for an individual term life insurance policy, then the term life product must be designed so that each individual policy recoups its unit cost. For a new product, insurers generally base unit costs on projections of the product’s expected volume of business.

Unit costs for most fixed expenses are expressed as a flat amount per contract. For example, an insurer’s costs for preparing and mailing account statements to customers are fixed; the costs are the same for all contracts of the same type. Therefore, to determine a unit cost for statement preparation costs, the insurer would divide the total cost of preparing and mailing statements to customers by the number of contracts. Figure 9.1 shows a unit cost calculation for policy issue expenses.

For variable expenses, insurers generally calculate unit costs as a percentage of an important contractual amount, such as the

  • Death benefit amount

  • Initial premium amount

  • Account value

  • Amount of account activity

 

Costing Methods

The process used during technical product design to set a product’s expense projections is called costing. Insurance companies can use one of two methods for costing life insurance and annuity products:

  • Full costing, or absorption costing, is an accounting method for estimating product-related expenses in which direct and indirect expenses are both counted. Thus, full costing requires an insurer to allocate all operating expenses to each product line and potentially to each product.

  • Marginal costing, or direct costing, is an accounting method for estimating product-related expenses in which only direct expenses are counted. Under marginal costing, indirect expenses are not allocated to products.

Marginal costing generally produces a smaller operating expense estimate than full costing produces. To offset this difference, insurers typically set margins that are designed to cover contingencies. The insight below illustrates the results of full costing and marginal costing for the same product. For the sake of simplicity, this example assumes that all of the product’s expenses are incurred and all premiums are paid at the same time—a highly unlikely scenario for actual insurance products.

INSIGHT

Full Costing and Marginal Costing

The Coral Life Insurance Company sells a life insurance product with the following expense profile for its first year of operations:

Direct expenses (per contract):

Agent first-year commissions

$60

Contract issue costs

$250

Contract underwriting

$20

Contract administration

$100

Total direct expenses

$430

Allocated indirect expenses (per contract):

Field office expenses

$30

Home office marketing expenses

$20

Systems support

$300

Total indirect expenses

$350

Because full costing includes both indirect and direct expenses, the total expense cost using full costing is calculated as

$430 + $350 = $780

Marginal costing, on the other hand, does not include indirect costs. Thus, the total expense cost using marginal costing is the total direct expenses, or $430.

 

Assigning Direct and Indirect Costs

Because direct costs are associated with a particular project, assigning unit costs for direct expenses to a particular product is usually a straightforward process. The process of assigning unit costs for indirect costs is less straightforward. An insurer usually incurs the same amount of indirect expenses regardless of whether or not it offers a specific product. For example, the costs associated with an insurer’s accounting system apply to the entire company, and would be a key company expense even if the insurer decided not to offer a given product. An insurer must therefore allocate unit costs for indirect expenses along several products and product lines.

Cost allocation, or expense allocation, is the accounting process of assigning an indirect cost to a particular cost object according to a formal procedure. A cost object is any purpose for which a business measures costs. For an insurance company, a cost object may be a product line, specific product, contract, monetary amount of contract value, customer, or any other specified business unit. The formal procedure used to assign indirect costs is known as a cost allocation method.

Both standard costs and costs derived from expense analysis can be allocated costs. Figure 9.2 shows a simplified cost allocation for a fixed whole life insurance product.

 

Managing Commission Expenses

A large portion of an insurance company’s operating expenses is the payment of commissions to financial professionals. In 2018, commissions to agents made up almost 40 percent of an insurer’s operating expenses. A product design’s commission expense is generally a direct expense, as commission payments are tied directly to sales of a specific product. Incorporating commission expenses into product design requires understanding the type of commission, which determines the timing and size of commission payments.

 

Managing Commissions for Life Insurance Sales

Insurers generally divide commissions for individual life insurance into two categories:

  • First-year commissions are payable when a contract is purchased and are equal to a stated percentage of the premium the insurer receives during the first policy year. Most insurers pay relatively large first-year commissions as a way to encourage sales. First-year commission rates for life insurance products typically range from 40 to 90 percent of the first-year premium.

  • Renewal commissions are payable while a policy is in force and are equal to a stated percentage of each premium paid for a specified number of years after the first policy year. Renewal commissions are designed to encourage persistency by providing agents with a continuing stream of income from existing policies. Agents benefit from finding and selling to customers who are less likely to lapse or surrender their policies, and therefore the insurer benefits from steady premium income and less need to make surrender payments. Renewal commissions are usually between 2 and 5 percent of the premiums received after the first policy year.

We see from this comparison that first-year commission payments increase the operating expenses for a life insurance product during the first year, while renewal commission payments increase a life insurance product’s operating expenses for multiple years. The duration of renewal commission payments depends on whether the commission is vested, nonvested, or conditionally vested:

  • A vested commission is guaranteed payable to an agent whether or not the agent represents the company when the commission becomes due.

  • A nonvested commission is payable only if the agent still represents the company when the commission becomes due.

  • A conditionally vested commission becomes vested only after an agent reaches a certain age or number of years with the company.

Most agent compensation schedules for life insurance sales include both first-year and renewal commissions. A common arrangement is the heaped commission schedule, which features relatively high first-year commissions and lower renewal commissions. While expensive for the insurer, a heaped commission schedule encourages agents to focus on generating new business. To stress the importance of persistency, insurers may increase or decrease production bonuses paid to agents, depending on whether the agent’s sales show higher or lower persistency, or offer agents a separate persistency bonus for favorable persistency results.

 

Managing Commissions for Annuity Sales

Annuity commission schedules generally do not distinguish between first-year and renewal commissions, given that annuities usually feature large initial premiums and much smaller, if any, subsequent premiums. The simplest form of commission schedule for annuities is the deposit-based commission schedule, which pays commissions only on premium payments. A deposit-based commission schedule usually pays a sum calculated as a percentage of the annuity’s premium, such as 5 percent.

By contrast, increasingly more insurers offer asset-based commission schedules. An asset-based commission schedule calculates commissions as a percentage of the accumulated value of a deferred annuity contract’s funds. In addition, commissions are payable as long as the contract remains in force, even if the contract owner stops making premium payments. At regular intervals—usually yearly—after premium payments stop, the agent receives a commission payment known as a trail commission.

Asset-based commission schedules are designed to improve persistency, conserve annuity assets, and encourage agents to provide excellent ongoing service to annuity contract owners. The insight below compares deposit-based and asset-based commission schedules.

INSIGHT

Deposit-Based and Asset-Based Commission Schedules

Flora Ballantine, an agent working for Coral Life Insurance and Wisteria Financial Group, sells two different variable annuities with a $250,000 initial premium amount. The first annuity, a Coral product, offers a 4 percent deposit-based commission schedule. The second annuity, a Wisteria product, offers a 1 percent asset-based commission schedule.

For selling the Coral annuity contract, Flora receives a single payment of $10,000 ($250,000 × 0.04). When selling Coral’s products, Flora has a financial incentive to make as many initial sales as she can.

For selling the Wisteria annuity contract, Flora receives a payment each year based on the accumulated value of the contract, as long as the annuity’s owner does not surrender the contract. The following table shows the commission payments for the first five years (rounded to the nearest dollar).

Note that, in this scenario, Flora earns more over time with Wisteria’s asset-based commission schedule—assuming the customer did not surrender the contract before the fourth year commission payment. When selling Wisteria’s products, Flora has a financial incentive to ensure that her customers keep their annuity contracts in force.

Most insurers today use a combination of deposit-based and asset-based commission schedules for annuity sales. The deposit-based commissions incentivize agents to generate new business, while asset-based commissions incentivize agents to encourage contract owners to keep their contracts in force. pages.title: Setting Margins for Profits, Risks, and Policyholder Behavior
pages.contents:
Setting Margins for Profits, Risks, and Policyholder Behavior

Once the insurer has identified and allocated the expected operating expenses for a new product, it should have an idea of how much revenue the product will need to earn to generate a profit. Of course, modeling can only anticipate potential results. When actual patterns do not match projected patterns, or when expenses arise that were not included in the insurer’s projections, these events can cause adverse deviations from an insurer’s expense projections.

 

Assumptions for Policyholder Behavior

In Chapter 2, we described policyholder behavior risk as the risk that policyholder actions or decisions will adversely affect product performance. The most common examples of policyholder transactions that terminate or reduce a product’s value are lapses, surrenders, and withdrawals.

  • Recall that a lapse is the termination of a life insurance policy for nonpayment of premium. Insurance products with cash value usually continue coverage until the policy’s cash value is depleted, but without certain guarantees, will also lapse eventually if no premiums are paid. Typically, a lapse rate that is higher than projected is a potential risk to a product’s profitability. While lapses are generally considered negative occurrences because they result in a loss of revenue, lapse-supported products are designed to be profitable in the face of higher lapse rates. For such products, a lapse rate that is lower than projected would be a potential risk to profitability.

  • Recall that a surrender is a transaction in which the owner of a cash value life insurance contract or deferred annuity contract chooses to receive the contract’s monetary value before the contract matures. With a surrender of an annuity, the contract terminates and the company makes no further payments.

  • A withdrawal is a transaction in which (1) the owner of a life insurance policy elects to receive a portion of the policy’s cash value while the policy is in force, or (2) the owner of a deferred annuity contract elects to receive a portion of the contract’s accumulated value during the accumulation period. A withdrawal is also known as a partial surrender or policy withdrawal. Not all cash value life insurance policies permit withdrawals of cash value. Insurers typically allow customers to withdraw a certain percentage of the cash value or accumulated value each year without charge, such as 7 to 10 percent. Withdrawals in excess of the specified percentages are subject to penalty charges.

Insurers usually assess the persistency of life insurance business by calculating the lapse rate and surrender rate for blocks of similar policies issued to individuals who are the same age, the same sex, and in the same risk category.

  • The lapse rate for a block of life insurance policies is the ratio of business in force that terminates for nonpayment of premium during a given period to the total business in force at the beginning of that period.

  • The surrender rate for a block of insurance or annuity contracts is the ratio of the number of contracts surrendered during a given period to the total number of contracts in force at the beginning of that period.

Farthing Life Insurance has a block of 10,000 term life insurance policies in force at the beginning of the year. 1,000 of those policies lapse during the year, and policyowners surrender another 500 policies during the year. The lapse rate for the block of policies during that year is the ratio of lapses during the year to the total business in force at the beginning of the year, or:

1,000 lapses ÷ 10,000 life insurance policies = 10% lapse rate

The surrender rate for the block of policies during that year is the ratio of surrenders during the year to the total contracts in force at the beginning of the year, or:

500 surrenders ÷ 10,000 life insurance policies = 5% surrender rate

Note that many insurers count surrenders as part of the overall lapse rate instead of differentiating between lapses and surrenders.

Lapses, surrenders, and withdrawals are some of the policyholder behaviors that can affect a product’s performance. Other examples of policyholder behavior include

  • Paying flexible premiums after the initial premium

  • Determining the timing of premium payments

  • Taking out policy loans

  • Changing the allocations of premiums between accounts

  • Transferring funds between fixed and separate accounts or between various subaccounts

  • Utilizing specific benefits

To properly model a product’s performance, insurers consider all of these behaviors when determining policyholder behavior assumptions. The task of projecting these behaviors is clearly challenging. To further complicate product modeling for policyholder behavior, companies typically have little or no internal experience data for new products and features. In addition, policyholder behavior constantly evolves, particularly with respect to new products and product features. External forces such as volatile financial markets and increased access to financial information may influence a policyholder’s decisions.

One factor affecting product profitability is whether an option is “in the money” for the policyholder. In a financial context, a benefit available from an ownership option or rider is in the money (ITM) for the policyholder if the benefit is more favorable for the customer than are the benefits available under the contract itself. In other words, if exercising an option would be more favorable to the policyholder than not exercising the option, the option is ITM. A common example of an ITM benefit is a policy element that retains value during stock market declines or similar downturns.

Carla Infante purchased an annuity with an interest-crediting rate of 2.5% from Farthing Life Insurance. Five years later, the market interest rate was 2.0%. Carla chooses not to surrender her annuity contract in favor of another product offering a lower interest rate. This choice is beneficial for Carla, and therefore ITM. However, Carla’s choice is less beneficial for Farthing, which may be experiencing spread compression.

Policyholders tend to exercise ownership options in products when financial market conditions are unfavorable for the company and favorable for the policyholder. However, this generalization does not always apply. A policyholder might not exercise her options even when the options are ITM, or she might exercise the options even when the transaction would produce a loss for the policyholder. For example, the immediate needs of a policyholder’s household may take priority over the optimal exercise of the policyholder’s ownership options. Unexpected expenses in a policyholder’s life may make it more attractive for the policyholder to exercise an option for a smaller amount of money, payable immediately, than to receive a larger amount of money in the future.

An insurer must estimate how efficient its policyholders will be for a given product—that is to say, how likely a policyholder is to exercise ownership options when market conditions produce the greatest gains for the policyholder. If the insurer underestimates policyholder efficiency, the insurer is at risk of underpricing the product’s riders or other benefits, and the company might not be able to meet its profit targets. If the insurer overestimates policyholder efficiency, it may price its products too high for the market.

 

Modeling Applications for Policyholder Behavior

Recall from Chapter 4 that actuarial assumptions may be classified as fixed, dynamic, or stochastic. Historically, when modeling the potential future behavior of policyholders, insurers primarily tend to use fixed and dynamic assumptions. Insurers may use stochastic assumptions if the risk being managed has specific characteristics, as described below.

In practice, insurers differ in how they model assumptions. One company might model withdrawals as a fixed assumption, while another company chooses to model withdrawals as a dynamic assumption. A single insurer may even model an assumption as either fixed or dynamic, depending on the function for which the modeling is used. Most commonly, insurers use

  • A fixed structure for assumptions used in pricing, valuation, and forecasting

  • A dynamic structure for assumptions used in asset/liability management and risk management 2

In addition, the type of product affects the choice of modeling assumption. For example, dynamic assumptions are most common when modeling policyholder behavior for universal life products.

In theory, any assumption can be modeled using a stochastic structure: lapse rates, flexible premium payments, surrender rates, and so on. Traditionally, stochastic modeling is preferable if the underlying risks have one or more of the following characteristics:

  • The volatility of the outcomes is unknown or high.

  • A given risk is nondiversifiable.

  • The company lacks an appropriate hedge for a given product risk.

  • The future outcomes from a given risk are likely to have a skewed distribution or a “fat tail,” as described in Chapter 4.

In the context of policyholder behavior, stochastic assumptions are particularly useful when modeling products that contain nonguaranteed elements. Nonguaranteed elements (NGEs) in life insurance and annuities are product features that allow an insurer to reward customers when the insurer has experienced or anticipates it will experience favorable deviations from its assumptions, or, conversely, allow the insurer to charge customers more when the insurer has experienced or anticipates it will experience unfavorable deviations from its assumptions. For example, the cash value on some universal life insurance products earns interest based on current market interest rates, which influences policyholder behavior when market interest rates rise, fall, or remain stagnant. To take these variables into consideration, insurers increasingly use stochastic assumptions when modeling possible future policyholder behavior for products with nonguaranteed elements.

 

Setting Margins

Using internal and external experience data, insurers typically build provisions for policyholder behavior into their expense projections. If actual lapse and surrender rates are lower than expected, the expense charge in the product design is typically sufficient to cover the company’s costs. If actual lapse and surrender rates are higher than expected the insurer may not be able to fully recover its costs.

To help protect against potential losses from adverse deviations from expense projections, insurers may base their expense charges on the results of pessimistic scenarios. If an expense charge is built on a pessimistic scenario—for instance, the expectation that lapse rates will be five percent higher than initially projected—then it is more likely that any deviation from that expectation will be favorable. Basing an assumption on a non-ideal outcome amounts to creating a margin.

Watch Video 9.1 for a basic illustration of the use of margins to manage the risk of decreased persistency for a life insurance product. For simplicity’s sake, this video does not include provisions for contingencies other than lapses, or calculate persistency rates beyond the product’s first year, both of which would be necessary for actual product design.

Video 9.1 Using Margins to Reduce Risk

The relative size of a margin can be affected by a variety of product characteristics, such as

  • Competition. A competitive market often acts to force prices down. If a product is competing with a number of other products, the product’s margin is likely to be smaller to keep the price competitive. Conversely, if a product has little or no competition with other products, it is likely to have a larger margin.

  • The amount of investment risk assumed by the insurer. Because insurers explicitly use margins to manage risk, a product that represents a larger amount of risk to the insurer is likely to have a larger margin. The risk-return tradeoff applies here, as the greater the risk the insurer assumes, the greater the potential return must be. Similarly, the lower the amount of risk the product represents to the insurer, the smaller the margin is likely to be.

  • The amount of investment risk assumed by the customer. Customers who purchase variable products assume greater risks than do those who purchase products with interest-rate guarantees, such as fixed-rate deferred annuities. In general, the greater the investment risk assumed by the customer, the lower the investment risk assumed by the insurer—and therefore, as described above, the smaller the margin is likely to be. Similarly, a product that presents a lower investment risk to the customer also presents a higher investment risk to the insurer, and therefore is likely to require a higher margin—which also makes the product vulnerable to interest rate compression.

  • The length of interest-rate guarantees. A product’s interest-rate guarantees affect the insurer’s risk in issuing the product. The insurer’s ability to revise a product’s crediting rate after the product has been issued reduces the risk associated with the product. The more frequently an insurer can revise a product’s crediting rate while the product is in force, the smaller the product’s margin is likely to be. Conversely, if the insurer is locked into longer-term interest-rate guarantees, the product represents a greater risk to the insurer and is likely to have a higher margin.

pages.title: Incorporating Operating Expense Charges into Product Designs
pages.contents:
Incorporating Operating Expense Charges into Product Designs

For some products such as immediate annuities, insurers do not disclose expenses to customers as separate charges, but rather incorporate expenses and other components of product design into the premium. For most life insurance products and deferred annuity products, insurers offset at least some operating expenses by means of explicit charges to customers. These charges can be one-time charges assessed at the time of purchase, or periodic charges assessed monthly, yearly, or at other predetermined intervals. The number and type of charges incorporated into a product structure depend partly on whether the product is fixed or variable.

 

Explicit Expense Charges in Fixed Products

Insurers typically classify the explicit expense charges included in fixed insurance and annuity products as administrative charges and transaction charges, as summarized in the chart below.

Administrative Charges

An administrative charge is a charge an insurer levies to cover the cost of issuing certain types of life insurance or annuity contracts, making administrative changes to such contracts, preparing contract owner statements, and performing general maintenance activities. Depending on how the company classifies its charges and expenses, administrative charges may also be known as administrative expense charges, administrative fees, contract fees, or service fees. Most administrative charges are assessed periodically. For universal life products, insurers typically calculate administrative charges as a flat amount per month based on the units of coverage. However, these administrative charges can also be calculated as a percentage of premium per period.

Fixed annuities generally do not assess explicit administrative charges. For fixed immediate annuities, the insurer factors administrative charges into the single premium payment. In fixed-rate deferred annuities, the interest spread covers applicable administrative expenses.

 

Transaction Charges

Transaction charges are one-time charges assessed when funds are paid into or withdrawn from a customer’s account. Transaction charges include sales charges and surrender charges.

Most insurers do not assess separate sales charges. Occasionally, however, insurers assess sales charges on fixed products when premiums are paid. In these cases, sales charges are designed to cover commissions and other sales costs. For fixed insurance products, sales charges are typically calculated as either a flat amount per transaction or a percentage of the amount of the transaction. Very few fixed-rate deferred annuities offered today assess sales charges; when such a product contains a sales charge, the charge is calculated as a percentage of the premium.

Insurers use surrender charges to provide protection against surrender and withdrawal rates that exceed projections. A surrender charge is a charge imposed when the owner of a cash value life insurance policy surrenders the policy for its cash surrender value, or if the owner of a deferred annuity contract surrenders the contract within a stated number of years after it was purchased. Insurers design surrender charges to cover acquisition, issue, and sales costs. For both fixed life insurance products and fixed-rate deferred annuities, surrender charges are a specified percentage of the amount received when the policy or contract is surrendered.

Insurers generally impose surrender charges that are highest during the early years of a contract and then decrease gradually over time.

A flat surrender charge might be $15 per unit for the first three years, after which the charge decreases by $1.50 per unit for each year thereafter until the charge disappears. A specified percentage surrender charge might be 8 percent of the amount withdrawn for the first year, after which the charge decreases by 1 percent each year until the charge disappears.

 

Explicit Expense Charges in Variable Products

The expense charges for variable products—or, as they are often called outside the United States and Canada, unit-linked products—can be categorized as administrative charges and transaction charges. U.S. securities laws require that all expense charges in variable products—including variable life insurance and variable annuity products—be disclosed separately.

 

Administrative Charges

The classification of expense charges varies from insurer to insurer. The following examples are some of the most commonly seen administrative charges on variable (unit-linked) life insurance and annuity products:

  • An insurer may periodically charge a general administrative charge to cover a variety of costs, such as making administrative changes to the contract and records, crediting investment earnings to contract accounts, and paying claims and annuity income benefits.

  • A common administrative charge in variable deferred annuities is a contract maintenance charge, which is a periodic charge assessed to cover general maintenance costs, such as preparation of account and other statements. Insurers typically express contract maintenance charges as a flat monetary amount per contract per month or per year. Insurers often waive contract maintenance charges for contracts whose value is above a specified amount, such as $50,000.

  • An insurer may assess a rider charge if the customer purchases a variable annuity guarantee rider. We discuss rider charges further in Chapter 11.

  • A mortality and expense (M&E) risk charge is a charge assessed to compensate the insurer for the mortality and expense risks inherent in the assumptions made when designing the product. The mortality portion of the risk charge covers the insurer’s obligation to provide mortality-based benefits such as guaranteed death benefits and lifetime annuity periodic payments. The expense portion of the risk charge covers the insurer’s obligation to administer the contract. A typical M&E risk charge ranges from 1.00 to 1.75 percent of the accumulated value.

  • A fund operating expense charge is a periodic charge that a fund manager assesses to cover its costs of managing variable subaccount assets, buying and selling securities, and administering trades. These charges are typically calculated as a percentage of the account values and are deducted from those values before earnings are distributed to shareholders.

 

Transaction Charges

Transaction charges for variable products can be divided into three categories: sales charges, transfer charges, and surrender charges.

The sales charges assessed on variable insurance and annuity products are designed to cover the insurer’s sales and contract issue costs and the costs of ongoing services provided by sales intermediaries. Funds that impose sales charges can structure these charges in one of the following ways:

  • A front-end sales charge is a one-time transaction charge imposed when an investor purchases shares in a subaccount. Front-end sales charges generally are calculated as a percentage of the amount invested.

  • A back-end sales charge is a sales charge assessed when an investor sells a security. In the context of life insurance and annuity products, the securities sold are typically shares in a subaccount fund. Back-end sales charges are calculated as a percentage of the amount sold.

Variable life insurance products generally include back-end sales charges. For variable annuity products, sales charges may be either front-end sales charges or, more commonly, back-end sales charges.

Surrender charges on variable products are designed to cover the costs of selling or redeeming fund shares to cover withdrawals or surrenders and are similar to the surrender charges assessed for fixed products. The amount of these charges is typically based on the amount withdrawn. As is the case with surrender charges for fixed products, surrender charges for variable products are structured on a decreasing scale.

Most insurers allow owners of variable contracts to transfer funds from one subaccount to another without charge, as long as the transfers fall within specified limits, such as amount or frequency. Transfer charges apply to transfers that exceed these limits. Charges for transfers in excess of allowed amounts are usually calculated as a percentage of the amount transferred.

pages.title: Additional Risk Management for Complex Products
pages.contents:
Additional Risk Management for Complex Products

In previous chapters, we discussed the overall strategies that insurers use to manage risks. During product design, insurers can establish some design features that help to manage product risks, including certain forms of policyholder behavior risk.

For life insurance and annuity products, surrender charges are one example of a design feature implemented to combat risk. Other features include

  • Restricting policy loan activity.

  • Employing adjustable interest rates for policy loans.

  • Incorporating nonguaranteed elements in product designs. Recall that NGEs allow an insurer to reward customers when the insurer has experienced or anticipates it will experience favorable deviations from its assumptions, or, conversely, allow the insurer to charge customers more when the insurer has experienced or anticipates it will experience unfavorable deviations from its assumptions. NGEs can be nonguaranteed benefits or nonguaranteed charges. Common examples of NGEs include (1) policy dividends on participating fixed premium life insurance policies; (2) premium adjustments for indeterminate premium products; (3) excess interest on universal life insurance, fixed-rate deferred annuities, and other products that credit interest at current rates; and (4) adjustments in periodic charges deducted from accumulated values.

Insurers also use design features that help manage product risks for more specific types of products.

 

Fixed and Fixed Fund Products

For fixed-rate universal life insurance, fixed-rate deferred annuities, and variable products that offer fixed fund options, additional design adjustments that can help in controlling a company’s product risks include

  • Designing a lower minimum guaranteed interest-crediting rate, where regulations permit.

  • Shortening the guarantee period for minimum guaranteed interest-crediting rates.

  • Decreasing current interest-crediting rates within allowable limits.

  • Decreasing the interval between declarations of new interest-crediting rates on fixed-interest asset accumulations.

  • Limiting withdrawals of account values by monetary amount, frequency, and percentage of account value.

 

Variable Products

Design adjustments to mitigate risk for variable universal life insurance and variable deferred annuities include

  • Discouraging market-timing abuses and controlling asset-trading costs by limiting customers’ movements of contract values between subaccounts in a specified period (by means of prohibition or assessing additional charges).

  • Limiting new premium additions to fixed accounts in a specified period, such as per calendar quarter.

  • Limiting reallocations of existing fund values to fixed accounts, such as placing a maximum monetary amount limit per account or limiting total fixed account allocations to a percentage of total allocations.

  • Limiting withdrawals of account values by monetary amount, frequency, and percentage of account value.

 

Variable Deferred Annuities

To address specific risks associated with variable deferred annuities, insurers can adjust product designs in several ways such as

  • Requiring waiting periods before a contract owner can begin withdrawing guaranteed income from the contract.

  • Imposing restrictions on the kinds of investments that contract owners can select.

  • Applying age-based guaranteed withdrawals, in which contract owners receive a higher guaranteed withdrawal rate if they delay drawing income until a specified age.

  • Using index-based guarantees, which help reduce an insurer’s capital market risk.

  • Using asset transfer algorithms, which dictate the transfer of assets between equity and fixed-income investments, depending on the direction of the market.

As you read in Chapter 6, effective technical product design enables an insurer to deliver on its contractual obligations while generating profit for the company. To achieve these dual objectives, the present value of a product’s future cash inflows should exceed, or at least equal, the present value of its future cash outflows, as illustrated in Figure 10.1.

An insurer needs sound actuarial assumptions to appropriately design its life insurance products. For instance, if a product’s mortality experience is unfavorable or the insurer’s investment returns underperform expectations, then profitability could suffer. Premium rates must also be reasonable; if rates are too high, then the insurer could lose customers to competitors that offer lower rates for similar products. In addition, profits that appear excessive are likely to attract regulatory scrutiny.

Recall that a product’s financial structure is made up of several components. As you can see in Figure 10.1, the product components representing cash inflows are premium payments from customers and the investment earnings on those premiums. Product components representing cash outflows are the charge for the cost of benefits, the charge for operating expenses, and the provision for adverse deviation—effectively, a margin that protects against potential losses on the product due to unfavorable experience. The provision for adverse deviation could turn into a contribution to the insurer’s earnings, as we will explain later.

In previous chapters, we discussed several of the product components, such as investment earnings and operating expenses. In this chapter, you’ll read about two more components: the cost of benefits and premiums. Before we get into the process for estimating the cost of benefits for different life insurance products, we’ll briefly describe some types of life insurance benefits and the types of pricing premiums that are designed to support them.

Once you have gained a deeper understanding of the cost of benefits component of a life insurance product’s design, you will see how all of the components work together to set the product’s premium rate. At the end of the chapter, we will present a basic example of how an insurer uses a product’s pricing premium rate to calculate an individual policyowner’s premium amount.

pages.title: Key Life Insurance Benefits
pages.contents:
Key Life Insurance Benefits

A single life insurance product can offer multiple benefits: death benefits, nonforfeiture values, and cash surrender values. In addition, life insurance may also offer additional benefits through policy riders, which represent additional benefit costs to the insurer. A product’s design must incorporate the costs of each benefit throughout the life of the product. Let’s explore these benefits.

 

Death Benefits

The death benefit is the primary policy benefit payable by a life insurer when an insured dies while the policy is in force. All life insurance products are designed to pay a death benefit when the insured dies, but the exact timing of the death—and the subsequent benefit payout, payout type, and payout timing—is uncertain. Whether a death benefit will be payable is also uncertain because the policy may lapse or expire before the insured dies.

As you have read in previous chapters, insurers determine the probability that death benefits will be payable in a given year by referring to mortality tables. Thus, the mortality cost, or cost to provide death benefits, for a group of life insureds depends in part on the mortality rate.

  • In general, the higher the mortality rate for a group of life insureds of the same age and sex, the higher the cost of benefits and, thus, the higher the premium rate.

  • Conversely, the lower the mortality rate for a group of life insureds of the same age and sex, the lower the cost of benefits and the lower the premium rate.

Recall from Chapter 8 that insurers generally use mortality rates to estimate the number of expected deaths within a group of insureds. Using that estimate, an insurer can calculate the mortality cost for a block of policies, as seen in the following formula:

Mortality cost = Expected number of death benefit payments × Amount of the average benefit payment

Later in this chapter, you’ll learn more about calculating the mortality cost for one-year term life, multiyear term life, whole life, and universal life insurance products.

 

Nonforfeiture Values and Cash Surrender Values

Although cash value life insurance products are designed to remain in force for a relatively long time before benefits become payable, policyowners sometimes stop paying premiums—which, depending on the type of product, can cause their policies to lapse. For these policyowners, an important benefit is the nonforfeiture value, which is the benefit that an insurer guarantees to a policyowner if the insurance contract lapses.

Other cash value life insurance policyowners may decide to voluntarily surrender their policies. In the case of a policy surrender, the insurer pays out the cash surrender value—also known as the surrender value or surrender benefit—which is the amount of the cash value that a policyowner is entitled to receive from the insurer upon surrender of the policy. Before paying the cash surrender value, the insurer first subtracts any surrender charges, as well as adjustments for other factors, such as policy loans. Note that for surrender benefits to be payable, an in-force policy must have accumulated a cash value at the time of surrender.

Insurers must account for nonforfeiture values and cash surrender values during the product design of cash value life insurance products. A detailed description of the calculation of nonforfeiture values and cash surrender values is beyond the scope of this course.

Lapses and surrenders can be costly for insurers because they (1) eliminate future income streams from premium payments, and (2) can prevent an insurer from recovering its product costs. However, insurers can often reduce the negative effects of lapses and surrenders by adding margins to the expense amounts in their product designs. Such margins provide a cushion in case actual expenses caused by adverse policyowner behavior exceed anticipated expenses. Insurers can also reduce the impact of lapses and surrenders by assessing surrender charges on policy lapses or surrenders that occur during a policy’s early years.

 

Benefits Offered Through Policy Riders

Insurers offer life insurance policies that include supplemental benefits; these benefits are usually added as riders to a policy and require the policyowner to pay an additional premium. Examples of life insurance policy riders that insurers commonly add to policies are waiver of premium benefits, accidental death benefits, and accelerated death benefits—such as critical illness benefits and long-term care insurance benefits. Later in the chapter, we will outline considerations for calculating the cost of such benefits.

 

Waiver of Premium Benefits

One type of waiver of premium benefit is the waiver of premium for disability benefit, under which the insurer promises to give up its right to collect premiums that become due while the insured is disabled according to the policy or rider’s definition of disability. Premiums are generally waived throughout the life of the policy as long as the insured remains totally disabled.

Another type of waiver of premium benefit is the waiver of premium for payor benefit, in which the insurer waives its right to collect a policy’s renewal premiums if the payor—the person paying the policy premiums—dies or becomes totally disabled. A waiver of premium for payor benefit is often included as a rider to a juvenile insurance policy; when this is the case, the rider usually states that the insurer will waive premium payments only until the insured reaches a specified age, such as 18 or 21.

 

Accidental Death Benefits

An accidental death benefit requires the insurer to pay a specified amount of money in addition to the policy’s basic death benefit if an insured dies as a result of an accident. Generally, the accidental death benefit is payable if the insured’s death was caused—directly and independently of all other causes—by an accidental bodily injury.

The payment of a policy’s basic death benefit is not contingent upon its accidental death benefit being payable. For example, if the insurer of a life insurance policy with an accidental death benefit rider determines that the policy’s basic death benefit is payable to the beneficiary, but the insured’s death was not caused by an accident, then the beneficiary would only receive the amount of the basic death benefit.

 

Accelerated Death Benefits

Typically, life insurance death benefits are payable only after the insured’s death. However, as people today live longer than ever before and require costly medical care, some policies include accelerated death benefits. An accelerated death benefit, also known as a living benefit, typically allows a policyowner to elect to receive all or part of the policy’s death benefit before the insured’s death if certain conditions are met. The payment of an accelerated death benefit usually reduces the death benefit that will be paid to the beneficiary at the insured’s death. Two types of accelerated death benefits are the critical illness benefit and the long-term care (LTC) insurance benefit.

  • Under a critical illness benefit—also known as a dread disease benefit—the insurer agrees to pay a portion of the policy’s face amount to the policyowner if the insured suffers from one of a number of specified diseases. Insureds become eligible for critical illness benefits when they have insurable events, which are certain diseases, events, or medical procedures specified in the rider, such as life-threatening cancer, coronary artery bypass surgery, myocardial infarction (heart attack), and stroke.

  • With a long-term care (LTC) insurance benefit, the insurer agrees to pay a monthly benefit to the policyowner if the insured requires constant care for a medical condition. The types of care given and the medical condition required to qualify for the LTC benefit are specified in the LTC policy rider.

Generally, the amount of each monthly LTC benefit payable is equal to a stated percentage of the policy’s face amount. The insurer usually pays monthly benefits until a specified percentage of the face amount has been paid out; any remaining death benefit is paid to the beneficiary after the insured’s death.

pages.title: Types of Pricing Premiums
pages.contents:
Types of Pricing Premiums

To cover the costs of providing life insurance policy benefits, actuaries must determine the proper premium rates to charge. In addition, the premium rates must enable the insurer to cover the costs of developing and administering products, as well as to generate a reasonable profit.

Insurance companies use premiums for both reserves and pricing. The portion of premiums used for reserves are set aside to pay future contract obligations and meet mandated reserve requirements. Every type of premium we discuss in this chapter is a type of pricing premium. A pricing premium is the monetary amount per unit of coverage that an insurer must collect from customers to cover any portion of the product’s cost of benefits or the insurer’s costs for supporting the product that is not covered by investment earnings.

For our purposes, pricing premiums can take the following forms:

  • A single premium, which is a form of premium payment in which one lump sum covers all of the financial considerations—such as operating expenses and cost of benefits—for the life of the contract. Single premiums typically purchase one-year term life insurance policies.

  • Level premiums, which are periodic premium payments that are equal in amount and are generally paid monthly, quarterly, or annually. Typically, level premiums purchase multiyear term life insurance and whole life insurance policies.

  • Flexible premiums, which allow policyowners to make payments to the insurer at various times so as to increase the savings element in a contract that was established with a single initial premium. Flexible premiums typically purchase universal life insurance policies.

In establishing a premium rate for a particular product, actuaries don’t calculate specific rates for individual policies; instead, they develop a rate for a block of policies. Thus, in this chapter’s examples, we will describe the process for calculating the cost of benefits for a sample block of policies. (For educational purposes, we have simplified the discussion. Because product design is complex, actuaries generally use product development software to perform necessary calculations.)

Throughout this chapter, as we calculate the cost of benefits, remember that insurers must also account for expenses such as commissions and taxes, along with other cash outflows. So, for a given product, the associated charges will be greater than the cost of benefits charge alone.

Because the death benefit is the primary policy benefit payable on a life insurance policy, we dedicate a significant portion of this chapter to describing mortality cost calculations for one-year term life, multiyear term life, whole life, and universal life insurance products.

pages.title: Cost of Benefits for One-Year Term Life Insurance
pages.contents:
Cost of Benefits for One-Year Term Life Insurance

As stated earlier, a single premium purchases a one-year term life insurance policy. One-year term life insurance—which is the simplest life insurance product—pays a death benefit only if the insured person dies during the year that the policy is in force. Because term life insurance policies usually do not accumulate cash values, actuaries do not need to calculate nonforfeiture values. Therefore, to determine the cost of benefits component of a one-year term life policy’s single premium, actuaries are primarily focused on estimating the mortality cost. The general steps for finding the mortality cost for a one-year term life policy include

  • Projecting the number of insureds who will die while the product is in force

  • Determining the average amount of the death benefit paid within a block of policies

  • Estimating the future value of the death benefits for the entire block

  • Finding the present value of the block’s future death benefits

 

Projecting the Number of Death Benefits

The insurer’s first step in calculating the mortality cost for a block of one-year term life insurance policies is to project the number of death benefits it expects to pay. The number of death benefits for the block equals the number of insureds who die during the year that the policies are in force. Insurers use the mortality rates provided in mortality tables to project the number of deaths for the block.

 

Determining the Average Death Benefit Amount

Then, the insurer needs to determine the average amount of the death benefit paid during the period. Because an insurer typically calculates the cost of benefits for a particular block of business, the average amount of a death benefit is equal to the average face amount of the policies in the block.

 

Estimating the Future Death Benefits

The formula for calculating the future death benefit payments for a block of term life policies is

Estimate of future death benefits = Total number of insured deaths during the period × Average amount of a death benefit

As you can see, an insurer can estimate a value for the block’s future death benefits payable by multiplying the number of death benefits it expects to pay during the period by the average amount of a death benefit. Let’s see an example.

EXAMPLE

Cardmore Insurance Company is estimating the mortality cost for a block of 10,000 one-year term life insurance policies. The block of policies is issued to men, age 35. For this estimate, the company consults the chosen mortality table and applies a mortality rate of 0.65 per 1,000 lives. The mortality rate for one life equals the tabular mortality rate divided by the number of lives—1,000—as shown:

0.65 ÷ 1,000 = 0.00065

Using the mortality rate for one life, Cardmore can project an average of how many insureds out of 10,000 will die during the year. The company multiplies the mortality rate for one life by the number of insureds in the block:

0.00065 × 10,000 = 6.5 deaths

Thus, Cardmore expects to pay an average of 6.5 death benefits per 10,000 insureds during the one-year term of this product. Each policy in the block has a $100,000 face amount. Therefore, we can use our future death benefits formula to project the total amount of expected future death benefits for this block:

Estimate of future death benefits = Total number of insured deaths during the period × Average amount of a death benefit
  = 6.5 deaths × $100,000 face amount per policy
  = $650,000

Analysis: Based on its actuarial estimate of 6.5 deaths for this particular block of policies, Cardmore Insurance Company should expect to pay $650,000 in death benefits. Obviously, 6.5 people cannot die in a given year. However, for pricing purposes, the actuarial estimate of 6.5 is more precise than using 6.0 or 7.0 as the number of projected deaths in the block during the year.

 

Finding the Present Value of Future Death Benefits

The present value of the future death benefits is the amount the insurer would need to invest at an assumed interest rate at the product’s inception to precisely cover the product’s estimated future death benefits. This assumed interest rate represents the insurer’s projected rate of return on the invested premiums.

Mortality tables indicate the estimated number of deaths that are likely to occur within a given year, but they do not indicate the actual dates during the year when deaths will occur. Although deaths and death benefit payments are likely to occur throughout the year, insurers often simplify calculations by assuming that all death benefits will be paid at a specific point during the year.

In our discussion, we assume that all death benefits are paid at the exact midpoint of the year. This assumption requires discounting death benefits for a specified period, n, of one-half year. Thus, an insurer would multiply the total amount of death benefits for a block of policies by the present value interest factor (PVIF) for a specified interest rate, i, and period of n = ½.

EXAMPLE

The insurance company from the previous example, Cardmore, wants to find the present value of the future death benefits it estimated: $650,000. Assume the interest rate is 7%; the corresponding PVIF for a 7% interest rate and a ½-year period equals 0.967. Cardmore finds the present value of the future death benefits as follows:

Present value of future death benefits for block of policies = Estimated future death benefits × PVIF
  = $650,000 × 0.967
  = $628,550

Analysis: $628,550 is the present value of the future death benefits for this block of 10,000 policies. Therefore, if Cardmore invests $628,550 today, it should earn enough on its investments to pay out $650,000 by the end of the one-year term.

pages.title: Cost of Benefits for Multiyear Term Life Insurance
pages.contents:
Cost of Benefits for Multiyear Term Life Insurance

Like the cost of benefits calculations for one-year term insurance, the cost of benefits calculations for multiyear term life insurance products involve estimating the present value of the cost of the death benefits. However, cost of benefits calculations for multiyear term life insurance products must address two issues that are not generally involved in annual premium calculations for one-year term life products:

  • Level annual premiums

  • Lapse rates (if a premium calculation is done on a monthly basis, some one-year term policies may account for lapse rates)

Policyowners generally purchase multiyear term life insurance products with a series of level annual premiums. A level annual premium (LAP) is any set of equal annual payments having a present value equal to a given single premium. Level annual premiums allow policyowners to pay the same premium amount for the stipulated duration of years from issue. For example, a policy with a 10-year LAP would state the premium as level for ten years.

To cover the insurer’s cost of benefits—and the other premium components, such as operating expenses—actuaries must find a LAP amount for which the sum of the present values of the premium payments is equivalent to the present value of a hypothetical single premium. We’ll provide an example of such a calculation later in the chapter. (For simplicity, the mortality cost will be the only component we’ll calculate.)

For a block of multiyear term life insurance policies, the number of insureds decreases each year because some insureds die and others allow their policies to lapse. Year-by-year decreases in the number of insured lives in the block affect the cost of benefits for the block in the following ways:

  • The number of premium payments the insurer collects from the block of policies decreases each year.

  • Lapses that occur in the early policy years may prevent the insurer from fully recovering the acquisition expenses associated with the block of policies.

We’ll use the following steps to illustrate the process of estimating the mortality cost for a block of multiyear term life insurance policies:

  • Project the number of benefit payments for the term’s duration

  • Determine the average amount of death benefit paid within the block of policies

  • Estimate the future value of death benefits for the entire block

  • Find the present value of the block’s future death benefits

  • Calculate the monetary amount of the level annual premium (LAP)

 

Projecting the Number of Benefit Payments

To calculate the total number of death benefit payments for a block of multiyear term insurance policies, an insurer must (1) calculate the number of benefit payments for each year in the term, and (2) sum the numbers to find the total number of payments. In other words, the insurer must project the total number of deaths for the duration of the term.

In the first year of the block’s term, the insurer multiplies the number of insureds at the beginning of the year by the appropriate mortality rate to project the number of deaths expected during the year.

After the first year, the insurer must account for both policy lapses and insured deaths. To calculate the projected number of deaths in the block for a particular year—and the number of resulting death benefit payments—the insurer first takes the number of insureds remaining at the beginning of that year and subtracts the number of insureds withdrawing (as estimated by applying the lapse rate). The result is the number of surviving insureds associated with in-force policies in the block. Next, the insurer applies the appropriate mortality rate to this number to find the number of insureds in the block who are expected to die by the end of that particular year.

The insurer repeats these calculations to find the number of deaths for each year in the term. Once the insurer has calculated the number of expected deaths for every year, it sums the numbers. The total number of deaths represents the number of benefit payments the insurer expects to make during the entire term.

 

Determining the Average Death Benefit Amount

Next, the insurer needs to determine the average amount of the death benefit paid within the block. To find this amount, the insurer sums the face amounts for all the policies in the block of business and divides by the number of policies in the block.

 

Estimating the Future Death Benefits

Then, the insurer multiplies the average death benefit amount by the number of deaths in a particular year to find the value of the death benefits for that year. The insurer performs these calculations for every year and sums the death benefit values to find the total value for the term. The following example shows how an insurer estimates the total value of the death benefits it will pay on a block of five-year term life insurance policies.

Finding the Present Value of Future Death Benefits

To calculate the present value of the death benefits for a multiyear term life insurance product, the insurer must calculate the present value of the death benefits for each year in the policy’s term rather than for a single year. Thus, each year’s estimated future death benefits are multiplied by the appropriate PVIF.

Note that we are assuming that all death benefit payments are occurring at the midpoint of the year. We made the same assumption in our discussion of one-year term life insurance. If we were to assume that payments occurred at the end of the year, the difference in timing would change the PVIFs used.

Once the insurer has calculated the present value of the death benefits for each year in the term, it can sum the present values to find the present value of the block’s total death benefits. This number, which represents the single premium, is important in determining the level annual premium. In the previous section, the insurer applied PVIFs to find the single premium. Now, it must apply PVIFs to find the LAP.
