pages.title: Cost of Benefits for Whole Life Insurance
pages.contents:
Cost of Benefits for Whole Life Insurance

When discussing the cost of benefits for one-year and multiyear term life insurance products, we were primarily focused on death benefits, as mortality cost was a significant factor in setting premiums for those products. Setting premiums for whole life insurance is similar to setting premiums for term life insurance and consists of calculating premiums and setting margins. Again, the goal of the process is to calculate the present value of the cost of benefits.

However, whole life insurance has two features that are usually not present for one-year and most multiyear term life insurance products:

  • Death benefit coverage while the policy remains in force during the lifetime of the insured (rather than for a limited number of years, in the case of term life products without continuation provisions)

  • Cash value and surrender benefits

To estimate future benefit payments for whole life insurance, actuaries must estimate the timing and average amount of

  • Death benefits for each year, using an appropriate mortality table

  • Lapses and surrender benefits, based on the number of insureds at the beginning of each year, the expected lapse or surrender rates for each year, and the surrender value per unit, as follows:

Annual surrender = Number of insureds at beginning of year × Lapse or surrender rate × Surrender value per unit

In calculating the total future benefits for most whole life insurance products, the following assumptions generally apply:

  • Level annual premiums are collected at the beginning of each year.

  • Death benefits are paid at the midpoint of each year.

  • Surrender benefits do not begin until the policy has been in force for several years. (Most products do not build a cash value until the policy has been in force for several years.) When surrender benefits become payable, we assume they are paid at the beginning of each year.

  • The final benefit payments for this plan of insurance will be made when the insured group reaches an advanced age, such as age 120.

To finalize the premium calculations for a whole life insurance product, the insurer would first calculate a single premium and then set level periodic premium amounts to derive a LAP, as previously shown.

pages.title: Cost of Benefits for Universal Life Insurance
pages.contents:
Cost of Benefits for Universal Life Insurance

So far, we have discussed the cost of benefit calculations for term life insurance products and whole life insurance, a type of permanent life insurance product. Another form of permanent life product is universal life (UL) insurance, which is characterized by flexible premiums, a flexible face amount, a flexible death benefit amount, and separation of the three primary policy elements—mortality charges, interest rate, and expense charges.

In some forms of UL policies, the cash value amount is reduced by significant expense charges, called surrender charges, if the policyowner chooses to surrender the policy. For these types of UL policies, regulators may require insurance companies to use another term—such as account value or accumulation value—to describe the cash value that accumulates in the policy. In addition, a second term—either net cash value or cash surrender value—describes the amount available to policyowners. For simplicity, we will use the term cash value in connection with universal life policies.

In this section, you’ll learn more about the characteristics of UL insurance. Then, you’ll read about considerations when calculating the cost of benefits for a block of UL policies.

 

Universal Life Insurance Overview

UL insurance is available in a number of varieties. In this chapter, we limit our discussion to basic fixed universal life (UL) insurance, indexed universal life (IUL) insurance, and variable universal life (VUL) insurance. Regardless of the form of UL insurance, UL policies are subject to different kinds of charges, which insurers deduct from cash values.

 

Types of Universal Life Insurance

Basic fixed UL insurance pays at least a stated guaranteed minimum interest-crediting rate on a policy’s cash value. The insurer also provides for a higher current interest-crediting rate if economic and competitive conditions warrant.

Indexed universal life (IUL) insurance, also called equity indexed universal life insurance, is a type of universal life insurance that offers certain principal value and earnings guarantees, but also offers the possibility of additional earnings by linking the cash value to a published index, such as the S&P 500. An IUL policy’s cash value is backed by the insurer’s general account assets and is generally divided into two policy accounts:

  • A fixed account, in which the crediting rate is a guaranteed minimum interest-crediting rate, similar to basic fixed UL insurance products.

  • An index account, in which the crediting rate is determined by changes in an index. The index-crediting rate is subject to a guaranteed minimum crediting rate—typically called the floor—and a maximum crediting rate—typically called the cap.

The main attraction of IUL is that it offers additional gains in the cash value when the market is strong, with relatively little risk because of the guarantees from the fixed account’s crediting rate and the index account’s floor. The floor limits the product’s investment risk, whereas the cap limits the product’s growth potential. Thus, IUL has a fairly conservative risk-reward structure.

Variable universal life (VUL) insurance is a version of UL insurance that combines the premium and death benefit flexibility of universal life insurance with the investment flexibility and risk of variable life insurance. VUL owners have the option to allocate the cash value to the insurer’s general account or to invest in various subaccounts (or fund options) of the insurer’s separate account. Typically, the VUL owner may change his allocations at least annually.

VUL policies do not guarantee minimum investment earnings or cash values for premiums allocated to subaccounts. Instead, the insurer’s credits to the cash value directly reflect the net investment earnings of the subaccounts. Thus, VUL insurance provides higher potential rewards than basic fixed UL insurance and IUL insurance, but with higher risks.

 

Deductions from Universal Life Policy Components

As with other life insurance products, UL product designs must cover the insurer’s costs of supporting the product. Actuaries determine the policy charges that apply to the insurer’s expenses associated with UL insurance and then add a margin to (1) cover the risk that the actual expenses will exceed expected expenses and (2) provide a profit on the product. Each expected expense and the margin added to that expense constitute the amount of that particular policy charge.

A UL policy specifies separate deductions from the cash value for various policy elements—such as expense charges, mortality charges, and, in some situations, surrender charges. You read about some of these charges in previous chapters.

UL policy charges are typically deducted from policy values at various times while the policy is in force, depending on policy provisions. For instance, the insurer may deduct

  • Charges from the premium payment before the premium amount is added to the policy’s cash value

  • Charges from the policy’s cash value on a monthly basis

  • A surrender charge from the policy’s cash value at the time of a surrender or partial withdrawal

For VUL insurance, charges may be deducted from the policy’s investment returns, typically whenever the cash value is calculated.

  • The mortality and expense (M&E) charge is typically a percentage of the cash value.

  • The investment management charge is typically deducted from the subaccount value.

Insurers have different ways of calculating UL mortality charges, depending on the form of death benefit that the policy specifies.

 

Universal Life Death Benefits

UL insurance products allow for different forms of death benefits, as you will see. The different options available to policyowners affect how actuaries calculate the mortality cost. Insurers use death benefit calculations to determine the monthly mortality charges for UL policies.

 

Universal Life Death Benefit Options

As seen in the table below, UL death benefits can take three alternative forms: a level amount death benefit, an increasing amount death benefit, and a level amount plus premiums death benefit. These three options are usually known as Option A, Option B, and Option C. (Some insurance companies use the terms Option I, Option II, and Option III.) Under all of the options, the policyowner chooses the face amount and may adjust this amount at any time.

Form

Description of Form

Death Benefit

Option A

Level Amount Death Benefit Plan

Face Amount

Option B

Increasing Amount Death Benefit Plan

Face Amount + Cash Value

Option C

Level Amount Plus Premiums Death Benefit Plan

Face Amount + Premiums Paid
 

Calculating the Net Amount at Risk

Although definitions vary from one contract to another, a UL policy’s net amount at risk generally represents the amount of the insurer’s funds that would be required at any given time to pay the policy death benefit. As we have previously stated, the insurer manages its general account assets so it can cover policy cash values, among other things. Therefore, at any given time, a UL policy’s net amount at risk equals the difference between the death benefit and the cash value.

Net Amount at Risk = Death Benefit – Cash Value

The net amount at risk is the remaining amount of money that the insurer would need to pay the policy’s death claim. Thus, for a UL policy, the net amount at risk is a better measure of the insurer’s cost of benefits than the death benefit. Figure 10.2 illustrates how the insurer’s net amount at risk for a given UL policy changes over time.

Using the UL death benefit information from the table in the previous section, we can derive the net amount at risk formulas for each death benefit option, as demonstrated in Video 10.1.

The differences between the UL death benefit options are easier to recognize when we enter values into the net amount at risk formulas. First, let’s see an example of the net amount at risk calculation for a policy with an Option A plan.

EXAMPLE

Justin Morton, age 45, is the policyowner-insured of a UL insurance policy issued by Lowfive Insurance Company. His policy has a face amount of $200,000 and a cash value of $50,000. Because Justin’s policy has an Option A plan, Lowfive’s net amount at risk on his policy is found as follows:

Net Amount at Risk = Face Amount – Cash Value
Net Amount at Risk = $200,000 – $50,000
Net Amount at Risk = $150,000

After one year, the policy’s face amount remains $200,000 and its cash value has grown to $75,000. Thus, the insurer’s net amount at risk decreases to $125,000, found as follows:

Net Amount at Risk = Face Amount – Cash Value
Net Amount at Risk = $200,000 – $75,000
Net Amount at Risk = $125,000

Analysis: In both scenarios, the policy’s death benefit was equal to the face amount, or $200,000. However, Lowfive’s net amount at risk decreased from the first scenario to the second. Therefore, we see that for a UL policy with an Option A plan—assuming the face amount remains the same—as the policy’s cash value grows, the insurer’s net amount at risk decreases.

Now, let’s examine the same policy with an Option B death benefit plan.

EXAMPLE

As before, Justin’s policy has a face amount of $200,000 and a cash value of $50,000. Because Justin’s policy has an Option B plan, his policy’s death benefit is $250,000, calculated as follows:

Death Benefit = Face Amount + Cash Value
Death Benefit = $200,000 + $50,000
Death Benefit = $250,000

In addition, Lowfive’s net amount at risk is as follows:

Net Amount at Risk = (Face Amount + Cash Value) – Cash Value
Net Amount at Risk = ($200,000 + $50,000) – $50,000
Net Amount at Risk = $200,000

Again, after one year, the policy’s face amount remains $200,000 and its cash value has grown to $75,000. The death benefit and net amount at risk are calculated as follows:

Death Benefit = Face Amount + Cash Value
Death Benefit = $200,000 + $75,000
Death Benefit = $275,000
Net Amount at Risk = (Face Amount + Cash Value) - Cash Value
Net Amount at Risk = ($200,000 + $75,000) – $75,000
Net Amount at Risk = $200,000

Analysis: In one year, the policy’s death benefit grew from $250,000 to $275,000. However, Lowfive’s net amount at risk—$200,000—remained the same. Therefore, for a UL policy with an Option B plan, as the policy’s cash value grows, the death benefit grows. Assuming the face amount doesn’t change, the insurer’s net amount at risk stays constant.

Lastly, we have an example of the net amount at risk and death benefit calculations if Justin’s policy has an Option C plan.

EXAMPLE

Justin’s policy has a face amount of $200,000 and a cash value of $50,000. To date, Justin has paid $7,000 in premiums. The policy’s death benefit is calculated as follows:

Death Benefit = Face Amount + Premiums Paid
Death Benefit = $200,000 + $7,000
Death Benefit = $207,000

Lowfive’s net amount at risk is calculated as follows:

Net Amount at Risk = (Face Amount + Premiums Paid) – Cash Value
Net Amount at Risk = ($200,000 + $7,000) – $50,000
Net Amount at Risk = $157,000

Analysis: Under the Option C plan, the policy’s death benefit changes when Justin pays more premiums—or adjusts the policy’s face amount—but not when the cash value changes. Lowfive’s net amount at risk will fluctuate depending on the amount of premiums that Justin pays and any changes to the policy’s cash value.

 

Calculating the Monthly Mortality Charge

For UL insurance, two estimates are required to find the cost of benefits: (1) the number of death benefits in a month—estimated by applying the mortality rate—and (2) the average death benefit amount. Typically, the monthly mortality rate applied varies by gender and underwriting risk class and increases as the insureds age.

Two monthly mortality rates apply to UL products:

  • The guaranteed maximum mortality rate is specified in the contract and sets an upper limit on the mortality charge. The insurer guarantees not to charge a rate higher than the guaranteed maximum mortality rate.

  • The current mortality rate is the monthly mortality rate actually used to calculate the monthly mortality charge and is generally substantially lower than the guaranteed maximum mortality rate. The current mortality rate represents the expected mortality rate plus a mortality margin. (Think of the mortality margin as a type of provision for adverse deviation that specifically applies to mortality costs and mortality charges.) The formula to calculate the current mortality rate is

Current mortality rate = Expected mortality rate + Mortality margin

When calculating a UL product’s monthly mortality charge, the insurer makes a reasonable assumption as to a death benefit amount and uses that amount to set a rate that can be applied to contracts of any size. Generally, the benefit amount for a UL policy is considered to be the insurer’s net amount at risk. Thus, for UL products, the insurer develops a monthly mortality charge in accordance with a certain level of net amount at risk.

The insurer could develop a mortality charge per $1,000 of net amount at risk, based on the assumption that the average death benefit amount is $1,000. Then, for a UL policy with a net amount at risk of $10,000, the insurer could charge ten times the mortality charge developed for a policy with a net amount of risk of $1,000. Some insurers may “band” the mortality rate so that the higher the net amount at risk, the lower the mortality rate per $1,000.

To finalize an estimate of the cost of benefits, we must multiply the average benefit cost by the average benefit amount—in this case, the net amount at risk. For each UL contract, the insurer applies a selected mortality rate to the net amount at risk to calculate a monthly mortality charge. Monthly mortality rates indicate to the insurer how many insureds are likely to die within each month.

EXAMPLE

Hannah Kendall is insured under a UL policy issued by Charion Insurance Company. The insurer has determined that its net amount at risk for her policy is $100,000—which represents 100 units of $1,000 of insurance (found as $100,000 ÷ $1,000). In addition, Charion’s calculated monthly mortality charge for Hannah’s policy is $0.57 per $1,000 of insurance. Thus, the insurer calculates the total monthly mortality charge for Hannah’s policy as follows:

Monthly mortality charge (per $1,000 of net amount at risk) × units per $1,000 of net amount at risk = Total monthly mortality charge
$0.57 × 100 units = $57.00

Now, suppose that Charion’s net amount at risk for Hannah’s policy changes to $200,000—which represents 200 units per $1,000 of net amount at risk. In this case, the total monthly mortality charge would be $114.00 ($0.57 × 200).

Analysis: Because Charion’s net amount at risk increased in the second scenario, the total monthly mortality charge increased. Likewise, if the net amount at risk had decreased, the amount of the total monthly mortality charge would have been lower.

The monthly mortality charge is often combined with a separate monthly expense charge, and the resulting combination is called a monthly policy charge. For UL products, the insurer uses expense analysis techniques to set a monthly expense charge to cover its expenses. The formula to calculate the monthly policy charge is

Monthly policy charge = Monthly expense charge + Monthly mortality charge

pages.title: Cost of Benefits for Riders
pages.contents:
Cost of Benefits for Riders

Throughout this chapter, you have seen how life insurance companies use mortality rates to project the mortality cost for a block of similar policies. Insurers generally model the cost of benefits for each policy rider in a similar way.

Recall from Chapter 6 that the projected cost of benefits generally equals the sum of each potential benefit payment to a policyowner multiplied by the expected probability that the benefit will be payable, as seen in in the following formula:

Projected cost of a single benefit for a given policy year = Potential benefit amount payable × Probability that the benefit will be payable

In general, riders present antiselection risks to insurers. Remember that antiselection risk is the risk of loss or adverse product performance due to the tendency of individuals who believe they have a greater-than-average likelihood of loss to seek insurance protection to a greater extent than do those who believe they have an average or a less-than-average likelihood of loss. For instance, a proposed insured who is convinced she will eventually have a critical illness is more likely than the average proposed insured to seek attachment of a critical illness benefit rider to her policy. Therefore, actuaries take antiselection risk into consideration when assessing the probability that a particular rider benefit will be payable.

×

pages.title: Setting Pricing Premium Rates
pages.contents:
Setting Pricing Premium Rates

While this chapter has gone into depth about estimating the cost of benefits, setting a product’s pricing premiums involves other financial components. Figure 10.3 illustrates the relationships between the premium components that we have covered in this text.

You read about one such component, investment earnings, in Chapter 7. An insurer invests a portion of the premiums it receives and expects to achieve investment earnings. Investment earnings enable the insurer to set a product’s base premium lower than the sum of its expected cost of benefits and operating expenses. In other words, investment earnings should offset some of the charges necessary to support the product.

In Chapter 9, we discussed another component, operating expenses. When designing products, actuaries develop conservative estimates for both operating expenses and cost of benefits. For instance, an insurer may project a mortality rate that is higher than expected to ensure that the product’s premium rate will be more than adequate.

Conservatism in developing actuarial assumptions provides a buffer that allows for adverse deviation. Thus, each product has a built-in margin for error. If deviations are positive—that is, a product’s actual expenses are less than its expected expenses—then the result is extra profit for the insurer. Stated differently, positive deviations become contributions to the company’s earnings.

As you saw in Figure 10.3, actuaries use the premium components to calculate the premium for a block of policies. Then, they establish the premium rate for the block by dividing the single premium by the number of policies in the block. The premium rate is expressed as a basic amount of insurance coverage called the unit of coverage. For life insurance, a unit of coverage usually is $1,000 of coverage. To find the premium amount to charge for a particular policy, the insurer multiplies the premium rate by the number of coverage units.

EXAMPLE

Whyzee Insurance Company’s actuaries determine that the annual premium rate for a block of whole life insurance policies is $4.50 per $1,000 of coverage. The insurer wants to calculate the annual premium amount for one of the block’s policyowners, Darren Schneider. The face amount of Darren’s policy is $500,000.

Analysis: Darren’s policy has 500 units of coverage, found as $500,000 ÷ $1,000. Whyzee multiplies the annual premium rate by the number of coverage units to find the amount of Darren’s annual premium payment:

$4.50 × 500 = $2,250

The product’s premium rate represents the base rate that the insurer charges to policyowners in the block. In addition, other factors affect the premium rate that the insurer actually charges a particular policyowner. For instance, an underwriter may assess a proposed insured as a substandard risk. In that case, the insurer would charge the policyowner a higher premium rate than owners of policies with insureds that are classified as standard risks.

pages.title: Types of Annuities
pages.contents:
Types of Annuities

An annuity is a contract between an insurer and a contract owner, who applies for and funds the annuity. In most annuity contracts, the contract owner is also the annuitant, whose lifetime the insurer uses to determine the amount and duration of periodic income payments payable under the contract. (Unless stated otherwise, assume that this chapter is discussing life annuities, which provide periodic income payments for the lifetime of the annuitant.)

Typically, the annuitant is the person who receives periodic income payments from the insurer. However, the contract owner could designate a payee to receive the payments instead of the annuitant. For simplicity, in this chapter, we assume that the contract owner is also the annuitant, and that the annuitant is also the payee and therefore receiving the insurer’s periodic income payments.

During the annuity contract’s payout period, also known as the liquidation period, the insurer makes periodic income payments to the annuitant. The annuitant may want payments to begin right away, or may prefer to wait for the contract to build more value before receiving payments. To accommodate either preference, insurers provide two basic types of annuity products:

  • Immediate annuities, under which periodic income payments begin no more than one year after the contract is purchased. For example, a person who is about to retire might use a lump-sum amount to buy an immediate annuity that begins making monthly payments within 30 days.

  • Deferred annuities, under which periodic income payments are scheduled to begin at least one year after the contract’s purchase date. Deferred annuities provide the opportunity for invested premiums to grow during the accumulation period, which begins on the contract’s purchase date and runs until either the beginning of the payout period or the date when the owner terminates the contract. Typically, the contract’s accumulated value fluctuates during the accumulation period. At some point in the future, a deferred annuity contract owner could choose to annuitize the contract. The process of annuitization converts the contract’s accumulated value into periodic income payments. In practice, many deferred annuity contracts are never annuitized.

For an immediate annuity, the issue date marks the beginning of the payout period. If a deferred annuity is annuitized, the beginning of the payout period is known as the maturity date or the conversion date. Figure 11.1 illustrates the periods and timing of periodic income payments for both an immediate and deferred annuity.

Annuity products also vary based on investment risks and principal guarantees. Thus, annuities can generally be categorized as fixed annuities or variable annuities.

 

Fixed Annuities

With a fixed annuity, the insurer guarantees (1) the minimum interest rate that it will apply to any accumulated value and (2) the minimum amount of the annuity payments that it will pay. Depending on the contract owner’s choices, a fixed annuity is also either an immediate annuity or a deferred annuity.

For fixed annuities, the insurer decides how to invest premiums and manages its general account assets so as to support the contractual guarantees. Thus, for fixed annuities, the insurer bears the investment risk.

A fixed indexed annuity (FIA), also called an indexed annuity, is a type of fixed deferred annuity that offers principal and interest rate guarantees, as well as the possibility of additional earnings based on changes in an index. An index is a statistical measurement system that tracks the changes in a group of similar values. We will describe an FIA’s index-crediting mechanism later in this chapter.

 

Variable Annuities

With a variable annuity, the amount of the accumulated value and the amount of the annuity payments fluctuate in accordance with the performance of one or more subaccounts. Premiums allocated to subaccounts are invested with an insurer’s separate accounts.

Compared to fixed annuities, variable annuities offer customers the possibility of greater investment growth in exchange for more investment risk and fewer guarantees. Because a variable annuity’s contract owner selects subaccounts, the owner—not the insurer—directly bears the investment risk associated with these subaccounts.

To mitigate risk, a variable annuity contract owner can usually place a portion of premiums in a fixed fund option, which guarantees a fixed rate of interest for a specified period of time. Premiums allocated to a fixed fund option are invested with the insurer’s general account. A fixed fund option has virtually the same characteristics as a fixed deferred annuity.

Deferred annuities provide the opportunity for a contract’s invested premiums to grow during the (accumulation / payout) period. If the contract is annuitized, the maturity date marks the beginning of the (accumulation / payout) period.

Annuity Benefits Overview

In general, annuities potentially provide the following benefit types: death benefits, surrender and withdrawal benefits, periodic income payments, and guarantee riders.

One way to look at the benefits under annuities is by contract period. The benefits offered by deferred annuities differ between the accumulation period and the payout period. For example, deferred annuities allow for surrender and withdrawal benefits during the accumulation period, but do not usually provide such benefits during the payout period. The following table shows the potential deferred annuity benefits payable by each annuity period.

Recall that immediate annuities do not have an accumulation period. During the payout period, immediate annuities do not provide surrender and withdrawal benefits.

Another way to look at the benefits under annuities is by annuity type. For instance, fixed immediate annuities have a payout period, but no accumulation period. Therefore, such annuities do not pay death benefits or withdrawal benefits. Because fixed-rate and variable deferred annuities have an accumulation period, they have the potential to pay death benefits, surrender benefits, or withdrawal benefits.

In the following sections, we describe the types of annuity benefits and the cost considerations for each benefit. First, we’ll look at annuity death benefits.

×

pages.title: Annuity Death Benefits
pages.contents:
Annuity Death Benefits

For many types of annuities, the contract owner selects a death benefit or death benefit rider for the contract. (We will cover riders later in the chapter.) In doing so, the owner designates the contract’s beneficiary, which is the person or entity who may receive benefits accrued or values remaining in the annuity contract upon the death of the annuitant.

Depending on which payout option an immediate annuity contract owner selects at the time of purchase, the insurer may or may not make payments to a beneficiary upon the annuitant’s death. For example, one type of payout option guarantees periodic income payments for a certain period and pays the beneficiary if the annuitant dies during that period. Another type of payout option provides the beneficiary with a refund of the unused portion of principal if the annuitant’s death occurs before the insurer has paid out the principal’s full value in periodic income. Such payout options are widely utilized in practice. We describe payout options in greater detail later in this chapter.

For a deferred annuity, the beneficiary receives a standard death benefit if the annuitant dies before the contract has been annuitized. Many deferred annuities also offer optional death benefits for an additional fee that will provide greater death benefits than the standard. The amount of a deferred annuity’s death benefit generally depends on the accumulated value of the contract at the time of the annuitant’s death rather than on the amount of premiums paid. However, certain contracts offer a return of premium death benefit as part of the contract, allowing for the greater of the accumulation value or premiums paid less withdrawals.

The process insurance companies use to estimate the cost of future deferred annuity death benefits is similar to the process they use to estimate the cost of life insurance death benefits, as discussed in the previous chapter. Typically, an insurer

  • Subtracts the expected number of surrenders from the number of in-force contracts at the beginning of the contract year.

  • Applies an appropriate mortality rate to the remaining number of contracts to determine the number of death benefits payable for the year. Because annuitants tend to live longer than life insureds, insurers don’t use the same sets of mortality data for annuity products as they do for life insurance products.

  • Repeats the process for each year of the accumulation period. The total of the future death benefits equals the sum of the projected death benefits payable for each year in the accumulation period.

pages.title: Annuity Surrender and Withdrawal Benefits
pages.contents:
Annuity Surrender and Withdrawal Benefits

Typically, surrender and withdrawal benefits are available during an annuity contract’s accumulation period. Thus, immediate annuities—which do not have accumulation periods—do not usually provide surrender and withdrawal benefits. For deferred annuities, contract owners can (1) surrender the contract or (2) withdraw from the contract’s accumulated value. If the owner surrenders the contract, the surrender value is the accumulated value minus any applicable surrender charge. Recall that insurers generally impose surrender charges that are highest during the early years of a contract and then decrease gradually over time.

When estimating the cost of deferred annuity surrender benefits, insurance companies assume that surrender benefits will be paid at the beginning of each year. They also use mortality rates to estimate the number of annuitants at the beginning of any given year during the accumulation period.

Insurers estimate the cost of surrender benefits for a future year based on the number of in-force contracts at the beginning of the year, the expected surrender rate for each year, and the surrender value per unit. The expected surrender rate is an estimate of the percentage of surrenders during a particular year. Surrender rates for deferred annuities are usually the lowest during the early years of the accumulation period, and spike after the end of the contract’s surrender charge period; such spikes in surrender rates are known as shock lapses.

The formula for estimating the cost of surrender benefits for a particular year n is

Present value of future surrender benefits, Year n = (Number of contracts, beginning of Year n) × (Expected surrender rate, Year n) × (Present value of surrender value per unit, Year n)

To find the total of the future surrender benefits, the insurer sums the annual surrender benefits for each year during the accumulation period.

Insurers must also calculate the cost of withdrawals. Typically, an insurer allows a deferred annuity contract owner to withdraw a specified percentage—usually 5-10 percent—of a contract’s accumulated value each year without charge. Withdrawals in excess of the allowable withdrawal rate are subject to separate surrender charges.

Insurers use the contractually specified withdrawal rate percentages to determine the cost of withdrawals for each year during the accumulation period. For instance, for year n, the formula is as follows:

Withdrawal value, Year n = (Accumulated value) × (Withdrawal rate, Year n)

As with surrenders, the insurer sums the withdrawal values for each year of the accumulation period to determine the total value of withdrawals.

For deferred annuities, surrender rates are usually the (highest / lowest) during the early years of the accumulation period. For partial withdrawals, withdrawals in excess of the deferred annuity contract’s allowable withdrawal rate are subject to separate (shock lapses / surrender charges).

pages.title: Annuity Periodic Income Payments
pages.contents:
Annuity Periodic Income Payments

Another potential benefit of an annuity is the regular income that an insurance company pays during the contract’s payout period. In general, insurers calculate the present values of their future payments and sum the present values to estimate the total cost of periodic income payments.

Insurers make periodic income payments according to a payout option, as selected by annuity contract owners. Two types of payout options are guaranteed annuity payout options and life annuity payout options.

 

Guaranteed Annuity Payout Options

Not every annuity is structured as a life annuity. Guaranteed annuity payout options provide regular payments of either a designated amount or for a designated period and are not linked to any life expectancy or mortality risk. Thus, a guaranteed annuity payout option guarantees that the insurance company will distribute the entire accumulated value of an annuity contract. The two types of guaranteed annuity payout options are

  • The fixed amount option, which requires the contract owner to choose the amount of income that the insurer will pay periodically. With this option, the insurer pays the same amount on a regular basis until the contract value is exhausted.

  • The fixed period option, which requires the annuity owner to choose the length of time the periodic income payments will continue. With this option, the insurer makes payments for a specified period of time regardless of whether the annuitant is living. If the annuitant dies during the payout period, then the contract’s beneficiary receives the remaining payments.

There is an interrelationship between the fixed amount option and the fixed period option. For instance, if a contract owner chooses a fixed amount option, then the amount chosen will influence the number of payments that are made before the contract value is exhausted.

For guaranteed annuity payout options, the insurer’s cost of future payments at the start of the payout period equals the contract’s accumulated value at the maturity date, when the contract is annuitized.

 

Life Annuity Payout Options

For life annuity payout options, insurers promise to make regular income payments for a period related to the life expectancy of one or more annuitants. Life annuity payout options apply to both immediate annuities and deferred annuities. For all of the life annuity payout options, the amount that the insurer pays periodically is based in part on the contract’s accumulated value or the single premium used to purchase the option.

The typical kinds of life annuity payout options are as follows:

  • A single life annuity, also known as a life only annuity or straight life annuity, is a payout option that provides periodic income payments in an amount based on both the single premium and the annuitant’s life expectancy. Under this option, the number of periodic payments is based on the lifetime of the annuitant. The insurer makes regular payments from the beginning of the payout period until the annuitant’s death, after which the company ceases payments. Thus, a single life annuity is the most basic form of a life annuity. For a single life annuity, an insurer calculates the cost of annuity payments over a period extending to the end of the mortality table—for example, to age 120—rather than for a specified number of years.

  • A single life annuity with period certain is a payout option that guarantees periodic income payments throughout the lifetime of the annuitant and also guarantees that the payments will continue for at least a specified period. If the annuitant dies before the end of the specified period, the insurer provides the periodic income payments to the beneficiary until the end of the period. If the annuitant dies after the end of the specified period, the beneficiary does not receive any periodic income payments.

  • A single life with refund annuity is a payout option that guarantees specified periodic income payments throughout the lifetime of the annuitant and also guarantees that the insurer will provide a refund if the annuitant dies before the total of the periodic income payments already made equals the amount paid for the annuity. In such a scenario, the contract’s beneficiary receives the refund, which is the difference between the amount the contract owner paid for the annuity and the total amount of periodic income payments paid to the annuitant prior to her death. The refund of the remaining premium can be paid to the beneficiary as a lump sum (cash refund) or in payments (installment refund).

  • A joint life annuity is a payout option that typically covers more than one life and guarantees periodic income payments until one of the annuitants dies, and then pays nothing more.

  • A joint and survivor (J&S) annuity, also known as a joint and last survivorship annuity, is a payout option that guarantees a series of periodic income payments to two or more annuitants until both or all of the annuitants die. The insurer bases periodic income payments on the life expectancies of the annuitants. Depending on the terms of the annuity, payments may decrease after the first annuitant dies.

Watch Video 11.1 to see how the different life annuity payout options affect an insurer’s payments of periodic income.

Life annuity payout options expose insurers to mortality risk because calculations for life annuities rely on the mortality experience of a population of annuitants. In other words, insurers must estimate the cost of the lifetime guarantees based on the life expectancies of the annuitants. If the actual mortality rate among the product’s annuitants is

  • higher than expected, then the insurer will generally make fewer periodic income payments than projected (meaning the cost to the insurer will be lower than expected)

  • lower than expected, then the insurer will generally make more periodic income payments than projected (meaning the cost to the insurer will be higher than expected)

To calculate the cost of one year’s periodic payments under a life annuity, insurers first find the total number of annuitants living at the beginning of the year. (If calculating for non-annuitized deferred annuities, this step includes subtracting the number of surrenders from the total number of annuitants.) Then, insurers multiply the result by the appropriate mortality factor to determine the number of annuitants still living at the end of the year. Next, they multiply the amount of each periodic payment by the number of surviving annuitants. The sum of the resulting values is the cost for one year for a block of contracts.

As described in Chapter 9, an insurer designing an annuity product can use a lower mortality rate than it expects to experience so as to provide a mortality margin into the design. The mortality margin introduces an element of conservatism into the design by increasing the assumed survivorship rates, thereby increasing the estimated number of payments the insurer will make. If the actual mortality rate among the product’s annuitants is higher than expected, the product is likely to be more profitable than projected because of the lower cost of periodic income payments. (Profitability may also be affected by the length of the accumulation period.)

pages.title: Indexed Crediting for Fixed Indexed Annuities
pages.contents:
Indexed Crediting for Fixed Indexed Annuities

Because fixed indexed annuities (FIAs) are a special type of fixed deferred annuity, they have an accumulated value, a surrender value, a death benefit, and payout options. Although FIAs permit flexible premiums, most are purchased with a single premium.

The main difference between FIAs and nonindexed fixed deferred annuities is the FIA crediting mechanism, known as indexed crediting. With indexed crediting, the FIA contract guarantees that the insurance company will periodically award monetary credits to the contract’s accumulated value on a specified basis; the credits are related to the growth rate in a specified external index of stock prices. The monetary credits awarded to the contract’s value are known as index credits. The specified external index is known as the reference index or the benchmark index. In many FIAs, the reference index is the Standard & Poor’s 500 (S&P 500) index.

FIAs have some features not found in other annuity products. For instance, the contract owner typically must leave the money in the chosen index-crediting method for a specified minimum contract term. The contract term is the length of time over which the insurer will calculate interest for the contract’s accumulated value.

As another example, nonforfeiture laws that apply to all individual deferred annuities set a minimum surrender value typically equal to 87.5 percent of premiums paid, with the surrender value accumulated at 1 to 3 percent interest for the term the contract has been in force. An FIA could, in theory, permit the contract owner to lose some of the premium upon surrender after a prolonged market downturn. However, this outcome is unlikely if the FIA contract contains provisions protecting the value of the premium.

In general, the index-crediting formula calculates index credits by multiplying an FIA contract’s accumulated value by the crediting rate, which is based on the reference index’s growth rate but is affected by provisions. Some indexed-crediting provisions limit how much the insurer contributes to the accumulated value. Other provisions serve to protect the contract owner if the reference index fails to achieve growth. In addition, insurers have several options for calculating index credits.

 

Limiting Provisions

Index-crediting formulas do not typically award the full growth rate of the index to the contract. Rather, these formulas have provisions designed to limit the insurer’s obligation for indexed crediting. The limits are based on economic factors, such as interest rates and credit spreads, as well as the cost of the options that the insurer buys to hedge the contract.

The limiting provisions may include a participation percentage, a cap, or a yield spread:

  • A participation percentage provision stipulates the rate at which the insurer shares the reference index’s growth with the contract owner. For example, for a period in which the reference index grows in value by 10 percent, a participation percentage of 60 percent reduces the growth rate credited to the contract’s accumulated value to 6 percent (found as 0.10 × 0.60 = 0.06).

  • A cap is an upper limit, expressed as a percent, on the rate of a reference index’s gain in value that the insurer credits to the annuity contract as interest. For instance, suppose an FIA contract has a provision that sets the cap at 10 percent. For a period in which the value of the reference index grows by 12 percent, the insurer limits the rate of interest it credits to the contract to the capped rate of 10 percent. An index-crediting formula may combine a participation percentage provision and an interest-rate cap; if combined, the insurer typically applies the participation percentage provision first, then the cap.

  • A yield spread provision states that the insurer always deducts a specified percentage from the growth rate in the reference index. For example, for a period in which the value of the reference index grows by 12 percent, a yield spread of 3 percent reduces the growth rate the insurer credits to the contract’s accumulated value to 9 percent (found as 12% - 3%). For another period, if the reference index grows by 5 percent, then the rate credited to the contract is 2 percent (found as 5% - 3%). The yield spread provision is less common than the interest-rate cap and the participation percentage provision.

 

Protecting Provisions

While some provisions limit the insurer’s sharing of the reference index growth with FIA contracts, other provisions protect contract owners by guaranteeing that they will not lose any portion of their premiums in the contract. Two examples of such provisions are the floor provision and the return of premium provision:

  • A floor provision specifies that the contract’s values are not reduced if the linked index decreases in value during a measurement period. Floor provisions typically guarantee that the index credit for the contract’s term cannot be less than zero. However, the index credit for a single period within the contract term can be zero.

  • Laws and regulations may permit the surrender value to fall below 100 percent of premiums. However, FIA contracts sometimes include a return of premium provision, under which the insurer promises to pay the contract owner the full value of premiums—minus any partial withdrawals—upon surrender if the contract has not built an accumulated value greater than the value promised in the provision.

 

Index Credit Calculation Methods

An insurance company’s first step in determining the amount of index credits to award to an FIA contract is to establish the contract term. Most FIAs have terms that range from one year to ten years, with six or seven years being the most common.

Insurers can calculate the index credits an FIA receives in a variety of ways. Rather than attempt to describe all the variations, we present three basic methods: the annual reset method, the point-to-point method, and the high water mark method.

 

Annual Reset Method

The annual reset method, also known as the ratchet method, involves comparing the value of the reference index at the start of each contract year with the value at the end of the year. For the next year, the starting value is “reset” to the ending value from the previous year. Under this method, the index values are reset at the beginning of each contract year during the term of the contract.

The annual reset method allows the contract owner to lock in gains each year and avoid losses. When the market goes up, the contract owner earns excess interest. When the market remains stable or goes down, the contract neither gains nor loses value. The following insight provides an example of applying the annual reset method.

INSIGHT

Applying the Annual Reset Method

Madeline Zelpha purchased an FIA with a single premium of $100,000. This FIA has a 90 percent participation percentage, a 12 percent cap, and no yield spread. As the contract owner, Madeline chose the annual reset method of calculating index growth. The reference index’s values change as shown in the following table:

The accumulated value of Madeline’s FIA grows as follows:

At the end of the first year, the 20 percent growth in the index is adjusted for the participation percentage of 90 percent as follows: 0.20 × 0.90 = 0.18, or 18 percent. Because 18 percent exceeds the cap of 12 percent, the contract value of $100,000 grows by 12 percent, resulting in $112,000 (found as $100,000 × 1.12).

For the second year, the index grew 10 percent. Adjusting for the participation percentage of 90 percent, the insurer calculates 9 percent as the interest rate to apply to the contract (found as 0.10 × 0.90). Because 9 percent is less than the cap of 12 percent, the contract grows by 9 percent, as follows: $112,000 × 1.09 = $122,080.

The index dropped in value for the third and fourth years, so the insurer did not credit the contract’s accumulated value with interest for either of those years.

For the fifth year, the index grew by 10 percent, the same value for the second year. Thus, the contract value for this year grew by 90 percent of 10 percent, or 9 percent (0.10 × 0.90). Again, 9 percent is less than the cap of 12 percent. Therefore, the contract value at the end of the fifth year is $122,080 × 1.09 = $133,067.20.

 

Point-to-Point Method

The point-to-point method compares the value of the reference index at the start of the annuity contract term to the value at the end of the term to determine what, if any, interest has accrued because of a change in the index. If the value of the index at the end of the term is higher than the value at the beginning of the term, the contract’s accumulated value will earn index credits. If the index shows negative growth or no growth, the accumulated value will not be credited.

Because earnings depend only on the value of the index at the end of the term, they are insulated from the effects of short-term fluctuations during the term. As long as the index values rise overall, the insulating effect can be an advantage. On the other hand, if values over the term stagnate or decline, it can be a disadvantage because contract owners cannot lock in short-term gains.

EXAMPLE

Let’s assume that our FIA owner, Madeline Zelpha, has the same contract as described in the insight above, with the same index growth as shown in the table. Instead of the annual reset method, she picks the point-to-point method.

Analysis: With the point-to-point method, computing the index growth is relatively easy because there are only two values to compare: the value of the index at the beginning of the contract term, 500, and the value at the end of the contract term, 605. The growth in the index, therefore, is found as follows:

$100,000 × 1.12 = $112,000.

The index growth of 21 percent, adjusted for the participation percentage of 90 percent, is equal to 0.189 (found as 0.21 × 0.90), or 18.9 percent. This value exceeds the cap of 12 percent, so the contract’s accumulated value earns 12 percent in interest for the term, calculated as follows:

 

High Water Mark Method

The high water mark method compares the value of the reference index at the beginning of the contract term with the highest value—or high water mark—that the index reaches on any contract anniversary date during the term. If the index has gained in value on the high water mark compared to the value at the beginning of the term, the contract’s accumulated value earns index credits for the contract term. However, if the index value at the high water mark is the same as or less than the index value at the start of the contract term, the accumulated value does not earn index credits. As a result, this method—like the annual reset method and the point-to-point method—allows the contract owner to take advantage of index gains without being subject to index losses.

The advantage of using high water marks rather than year-end or term-end values is that earnings are not dependent on index growth at the end of each contract year or at the end of the term. According to this method, the index need only show growth on any contract anniversary date in order to earn index credits.

EXAMPLE

Now suppose that Madeline Zelpha purchased her FIA contract with a single premium payment of $100,000 and chose the high water mark method of crediting interest. This FIA has an 80 percent participation percentage and no cap or yield spread. (The high water mark method does not generally impose caps.)

The reference index values are the following on the purchase date and each of the four contract anniversary dates:

Purchase date = 500
Anniversary 1 = 540
Anniversary 2 = 600
Anniversary 3 = 550
Anniversary 4 = 480

Analysis: As with the point-to-point method, only two values matter: the value of the index at the beginning of the contract term—500—and the highest value that the index reached on any contract anniversary date—600. The growth in the index, therefore, is found as follows:

The index growth of 20 percent, adjusted for the participation percentage of 80 percent, is equal to 16 percent (0.20 × 0.80 = 0.16). As a result, the contract’s accumulated value earns 16 percent in interest for the term:

$100,000 × 1.16 = $116,000.

pages.title: Variable Annuity Guarantee Riders
pages.contents:
Variable Annuity Guarantee Riders

As you read earlier, a variable annuity allows a contract owner to choose investments for the contract via the insurance company’s subaccount menu. The contract's value fluctuates in accordance with the performance of the selected subaccounts. As such, growth in a variable contract’s accumulated value is not certain.

Recall that for variable annuities, the contract owner bears the investment risk for subaccount performance. Variable annuity owners seeking to mitigate their investment risk can obtain guaranteed benefits in the form of riders. Because the insurer guarantees variable annuity rider benefits, it administers variable annuity riders within its general account, as it does with fixed annuities. (Variable annuity premiums allocated to subaccounts are managed through an insurer’s separate accounts.)

The rider charge, or rider premium, is the additional charge for a variable annuity contract owner to purchase a rider. Typically, the rider charge is a specified percentage—such as 0.75 percent—of the contract’s benefit base, which is different than its accumulated value. The benefit base, also called the income base, is a theoretical account value that grows at a guaranteed rate—as specified in the variable annuity contract—and is used as the basis for calculating guaranteed withdrawal amounts.

The rider charge, which the insurer subtracts from the contract’s accumulated value, covers the company’s costs for the following elements:

  • Administrative expenses to support the rider

  • Capital requirements to support the rider

  • The cost of managing risk, including the costs of investing in options for hedging

  • Variability in risk management costs

  • Variability in pricing assumptions, including policyholder behavior and market interest rates

Some of the variable annuity guarantee riders available to contract owners include types of guaranteed minimum death benefit riders and living benefit riders.

 

Guaranteed Minimum Death Benefit Riders

A guaranteed minimum death benefit (GMDB) generally guarantees that the variable annuity death benefit will at least equal a specified minimum amount. Most variable annuities specify a minimum amount equal to the greater of (1) all premiums paid—adjusted for withdrawals—or (2) the contract’s accumulated value at the time of the annuitant’s death.

EXAMPLE

Wei-Chao Chen purchases a variable deferred annuity with a single premium payment of $500,000. Mr. Chen is the contract’s owner and its annuitant. Mr. Chen’s variable annuity has a GMDB equal to the greater of all premiums paid—adjusted for withdrawals—and the accumulated value at the date of death. When Mr. Chen dies, he has taken no withdrawals from his annuity and his contract’s accumulated value has fallen to $300,000.

Analysis: The contract’s accumulated value—$300,000—fell below the premium amount that Mr. Chen paid—$500,000. Therefore, the death benefit of his annuity is the greater of the two values: $500,000.

Variable annuity guaranteed death benefits continue to evolve in ways that benefit contract owners and their beneficiaries. Because newer forms of GMDBs generally result in higher guaranteed death benefits, they are more expensive than the traditional guaranteed death benefit described above. These newer forms of GMDBs include annually compounded death benefits, ratcheted death benefits, and highest anniversary value death benefits. As you’ll see, no matter what kind of GMDB a variable annuity has, the beneficiary always receives the greatest value available—whether it’s the accumulated value or a specified benefit—as stated in the contract.

 

Annually Compounded Death Benefit

The annually compounded death benefit resembles the common guaranteed minimum death benefit described above. The difference is that the contract’s principal (minus withdrawals) is compounded annually at a specified rate, such as 3–5 percent per year.

EXAMPLE

Assume that Mr. Chen’s variable annuity in the previous example has a guaranteed death benefit that applies 3 percent annual compounding to the principal. Five years after purchasing his variable annuity, his initial premium payment of $500,000 has grown as follows:

Year 1 end value = $500,000 × 1.03 = $515,000
Year 2 end value = $515,000 × 1.03 = $530,450
Year 3 end value = $530,450 × 1.03 = $546,363.50
Year 4 end value = $546,363.50 × 1.03 = $562,754.41
Year 5 end value = $562,754.41 × 1.03 = $579,637.04

Analysis: Suppose Mr. Chen dies five years after purchasing his variable annuity. His beneficiary will receive $579,637.04, as long as that death benefit base amount is greater than the contract’s accumulated value and there were no withdrawals.

 

Ratcheted Death Benefit

Under the ratcheted death benefit, the insurer resets the contract’s death benefit at periodic intervals, based on growth in the accumulated value. The most common reset period is in the four- to six-year range. Once the insurer resets the death benefit, it can never be less than this amount, unless there are withdrawals from the contract.

EXAMPLE

Assume that Mr. Chen’s variable annuity has a ratcheted death benefit with a five-year reset period. Five years after he purchases his variable annuity, his contract’s accumulated value has grown to $580,000. Thus, the insurer resets the death benefit of Mr. Chen’s variable annuity to $580,000. If, after five more years, the accumulated value is even higher, that new value would become the guaranteed death benefit.

 

Highest Anniversary Value Death Benefit

The highest anniversary value death benefit is a variation of the ratcheted death benefit. The difference is that, instead of resetting the death benefit at predetermined intervals—such as every five years—the death benefit is reset every anniversary year in which the accumulated value increases.

EXAMPLE

Let’s assume that Mr. Chen’s variable annuity has a guaranteed death benefit that has a highest anniversary value reset feature. Mr. Chen purchased his variable annuity with a single premium of $500,000 on March 5, 2017. His contract’s accumulated value on its anniversary date is as follows:

March 5, 2018 $480,000
March 5, 2019 $550,000
March 5, 2020 $525,000

Analysis: On March 5, 2018—the first anniversary date—the contract’s accumulated value had fallen to $480,000. Thus, the insurer did not apply the reset, and the contract’s guaranteed death benefit equaled Mr. Chen’s premium payment of $500,000 (assuming no withdrawals). On March 5, 2019, the accumulated value had grown, so the insurer reset the death benefit to $550,000. On the next anniversary date—March 5, 2020—the insurer did not reset the death benefit because the accumulated value fell from the previous anniversary date.

If Mr. Chen were to die in July 2020, his beneficiary would receive $550,000—assuming this amount is greater than the contract’s accumulated value and no withdrawals were taken from the contract after the reset.

 

Living Benefit Riders

Variable annuity guaranteed living benefits can be referred to as “GLBs.” Living benefits typically offer some type of guaranteed benefit while the annuitant is alive. When a variable annuity contract owner purchases a living benefit rider, the contract essentially has two values: the accumulated value and the living benefit value, which is based on the insurance company’s guarantees for that particular contract. Because living benefits are guaranteed, insurers must establish reserves for them and be prepared to make benefit payments that become due.

From a customer’s perspective, living benefits can provide protection against market losses: if a variable annuity contract’s accumulated value falls due to poor market performance, the living benefit value is unaffected. Thus, variable annuity contract owners can use living benefit riders to hedge their investment risk. Put differently, living benefit riders essentially enable variable annuity contract owners to share their investment risk with insurers.

From an insurer’s perspective, living benefits introduce the risk that a variable annuity’s separate account assets will not be sufficient to cover the contract’s living benefit value, thus necessitating contributions from the insurer’s general account assets. Because living benefit riders increase the risk assumed by insurers, most insurers impose limits on the investment choices of variable annuity contract owners who purchase living benefits. For example, insurers may not offer some of the most aggressive subaccounts to contract owners who select a GLB.

Most variable annuity contracts offer one or more of the following living benefit riders: guaranteed minimum income benefits, guaranteed minimum withdrawal benefits, guaranteed lifetime withdrawal benefits, and guaranteed minimum accumulation benefits.

 

Guaranteed Minimum Income Benefit

The guaranteed minimum income benefit (GMIB) is a living benefit rider that guarantees a minimum protected value that can be converted into periodic income payments—usually after a waiting period of seven to ten years—even if the variable annuity’s accumulated value declines because of poor investment performance. The minimum protected value may specify some growth of the principal, such as an annual compound interest rate, or locked-in investment gains at maximum contract anniversary values. The GMIB requires the contract owner to annuitize the contract to receive the benefit.

EXAMPLE

Let’s return to our variable annuity contract owner, Wei-Chao Chen, who purchases his variable annuity with a single premium payment of $500,000. Assume that Mr. Chen also purchases a GMIB rider that stipulates a growth rate of 5 percent compounded per year. The GMIB rider requires a waiting period of 10 years.

Analysis: After 10 years, the accumulated value of Mr. Chen’s annuity is $450,000. However, the living benefit value is $814,447.31, found as $500,000 × (1.05) 10 . Mr. Chen could decide to annuitize his variable annuity and receive annual income payments based on the living benefit value. If he annuitizes his contract, his insurer would determine the lifetime payment amount by applying a guaranteed annuitization rate that was stipulated in the rider at the contract’s issue.

 

Guaranteed Minimum Withdrawal Benefit

The guaranteed minimum withdrawal benefit (GMWB) is a living benefit rider that guarantees a minimum protected value against which a variable annuity contract owner may make annual withdrawals of a specified amount, without charge, even if the contract’s accumulated value falls below the protected value as a result of poor investment performance. GMWB riders offer contract owners some protection against market downturns without requiring annuitization of contracts.

EXAMPLE

Instead of a GMIB, assume that Mr. Chen purchases a GMWB that stipulates he can annually withdraw 5 percent of the contract’s principal of $500,000. One year later, the accumulated value of his contract is $400,000. Mr. Chen decides to use the living benefit to make a withdrawal from his contract.

Analysis: Mr. Chen withdraws $25,000 (found as $500,000 × 0.05). Because of his GMWB rider, Mr. Chen could withdraw $25,000 a year until he has used up the contract’s protected value. At that rate of withdrawal, the protected value of $500,000 should last for 20 years (found as $500,000 ÷ $25,000 per year = 20 years).

 

Guaranteed Lifetime Withdrawal Benefit

Closely related to the GMWB, the guaranteed lifetime withdrawal benefit (GLWB) is a living benefit rider that guarantees minimum withdrawals to a variable annuity owner for life. The main difference between the GMWB and the GLWB is duration: GMWB withdrawals are guaranteed for a specified period, while GLWB withdrawals are guaranteed for the life of the contract owner. For the GLWB, the withdrawal amount is usually specified as a percentage of the contract’s living benefit value or accumulated value, whichever is greater. With a GLWB, the contract owner is not required to annuitize the contract.

EXAMPLE

Now assume that Mr. Chen’s GMWB is a GLWB. One year after purchasing his variable annuity, Mr. Chen decides to use the living benefit. The accumulated value of his contract is $400,000, and the principal is $500,000.

Analysis: Because the contract’s principal amount of $500,000 is higher than its accumulated value of $400,000, the insurer bases the GLWB calculation on the principal amount. The insurer uses Mr. Chen’s current age to determine the percentage that will apply to the principal. This percentage of the principal is the amount that will be withdrawn and disbursed to Mr. Chen for the rest of his life. The insurer determines that Mr. Chen’s withdrawal rate is 5%, so he will receive lifetime annual disbursements of $25,000 (found as $500,000 × 0.05).

 

Guaranteed Minimum Accumulation Benefit

A guaranteed minimum accumulation benefit (GMAB) is a living benefit rider that guarantees a minimum protected value for a variable annuity contract even if its accumulated value declines because of poor investment performance. Usually, the contract owner must wait for a specified period—typically from seven to ten years—before the guaranteed value provided under the GMAB becomes available.

The amount of the GMAB’s protected value is generally equal to a return of the contract owner’s premium or the premium plus a modest growth factor. With a GMAB, the contract owner is not required to annuitize the contract and thus can still earn future investment gains.

EXAMPLE

Let’s say that Mr. Chen purchases a GMAB based on the annuity contract’s principal of $500,000. The living benefit has a required waiting period of eight years. Eight years later, the accumulated value of Mr. Chen’s contract has fallen to $280,000.

pages.title: Summary of Annuity Product Costs and Charges
pages.contents:
Summary of Annuity Product Costs and Charges

As you have read, annuity contract owners can choose from several annuity types, indicate their preferences for receiving periodic income and other contract benefits, and choose different kinds of riders for their contracts.

During annuity product technical design, insurers must project the costs of the types of benefits the product will provide. For instance, finding the cost of an annuity’s periodic income payments requires finding the sum of the present values of all future payments. The periodic payment amount, assumed interest rate, and number of expected payments are all factors in the insurer’s present value calculations. The insurer calculates present value as of the beginning of the payout period.

The total cost of benefits for an annuity equals the sum of the present value of each potential benefit multiplied by the expected probability that each benefit will be payable. For example, the cost of benefits calculation for a new fixed deferred annuity product with death benefits, surrender benefits, and periodic income benefits is calculated using the following formula:

Cost of annuity benefits = (Present value of death benefits × Probability that benefits will be payable)
+
(Present value of surrender benefits × Probability that benefits will be payable)
+
(Present value of periodic income benefits × Probability that benefits will be payable)

In addition to the cost of benefits, an annuity product’s design must account for the other financial components described earlier in the text. For instance, product design includes considerations of investment earnings. As you read in Chapter 7, how an insurer incorporates investment earnings into an annuity contract depends on whether the contract is fixed or variable.

Annuity product design must also consider operating expenses, which you read about in Chapter 9. For immediate annuities, insurers typically incorporate operating expenses into the premium. For most deferred annuity products, insurers offset at least some operating expenses by means of explicit charges—such as surrender charges—to customers. Examples of other explicit charges associated with variable deferred annuities include contract maintenance charges, M&E risk charges, fund operating expense charges, and rider charges.

figure11-1.title: Key Periods for Immediate and Deferred Annuities
alt:
Three annuity timelines.

The Immediate Annuity timeline consists of a payout period that begins on an issue date, and is marked by periodic income payments.

The Non-Annuitized Deferred Annuity timeline consists of an accumulation period that begins on a purchase date.

The Annuitized Deferred Annuity timeline consists of an accumulation period that begins on a purchase date, reaches a maturity date, and then transitions into a payout period. The payout period is marked by periodic income payments.
